EXAMPLES OF POTENTIAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF VIRUS OR PATHOGEN TRANSMISSION AND PREVENTION AMONGST HERDS, THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW VACCINES, AND NEW MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT FOSTER ANIMAL WELLBEING.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES BENEFICIARIES OF THESE RESEARCH PROJECTS INCLUDE FOOD ANIMAL PRODUCERS, VETERINARIANS, ANIMAL NUTRITIONISTS, THE PUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR, AND OTHER ANIMAL, PHARMACEUTICAL, AND BIOMEDICAL SCIENTISTS. THE PUBLIC AT LARGE ALSO BENEFITS FROM ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT HELP MAINTAIN A SAFE, SECURE, AND HUMANE FOOD SUPPLY.

ABSTRACT FOR FY2023 ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM APPLICATION UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY WILL USE OUR FY2023 ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM CAPACITY FUNDS TO CONDUCT ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH, TO PUBLISH AND DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS OF SUCH RESEARCH, AND TO PURCHASE EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES NECESSARY FOR CONDUCTING SUCH RESEARCH.  THESE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ALIGN WITH ONE OF THE CRITICAL ISSUES DEFINED IN THE UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY FY2023 PLAN OF WORK, GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY AND HUNGER. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS CRITICAL ISSUE IS TO ENHANCE GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY THROUGH PRODUCTIVE AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS. ANIMAL HEALTH IS AT THE CORE OF ALL ANIMAL PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. WE CAN MAKE REAL PROGRESS IN IMPROVING FOOD SECURITY, NOT ONLY IN THE U.S., BUT THROUGHOUT THE WORLD. TO FEED GROWING POPULATIONS, WE MUST DEVELOP ANIMALS THAT ARE MORE STRESS- AND DISEASE-RESISTANT AND INCREASE THE OVERALL PRODUCTIVITY OF LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. FUTURE INVESTIGATIONS WILL INCLUDE TRADITIONAL LIVESTOCK BREEDING BUT WILL ALSO EMPHASIZE GENOMICS. MORE FOCUS WILL NEED TO BE GIVEN TO THE "SCIENCE" OF AGRICULTURE. ANIMALS MUST BE MADE MORE EFFICIENT IN THE USE OF EXISTING OR EVEN ALTERED FORAGE RESOURCES.  THE RESEARCH CONDUCTED WITH THESE FUNDS WILL RESULT IN DELIVERABLES THAT INCLUDE PRESENTATIONS AT SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS, SCIENTIFIC AND LAY PUBLICATIONS, OUTREACH ACTIVITIES INCLUDING EXTENSION EVENTS AND FACT SHEETS, AND TOOLS OR DEVICES DESIGNED TO ADDRESS SPECIFIC NEEDS. IMPACTS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL INCLUDE CHANGES IN KNOWLEDGE, CHANGES IN ACTIONS, AND CHANGES IN CONDITIONS. THIS RESEARCH WILL BENEFIT RANCHERS AND LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS; VETERINARIANS; THE CITIZENS OF THE STATE OF UTAH, THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, THE COUNTRY, AND THE INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY; STATE AND NATIONAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES; AND THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY.

CAPACITY GRANT FOR FY 23 UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA SCHOOL OF VETERINARY MEDICINE IDENTIFIER # 042250712  ABSTRACT  THE PROPOSED STUDIES WILL EVALUATE SEVERAL AREAS VITAL TO THE UNDERSTANDING OF HEALTH, DISEASE AND TREATMENT IN AGRICULTURALLY-IMPORTANT ANIMALS. WE PROPOSE FOUR STUDIES FOR THE FUNDING REQUESTED. THE FIRST STUDY IS IN BROILER CHICKENS. THERE ARE TWO MAIN METHODS FOR CATCHING THESE CHICKENS FOR INSPECTION, TREATMENT, AND PROCESSING. THE PROPOSED STUDY COMPARES BIRD HEALTH OUTCOMES AND STRESS WHEN MECHANICAL CATCHING MACHINES ARE USED TO CATCH BIRDS FOR TRANSPORT TO SLAUGHTER OR HUMANS ARE USED TO CATCH THE BIRDS. BLOOD COLLECTED AFTER SLAUGHTER WILL BE ANALYZED FOR MARKERS OF STRESS. TWO STUDIES WILL BE CONDUCTED IN SMALL RUMINANTS. POINT-OF-CARE ANALYZERS CAN IMMEDIATELY GIVE INFORMATION ON BLOOD GAS AND ELECTROLYTE LEVELS IN PATIENTS, WHICH LETS THE VETERINARIAN DEVISE THE TREATMENTS NEEDED FOR THAT ANIMAL WITHOUT THE DELAY ASSOCIATED WITH SENDING SAMPLES TO A LABORATORY. THE PROPOSED STUDY SEEKS TO VALIDATE THE USE OF A COMMERCIAL POINT-OF-CARE ANALYZER IN GOATS TO DETERMINE IF THE RESULTS FROM THE ANALYZER CAN BE USED CONFIDENTLY TO GUIDE DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT. BLOOD WILL BE COLLECTED FROM 50 GOATS THAT ARE PATIENTS AT THE VETERINARY HOSPITAL. THE BLOOD WILL BE ANALYZED BY THE POINT-OF-CARE ANALYZER AND BY THREE DIFFERENT STANDARD BENCH-TOP MACHINES. THE DATA WILL BE ANALYZED TO DETERMINE THE AGREEMENT OF THE POINT-OF-CARE ANALYZER WITH VALUES OBTAINED BY THE STANDARD METHODS. OUR SECOND STUDY ON SMALL RUMINANTS FOCUSES ON ANESTHESIA. TREATMENT OF SMALL RUMINANTS FOR CONDITIONS SUCH AS BLADDER STONES AND RUMEN DISORDERS MAY INVOLVE ANESTHESIA, AND INHALANT ANESTHETICS SUCH AS DESFLUORANE ARE BEING USED MORE FREQUENTLY TO PROVIDE SAFE ANESTHESIA AND RAPID RECOVERY. LARGE ANIMAL PATIENTS REQUIRE MORE DESFLURANE THAN DO SMALL ANIMALS, AND ARE TYPICALLY DETACHED FROM THE ANESTHETIC BREATHING CIRCUIT DURING RECOVERY, WHICH LEADS TO THE ELIMINATION OF ANESTHETIC GASES DIRECTLY INTO THE ENVIRONMENT. IN THIS STUDY, THE OFF-GASSING OF DESFLUORANE WILL BE MEASURED DURING RECOVERY OF SMALL RUMINANT PATIENTS IN OUR VETERINARY HOSPITAL. ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLING OF THE OPERATING ROOM, ANESTHESIA MACHINE, AND ANESTHESIA WORKING AREA WILL BE PERFORMED FOR ONE MONTH. ENVIRONMENTAL LEVELS AND DOSIMETER BADGE RESULTS WILL BE ANALYZED TO DOCUMENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION AND EXPOSURE DURING THE ONE-MONTH SAMPLING TIMEFRAME. OUR FOURTH STUDY IS ON EVALUATION OF THE EFFECTS OF MANIPULATION OF THE RUMEN MICROBIOME ON METHANE EMISSIONS IN CATTLE. IT IS CRITICAL THAT METHANE EMISSIONS CAN BE MEASURED PRECISELY. FOR THIS STUDY, WE WILL REQUIRE ANALYZERS TO CAPTURE BREATH SAMPLES FROM COWS AND THEN PROVIDE THE COMPOSITION OF INDIVIDUAL GASES IN THE EXPIRED AIR, INCLUDING CARBON DIOXIDE, METHANE, AND HYDROGEN.

UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH FUND ABSTRACT THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH THAT ADDRESSES PRESSING ISSUE IN ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE PREVENTION OR TREATMENT. FOR FY23, THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE AWARD WILL SUPPORT RESEARCH THAT SEEKS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND INFLAMMATION IN AGRICULTURAL ANIMALS USING THE THOROUGHBRED RACEHORSE AS A MODEL. THE PROJECT WILL LOOK AT CHANGES IN MRNA EXPRESSION BETWEEN EXERCISED AND NON-EXERCISED HORSE, AS WELL AS NON-INJURED AND INJURED HORSES FROM RACING IN KENTUCKY. BY BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE MRNA EXPRESSION IN ANIMALS PREDISPOSED TO INJURY, WE MAY DEVISE A METHOD FOR IDENTIFYING AGRICULTURAL ANIMALS AT RISK FOR INJURY AND LAMENESS. MANAGING GENETIC FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO INJURY RISK THROUGH BETTER BREEDING OR ENVIRONMENT CAN HELP IMPROVE ANIMAL WELFARE IN THE FUTURE. DELIVERABLES FROM THE RESEARCH PROGRAMS SUPPORTED BY ANIMAL DISEASE AND HEALTH RESEARCH FUNDING INCLUDE NEW DATA, SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS, AND GRADUATE STUDENTS TRAINED THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN THE PROJECT. BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE ANIMAL GENETICISTS AND BREEDERS

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY THE OREGON AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (OAES) AND THE OSU EXTENSION SERVICE (OSUES) AT OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY PROVIDE THE PEOPLE OF OREGON WITH RESEARCH-BASED KNOWLEDGE AND EDUCATION THAT FOCUS ON STRENGTHENING COMMUNITIES AND ECONOMIES, SUSTAINING NATURAL RESOURCES, AND PROMOTING HEALTHY FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS. OAES IS OREGON'S PRINCIPAL SOURCE OF KNOWLEDGE RELATING TO AGRICULTURAL AND FOOD SYSTEMS, AND A MAJOR SOURCE OF KNOWLEDGE REGARDING ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, NATURAL RESOURCES, LIFE SCIENCES, AND RURAL ECONOMIES AND COMMUNITIES WORLDWIDE. OSUES WORKS TO USE RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION TO CREATE POSITIVE IMPACTS ON COMMUNITY LIVABILITY, ECONOMIC VITALITY, AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES SUSTAINABILITY, AND THE HEALTH AND WELL- BEING OF PEOPLE. PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS CONDUCTED BY OAES AND OSUES ARE COMPLEMENTARY AND CROSS DISCIPLINARY LINES TO MORE FULLY ADDRESS CRITICAL ISSUES AT THE LOCAL, REGIONAL AND NATIONAL LEVELS. THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES’ OAES OFFICE REFLECTS THESE VALUES: VALUE 1: RESPONSIVENESS - WE REACT IN A TIMELY FASHION TO THE NEEDS OF THOSE WE SERVE; VALUE 2: PARTNERSHIP AND COOPERATION - WE COLLABORATE WITH INDIVIDUALS, ORGANIZATIONS, BUSINESSES, AND AGENCIES OUTSIDE THE UNIVERSITY; VALUE 3: TEAMWORK AND COORDINATION - WE SYNCHRONIZE OUR EFFORTS AMONG OUR UNITS AND WITH OTHER UNITS AT THE UNIVERSITY; VALUE 4: CREDIBILITY - WE FOCUS ON BEING KNOWN AS A SOURCE OF RELIABLE, OBJECTIVE, RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION AND EDUCATION. THE CORE VALUES AND OPERATING PRINCIPLES OF OSUES ARE: VALUE 1: COMMUNITY-BASED - WE VALUE COMMUNITY RELATIONSHIPS AND CONNECT OSU TO LOCAL PEOPLE AND ISSUES TO ENHANCE THE PRESENT AND THE FUTURE OF THE PEOPLE AND COMMUNITIES OF OREGON. VALUE 2: ACCOUNTABILITY - WE FOCUS ON ACHIEVING MEASURABLE OUTCOMES, AND DOCUMENT AND COMMUNICATE THE IMPACT AND VALUE OF OUR WORK. VALUE 3: CREDIBILITY - WE DELIVER RELEVANT, RESEARCH-BASED KNOWLEDGE THROUGH OUR EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS. VALUE 4: DIVERSITY - WE EXHIBIT RESPECT, VALUE DIFFERING PERCEPTIONS AND WORLD VIEWS, AND ENCOURAGE DIVERSITY. VALUE 5: PARTNERSHIPS - WE COLLABORATE WITH ACADEMIC, PUBLIC, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO ACHIEVE GREATER RESULTS AND BUILD COMMUNITY CA PACITY. WE VALUE THE PUBLIC GOOD THAT COMES FROM COLLABORATING WITH VOLUNTEERS. VALUE 6: RESPONSIVENESS - WE ENGAGE WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO IDENTIFY PRIORITY ISSUES AND NEEDS, TO DESIGN TIMELY RESPONSES, AND TO BUILD FUTURE CAPABILITY.  TO CARRY OUT ITS MISSION IN A MANNER CONSISTENT WITH UNIVERSITY GOALS, OAES USES ITS RESOURCES TO ADVANCE KNOWLEDGE IN THE FOLLOWING AREAS OF EMPHASIS: 1) NEW VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS AND MARKETS THAT LEVERAGE THE ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTIONS OF OREGON AGRICULTURE. 2) NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT AND POLICY THROUGH DISCOVERY AND LEARNING TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF OUR NATURAL AND WORKING LANDSCAPES AS A SYSTEM. 3) INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS THAT HELP ASSURE ECONOMICALLY SUSTAINABLE, ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND AND RESILIENT AGRICULTURE.     THEOSUES GOALS FOR ADVANCING THE ORGANIZATION'S MISSION TO ALIGN WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S STRATEGIC PLANS INCLUDE: GOAL 1: IMPROVE ACCESS TO HIGH-QUALITY LEARNER SERVICES - EXTENSION PROVIDES ACCESS TO THE KNOWLEDGE RESOURCES OF OSU BY BEING FOCUSED AND NIMBLE IN ENGAGING OREGON'S DIVERSE PEOPLE AND COMMUNITIES IN HIGH-QUALITY LEANER SERVICES THAT HELP BUILD SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITY FUTURES. GOAL 2: INVEST FOR EXCELLENCE AND IMPACT - EXTENSION WORKS TO INCREASE AND DIVERSITY ITS FUNDING BASE AND ENCOURAGE PROGRAM EXCELLENCE THROUGH STRATEGIC INVESTMENTS WITHIN FOUR THEMATIC AREAS: HEALTHY COMMUNITIES AND ECONOMIES; RESILIENT AND PRODUCTIVE FORESTRY AND NATURAL ECOSYSTEMS; SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE, FOOD SYSTEMS, AND GARDENING; THRIVING YOUTH, INDIVIDUALS, AND FAMILIES. THIS WILL CREATE MEASURABLE OUTCOMES AND IMPACTS THAT WILL BE REPORTED WIDELY TO STAKEHOLDERS. GOAL 3: INCREASE EFFECTIVENESS WITH APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY - EXTENSION USES ESTABLISHED AND NEW TECHNOLOGIES STRATEGICALLY TO INCREASE EFFICIENCIES, EXPAND OUTREACH AND ENHANCE AND REPORT THE OUTCOMES OF ITS EDUCATIONAL SERVICES.  THE AES STATION UNITS ACROSS THE STATE, UTILIZE INPUT FROM AFFILIATED ADVISORY COMMITTEES, FROM FACULTY RESEARCH EXPERTS, LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING FARMERS AND RANCHERS, FORESTERS, AGENCY PERSONNEL, ELECTED LEADERS, EDUCATORS, HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND MYRIAD OTHER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ENTITIES TO ESTABLISH NEED AND DESIGN APPROPRIATE PROGRAMMING. IN MANY CASES, STAKEHOLDERS ARE DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN THE PROGRAMMING AS VOLUNTEERS OR BY PERMITTING DEMONSTRATIONS AND APPLIED RESEARCH TRIALS ON THEIR PROPERTIES. WE RECENTLY AUGMENTED OUR ABILITIES TO CONNECT WITH STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS DIVERSE INTEREST AREAS AND TO GAIN ADVICE REGARDING FUTURE RESEARCH PRIORITIES FOR THE PEOPLE OF OREGON WITH THE FORMATION OF A RESEARCH COMMUNITY ADVISORY NETWORK (RCAN) TO PROVIDE INPUT TO THE OAES ON CURRENT AND FUTURE RESEARCH NEEDS. ADDITIONALLY, FACULTY MEMBERS UTILIZE CRITICAL DEMOGRAPHIC AND ECONOMIC DATA, AND EXAMINE CURRENT RESEARCH FINDINGS TO IDENTIFY SOCIETAL NEEDS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR SIGNIFICANT SOCIAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS. PROGRAMMING IS THEN PLANNED BASED ON INPUT WITHIN OAES, EXTERNAL ADVISORY GROUPS, AND IN EACH OTHER ACADEMIC COLLEGES/PROGRAMS (I.E. FORESTRY, AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES, HEALTH AND HUMAN SCIENCES) AND ASSOCIATED EXTENSION PROGRAMS.  INPUT IS SOLICITED BY OSUES THROUGH A STATEWIDE ADVISORY NETWORK KNOWN AS EXTENSION COMMUNITY ADVISORY NETWORK (ECAN) THAT DIRECTLY ADVISES THE VICE PROVOST FOR EXTENSION AND ENGAGEMENT AND DIRECTOR OF EXTENSION. THIS ADVISORY COMMITTEE IS MADE UP OF INDIVIDUALS REPRESENTING EACH OF OSUES’S SEVEN PROGRAM AREAS (4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY HEALTH, FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES, OPEN CAMPUS, OUTDOOR SCHOOL, AND SEA GRANT) AS WELL AS TWO COUNTY COMMISSIONERS AND ADDITIONAL REPRESENTATIVES FROM OREGON COUNTIES AS DETERMINED BY THE OSUES DIRECTOR. PLANNED OUTCOMES DEVELOPED FROM THIS PROCESS ARE OUTLINED IN A BIENNIAL PLAN SUBMITTED BY EACH PARTICIPATING COLLEGE.  OAES PROJECTS ARE REVIEWED ANNUALLY ON THE BASIS OF PLANNED OUTCOMES OUTLINED IN A FIVE-YEAR, PEER REVIEWED PROPOSAL SUBMITTED TO OAES AND APPROVED BY NIFA. PROJECT OUTCOMES ARE ALSO ASSESSED AGAINST THE AES’S INTERNAL STRATEGIC INTENT DOCUMENT, A STRATEGIC DIRECTIVE FORMULATED WITH INPUT FROM INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS. OAES HAS IDENTIFIED FOUR CRITICAL ISSUES THAT WILL BE ADDRESSED UNDER THE POW: 1) MARINE CONSERVATION AND FOOD SYSTEMS, 2) AGRICULTURAL COMPETITIVENESS AND RESILIENCE, 3) MARKETS AND ACCESS IN FOOD AND HEALTH INNOVATIONS, AND 4) WORKING AND NATURAL LANDSCAPES. THESE FOUR "THEMES" WILL DRIVE THE RESEARCH AND OUTREACH EFFORTS OF THE COLLEGE OVER THE REPORTING PERIOD. THE STRATEGIC CHALLENGES IDENTIFIED BY NIFA, WHICH TARGETED SUSTAINABLE ENERGY, CLIMATE CHANGE, GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY/HUNGER, FOOD SAFETY, AND OBESITY ARE EVIDENT ACROSS THE PLAN. AN ADDITIONAL CRITICAL ISSUE– ANIMAL HEALTH – HAS BEEN ADDED TO ADDRESS CAPACITY FUNDING ASSOCIATED WITH ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH AS WELL AS OTHER COMPETITIVE GRANT FUNDING. THE CONNECTIVELY AND INTERACTIONS BETWEEN THE OAES AND OSUES AND THE OVERLAP IN THE STAKEHOLDER COMMUNITIES WE SERVE ULTIMATELY COMBINES TO RESULT IN ACCESS TO RESEARCH-BASED KNOWLEDGE AND EFFECTIVE PROGRAMMING THAT DELIVERS RESEARCH-BASED SOLUTIONS FOR CONTEMPORARY ISSUES TO ENABLE RESILIENCE IN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES AND IMPROVED LIVELIHOODS FOR THE PEOPLE OF OREGON

THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY (OSU) APPROVED PLAN OF WORK (POW) ENCOMPASSES A FIVE‐YEAR PERIOD BEGINNING ON OCTOBER 1, 2022 AND REPRESENTS A JOINT EFFORT BY THE TWO CRITICAL COMPONENTS OF OSU’S COLLEGE OF FOOD, AGRICULTURAL, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES (CFAES): THE OHIO AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (ALSO KNOWN AS OARDC) AND OSU EXTENSION. CFAES RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS ARE CONDUCTED IN NINE ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS ON OUR CAMPUSES IN COLUMBUS AND WOOSTER; ELEVEN RESEARCH STATIONS AND FIELD LABS; AND IN ALL 88 COUNTIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. FACULTY IN CFAES ENGAGE IN RESEARCH FROM VERY BASIC CELLULAR LEVEL RESPONSES TO APPLICATIONS OF DISEASE AND PEST MANAGEMENT AS WELL AS DEVELOPING NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND USES FOR AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS AND WASTE.  WHILE THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY IS THE LARGEST INDUSTRY IN THE BUCKEYE STATE, CFAES RESEARCH REACHES BEYOND AGRICULTURE AND COVERS ENVIRONMENTAL, WATER QUALITY AND SOCIETAL ISSUES THAT RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES FACE. CFAES RECENTLY UPDATED OUR STRATEGIC PLAN, INCLUDING THE GOALS LISTED BELOW TO GUIDE OUR WORK AND ACTIONS AT ALL LEVELS AND WITH INVOLVEMENT OF RESEARCH FACULTY IN ALL AREAS.  GOAL 1: STUDENT/LEARNER FIRST PHILOSOPHY ‐ CFAES TEACHING REACHES ACROSS THE LIFESPAN FROM YOUTH SERVED THROUGH 4‐H PROGRAMS TO STUDENTS PURSUING DEGREES ON CAMPUS TO 2 MILLION PLUS LIFELONG LEARNERS IN EXTENSION PROGRAMS. GOAL 2: INNOVATIVE SCHOLARSHIP TO SUSTAIN LIFE ‐ CFAES RESEARCH PROJECTS AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS ADDRESS OUR CRITICAL ISSUES WHICH COVER AREAS IN HEALTH AND WELLNESS, ECONOMIC VITALITY, FOOD SECURITY AND PRODUCTION, ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND SUSTAINABILITY AS WELL AS HELPING PEOPLE THRIVE ACROSS THE LIFESPAN. GOAL 3: CAPACITY BUILDING OF OUR PEOPLE AND OUR COMMUNITIES ‐ PEOPLE ARE OUR GREATEST ASSET AND CFAES STRIVES TO BUILD ON THE SUCCESS OF OUR PEOPLE. CHANGING WORKFORCE DYNAMICS, COVID‐19 PRESSURES, MARKET COMPETITION, ECONOMIC DRIVERS, AN INCREASING DESIRE FOR A MORE BALANCED APPROACH TO HOW LIFE AND WORK INTERFACE, AND A NEED FOR DIVERSIFYING OUR TALENT. GOAL 4: PARTNER OF CHOICE ‐ CFAES WANTS TO ENGAGE OUR ENTIRE COMMUNITY, INCLUDING BOTH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS. GOAL 5: RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP IN A ONE‐COLLEGE MODEL ‐ CFAES CONTINUES TO TRANSFORM AND IMPROVE OUR PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT ACROSS OUR THREE CAMPUSES. A NEW SCIENCE BUILDING PROVIDING MODERN RESEARCH SPACE WAS RECENTLY COMPLETED ON THE WOOSTER CAMPUS AND THE NEW CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT AGRICULTURE RESEARCH COMPLEX, WILL OPEN SOON AT WATERMAN FARM ON THE COLUMBUS CAMPUS.  THE JOINT POW WAS DEVELOPED AROUND THESE GOALS AS WELL AS FIVE CRITICAL ISSUES. 1) HEALTH AND WELLNESS – EXPLORING HEALTH RELATED ISSUES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO MENTAL HEALTH AWARENESS AND INITIATIVES, HEALTH INEQUITY, CHRONIC DISEASE AND OBESITY PREVENTION, COMMUNITY NUTRITION EDUCATION, AND FARM SAFETY. 2) ECONOMIC VITALITY – ISSUES RELATED TO ECONOMIC VITALITY INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO BUSINESS RETENTION AND EXPANSION, ENHANCING RURAL ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES, INCREASING BROADBAND ACCESS IN RURAL AREAS, THE EFFECTS OF TRADE POLICIES ON FOOD AND AG INDUSTRIES, AND THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT. 3) FOOD SECURITY AND PRODUCTION – WE WILL EXPLORE ISSUES RELATED TO MITIGATING FOOD INSECURITY THROUGH COMMUNITY SERVICE AND FOOD PRODUCTION EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND FOOD SYSTEM SUSTAINABILITY INCLUDING DIGITAL AGRICULTURE, CLIMATE SMART AGRICULTURE, IMPROVED FOOD ANIMAL HEALTH AND PRODUCTION, CROP IMPROVEMENT AND RESILIENCY, WEED AND PEST CONTROL, PLANT BREEDING AND DISEASE RESISTANCE, NUTRIENT DENSE FOODS, NEW FOOD PRESERVATIVES, AND ANTIMICROBIAL FOOD PACKAGING. 4) ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND SUSTAINABILITY. RESEARCH TOPICS COVER AREAS SUCH AS SOIL HEALTH AND REMEDIATION, BIOLOGICAL CONTROL AGENTS, REDUCTION OF PESTICIDE USE, SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF POLYMERS AND BIOPLASTICS, WATER QUALITY AND WASTEWATER TREATMENT, AQUATIC ECOSYSTEM HEALTH, AIR QUALITY AND SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF BIOPRODUCTS AND RENEWABLE FUELS. 5) THRIVING ACROSS THE LIFESPAN ‐ PROGRAMS UNDER THIS CRITICAL ISSUE ARE RELATED TO POSITIVE HUMAN DEVELOPMENT FOR ALL AGES. A MAJOR FOCUS IS YOUTH DEVELOPMENT THROUGH 4‐H AND FINANCIAL LITERACY PROGRAMS.

THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION HAS A SMALL ALLOCATION FROM THE AHDR PROGRAM TO FURTHER ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH ON THE ISLAND. ONLY ONE PROJECT, DESCRIBING THE RELATIONSHIP OF WATER QUALITY ON PUERTO RICO'S DAIRY FARMS TO ANIMAL HEALTH AND MILK QUALITY, IS SUPPORTED BY THESE FUNDS. DAIRY FARMERS, AGRONOMISTS, STUDENTS AND EXTENSION AGENTS ARE THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS EFFORT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE WATER SAMPLING FROM DAIRY FARMS IN THE STUDY, EVALUATING SAMPLES FOR FACTORS AFFECTING WATER QUALITY, AND DESCRIPTION OF THE INCIDENCE OF HEALTH PROBLEMS, MILK QUALITY AND MILK PRODUCTION AT DAIRY FARMS STUDIED. EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A DATABASE OF WATER QUALITY OF DAIRY FARMS SAMPLED DURING THREE SEASONS OF THE YEAR; REGULAR COUNSELING ON WATER MANAGEMENT TO DAIRY FARMERS; PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS AT ACADEMIC AND DAIRY FARMERS ASSOCIATIONS MEETINGS. THE PRINCIPAL OUTCOME EXPECTED FROM THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE DAIRY FARMERS’ AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPORTANCE OF WATER MANAGEMENT AND QUALITY IN THEIR OPERATIONS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT ANIMAL HEALTH ABSTRACT PENN STATE’S COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES’ OFFICE FOR RESEARCH AND GRADUATE EDUCATION WILL HOLD AN ANNUAL COMPETITION TO SEEK PROPOSALS THAT ARE COMPRISED OF BASIC AND APPLIED STUDIES ON INFECTIOUS AND NONINFECTIOUS AGENTS WHICH IMPAIR THE NORMAL STATE OF THE LIVING ANIMAL BODY AND/OR AFFECT THE PERFORMANCE OF VITAL FUNCTIONS. THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY IS OFFERED TO SUPPORT RESEARCH THAT: 1) PROMOTES THE GENERAL WELFARE THROUGH IMPROVED HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK, POULTRY, AQUATIC ANIMALS, AND OTHER INCOME-PRODUCING ANIMALS WHICH ARE ESSENTIAL TO THE NATION’S FOOD SUPPLY AND WELFARE OF PRODUCERS AND CONSUMERS OF ANIMAL PRODUCTS; 2) IMPROVES THE HEALTH OF HORSES; 3) FACILITATES THE EFFECTIVE TREATMENT AND PREVENTION (WHERE POSSIBLE) OF DISEASES IN BOTH DOMESTICATED AND WILD SPECIES WHICH, IF NOT CONTROLLED, WOULD BE DISASTROUS TO THE UNITED STATES ANIMAL INDUSTRIES AND ENDANGER THE NATION’S FOOD SUPPLY; 4) FACILITATES THE PREVENTION OF DISEASE IN HONEY BEES TO PROTECT THE PRODUCTION OF AN IMPORTANT AGRICULTURAL PRODUCT; 5) MINIMIZES LIVESTOCK AND POULTRY LOSSES DUE TO TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING; 6) PROTECTS HUMAN HEALTH THROUGH CONTROL OF ANIMAL DI SEASES TRANSMISSIBLE TO HUMANS; 7) IMPROVES METHODS OF CONTROLLING THE BIRTH OF PREDATORS AND OTHER ANIMALS; AND 8) PROMOTES THE GENERAL WELFARE THROUGH EXPANDED PROGRAMS OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION TO IMPROVE ANIMAL HEALTH. INTERNAL REVIEWS OF PROPOSALS ENSURE THAT THE PROJECTS RECOMMENDED FOR FUNDING ARE OF SUFFICIENT QUALITY TO MERIT FUNDING AND THE PROPOSED PROJECTS MEET THE CRITERIA AS DEFINED BY USDA’S ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM. FINAL DECISIONS FOR FUNDING WILL BE MADE BY THE ASSOCIATE DEAN FOR RESEARCH AND ARE CONTINGENT ON A USDA APPROVED ANIMAL HEALTH AES PROJECT.

ABSTRACT  BACKGROUND: ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH CAPACITY PROGRAM (AHDR) FUNDS RECEIVED FROM USDA NIFA ARE PROVIDED TO THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE (CVM) FOR THE STUDY OF DISEASES OF FOOD ANIMALS (INCLUDING EQUINE). THE CVM ALLOCATES AHDR FUNDS TO ONE OR TWO SPECIFIC PROJECTS PER YEAR UTILIZING AN INTERNAL AWARDING PROCESS DESCRIBED AS FOLLOWS: PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF AHDR IS TO INCREASE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AT ACCREDITED PUBLIC OR PRIVATE VETERINARY SCHOOLS OR COLLEGES, OR STATE AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATIONS CONDUCTING ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH. CVM UTILIZES THE AWARD IS TO PROVIDE SEED MONEY TO CVM FACULTY FOR STUDIES LEADING TO GREATER USDA/NIFA SPONSORED RESEARCH PROJECTS. THEREFORE, PRIORITY IS GIVEN TO PROPOSALS THAT OFFER THE MOST PROMISE OF DEVELOPING INTO SUBSEQUENT RESEARCH PROJECTS. APPLICATION PROCEDURES: TIMELINE IS MAY 1, 2023 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30, 2023. FACULTY WITHIN OSU CVM ARE ELIGIBLE. THE PROPOSAL MUST USE THE PROVIDED GRANT TEMPLATE. AN ELECTRONIC VERSION SHOULD BE SENT (BY THE NOTED DEADLINE DATE) TO CVM OFFICE OF RESEARCH <(>&<)> GRADUATE STUDIES. THERE IS A LIMIT OF ONE PROPOSAL SUBMISSION PER PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR FOR THIS COMPETITION. INTRAMURAL FUNDED PROJECT WILL BE SET UP THROUGH THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROGRAMS AND THE NIFA NRS REPORTING SYSTEM. CURRENTLY FUNDED PROJECT (5/1/2022 – 9/30/2023): INVESTIGATING SPACE-TIME PATTERNS OF POULTRY PATHOGENS IN THE U.S. BY DR. ANDREIA ARRUDA RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS CAUSED BY ORNITHOBACTERIUM RHINOTRACHEALIS (ORT) AND PASTEURELLA MULTOCIDA (PM) BACTERIA ARE SIGNIFICANT THREATS TO THE POULTRY INDUSTRY BY CAUSING ECONOMIC LOSSES AND WELFARE ISSUES. DUE TO CHARACTERIZATION DIFFICULTIES AND UNDERUTILIZATION OF EPIDEMIOLOGICAL TOOLS, LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE SPATIO-TEMPORAL SPREAD OF BACTERIAL SUBTYPES FOR THESE DISEASES IN THE FIELD. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS RETROSPECTIVE OBSERVATIONAL CROSS-SECTIONAL STUDY ARE TO A) DESCRIBE MOLECULAR CHARACTERIZATION AND SPACE-TIME PATTERNS FOR ORT AND PM USING ISOLATES COLLECTED FROM OUTBREAKS ON POULTRY FARMS; B) INVESTIGATE THE EXISTENCE OF SPATIAL CLUSTERS (HOTSPOTS) FOR ORT AND PM; AND C) INVESTIGATE THE ASSOCIATION BETWEEN GENETIC SIMILARITY AND SPATIAL PROXIMITY FOR BOTH ORT AND PM. ANALYSIS WILL BE DONE SEPARATELY FOR EACH BACTERIA. WE USED A UNIQUELY DEVELOPED CORE-GENOME MULTI-LOCUS SEQUENCING TYPING (CGMLST) SCHEME FOR ORT AND PM CHARACTERIZATION AND SUCCESSFULLY SEQUENCED AND CHARACTERIZED 103 ORT AND 81 PM ISOLATES COLLECTED FROM POULTRY FARMS DURING CONFIRMED DISEASE OUTBREAKS BETWEEN 2013-2021. TO CONTINUE THIS WORK AND ACCOMPLISH THE PROPOSED OBJECTIVES, CLUSTER ANALYSIS (SATSCAN) AND SPATIO-TEMPORAL VISUALIZATION AND ANALYSES (QGIS) WILL BE CONDUCTED. WHEN COMPLETED, THIS STUDY WILL BE ONE OF THE FIRST TO COMBINE ORT AND PM ISOLATE CHARACTERIZATION WITH SPATIAL-TEMPORAL ANALYSIS IN POULTRY IN THE U.S. AND DESCRIBE WHETHER LOCAL SPREAD IS IMPORTANT FOR THOSE BACTERIAL PATHOGENS. DATA FROM THIS STUDY WILL INCREASE THE UNDERSTANDING OF ORT AND PM PATHOGEN DIVERSITY AND LOCAL PATHOGEN PLASTICITY IN CONFIRMED OUTBREAKS. THIS ADDED INFORMATION WILL DEMONSTRATE THE USE OF EPIDEMIOLOGICAL TOOLS IN COMBINATION WITH DATA ALREADY COLLECTED BY PRODUCERS BUT RARELY SHARED. A SUCCESSFUL STUDY MAY ALSO HELP RECRUIT ADDITIONAL POULTRY PRODUCERS AND COMPANIES IN DEVELOPING AN ONLINE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR ORT AND PM OUTBREAKS BY SHARING AND UTILIZING ROUTINELY COLLECTED HEALTH DATA. FINALLY, INCREASED KNOWLEDGE REGARDING ORT AND PM MAY LEAD TO IMPROVED BIOSECURITY PROTOCOLS AND VACCINATION SCHEMES. CURRENTLY, HIGHLY PATHOGENIC AVIAN INFLUENZA OUTBREAKS ARE HAPPENING ACROSS THE U.S. THIS IS A CONCERNING DEVELOPMENT FOR THE POULTRY INDUSTRY AND PUBLIC HEALTH. THE ABILITY TO MITIGATE THE EFFECTS AND PREVENT FUTURE EPIDEMICS IS PARAMOUNT BUT REQUIRES INCREASED DATA SHARING AND SOPHISTICATED ANALYSES TO GAIN KNOWLEDGE OF HOW DISEASES ARE TRANSMITTED. THE ABILITY FOR PRODUCERS TO SHARE DISEASE STATUS AND VISUALIZE DISEASE TRANSMISSION IN REAL-TIME ON A JOINT POULTRY INDUSTRY PLATFORM IS CURRENTLY LACKING. THE GOAL OF OUR PROJECT IS TO UTILIZE 8 YEARS' WORTH OF RETROSPECTIVE ORNITHOBACTERIUM RHINOTRACHEALIS AND PASTEURELLA MULTOCIDA BACTERIA OUTBREAK DATA TO MODEL THEIR GENOMIC AND SPATIAL PATTERNS OVER TIME IN THE FIELD. FINDINGS FROM THIS STUDY WILL FUNCTION AS A FRAMEWORK TO STUDY OTHER PATHOGENS SUCH AS AVIAN INFLUENZA AND TO PROVIDE PRODUCERS AND VETERINARIANS INFORMATION ON THE USEFULNESS OF EPIDEMIOLOGICAL TOOLS. RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL ENCOURAGE DATA SHARING WITHIN THE POULTRY INDUSTRY

ABSTRACT AGRICULTURE IS THE PRIMARY INDUSTRY IN SOUTH CAROLINA, WITH 25,000 FARMS ACROSS 4.7 MILLION ACRES THAT CONTRIBUTE OVER $46 BILLION TO THE STATE'S ANNUAL ECONOMY AND PROVIDES OVER 247,000 JOBS. FORESTRY IS ALSO AN IMPORTANT ECONOMIC DRIVER IN SC, CONTRIBUTING OVER $21.2 BILLION ANNUALLY. WITH DIVERSE NATURAL RESOURCES ACROSS THE STATE, TOURISM IS AN ADDITIONAL ECONOMIC FORCE, ACCOUNTING FOR EXPENDITURES OF $24.4 BILLION IN 2019. SUPPORTING AND IMPROVING THE LIVELIHOOD AND QUALITY OF LIFE FOR SC RESIDENTS ARE WHAT DRIVE THE PROGRAMMING AND RESEARCH FOCUS FOR CLEMSON UNIVERSITY. THE PLAN OF WORK REFLECTS RESEARCH ACTIVITIES TO BENEFIT AGRIBUSINESS, COMMUNITIES, AND CITIZENS OF SC. THE RESEARCH IS CONDUCTED ON THE MAIN CAMPUS OF CLEMSON UNIVERSITY AND IN EACH OF THE SIX RESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTERS (RECS) LOCATED ACROSS THE STATE. FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE ADVANCING THE COMPETITIVENESS OF THE AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, SAFEGUARDING THE FOOD SUPPLY, PRESERVING NATURAL RESOURCES, AND PREPARING YOUNGER GENERATIONS TO BECOME PRODUCTIVE CITIZENS. RESEARCH TO IMPROVE THE PRODUCTIVITY AND PROFITABILITY OF AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS INCLUDES OUR ADVANCED PLANT TECHNOLOGY (APT) PROGRAM AND OUR PRECISION AGRICULTURE PROGRAM. THE APT PROGRAM USES TRADITIONAL PLANT BREEDING AND MOLECULAR GENETICS TO DEVELOP NEW CROPS AND CROP-BASED PRODUCTS. THE PRECISION AGRICULTURE PROGRAM DEVELOPS DEVICES AND METHODOLOGIES FOR SITE-SPECIFIC AND MORE EFFICIENT USE OF INPUTS (E.G., WATER, FERTILIZER, PESTICIDES). OTHER RESEARCH EFFORTS STUDY LIVESTOCK FORAGE PRODUCTION TO ENHANCE FARM PROFITS AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY. RESEARCH ACTIVITIES SPECIFIC TO THE MAJOR AGRONOMIC AND SPECIALTY CROPS FOCUS ON REDUCTION OF COSTS TO MANAGE WEEDS, DISEASES AND INSECT PESTS. LIKEWISE, INVESTIGATORS ARE DEVELOPING IMPROVEMENTS TO IRRIGATION WATER MANAGEMENT USING REAL-TIME SOIL AND WEATHER INPUTS. RESEARCH PROGRAMS TO SUSTAIN CONSERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES INCLUDE: 1) REMOTE CLIMATIC DATA COLLECTION AND DATA MANAGEMENT ON FORESTS, 2) TECHNIQUES TO ENHANCE FOREST GROWTH AND QUALITY (SILVICULTURE, HARVESTING OPERATIONS, FOREST MANAGEMENT, AND FOREST HEALTH), 3) HYDROLOGIC AND FOREST PRODUCTIVITY PROCESSES ALONG HYDROPERIODS AND SALINITY GRADIENTS. RESEARCH IN FOOD SAFETY, SECURITY AND NUTRITION FOCUSES ON 1) EFFECTIVENESS OF RENDERING AND POST-PROCESS STORAGE CONDITIONS TO PREV ENT THE GROWTH OF ANIMAL DISEASE PATHOGENS, 2) DEVELOPMENT OF RAPID DETECTION METHODS FOR FOOD CONTAMINANTS, 3) IMPROVEMENTS IN PACKAGING TO ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD QUALITY AND REDUCING FOOD WASTE.

PROJECT ABSTRACT OUR PORTFOLIOS OF SOLUTIONDRIVEN, CUTTINGEDGE RESEARCH IS CREATING NEW KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY WHICH IS THEN EXTENDED TO ALL NORTH CAROLINIANS THROUGH NC COOPERATIVE EXTENSION. WE ARE TRANSFORMING SCIENCE INTO EVERYDAY SOLUTIONS THAT IMPROVE LIVES AND ALLOW NORTH CAROLINIANS TO LEAD PROSPEROUS, HEALTHY LIVES. A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF EXTENSION AGENTS SERVES AS THE CONDUIT THROUGH WHICH THE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY ARE COMMUNICATED TO UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS WHO THEN CONDUCT RESEARCH AND FORMULATE SOLUTIONS. EXTENSION AGENTS THEN DELIVER ESSENTIAL INFORMATION INTO THE HANDS OF GROWERS, INDUSTRY, AND MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS AT NC STATE FOCUS ON ADDRESSING FOUR IDENTIFIED STATEWIDE CRITICAL ISSUES: IMPROVING PLANT AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS; PROTECTING ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES, ENRICHING YOUTH, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY WELLBEING; AND ENHANCING FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH. THROUGH INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS, NC STATE IS SOLVING CHALLENGES RELATED TO THE PRODUCTIVITY AND PROFITABILITY OF BOTH LARGE AND SMALL SCALE FARMS. RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION EDUCATORS ARE ALSO DEVELOPING AND DISSEMINATING KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY TO IMPROVE LANDSCAPING AND GARDENING. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS IN ANIMAL SYSTEMS ARE FOCUSED ON DEVELOPING AND DISSEMINATING KNOWLEDGE AND METHODS FOR ANIMAL BREEDING, REPRODUCTION, NUTRITION, GENETICS AND GENOMICS, PHYSIOLOGY, ENVIRONMENTAL STRESS, PRODUCT QUALITY, AND HEALTH AND WELLBEING. THESE INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS ALSO AIM TO TACKLE THE CRITICAL ISSUES IMPACTING THE QUALITY OF OUR SOIL, WATER AND AIR BY PROVIDING SCIENTIFIC SOLUTIONS FOR ANIMAL WASTE MANAGEMENT, WASTEWATER TREATMENT, NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT, SEPTIC SYSTEMS, WETLAND MANAGEMENT, SOIL PROPERTIES, AND FISHERY AND POND MANAGEMENT. NC STATE EXTENSION CONTINUES TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES TO ENRICH YOUTH, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY WELL BEING THROUGH THE 4H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. 4H PROGRAMS INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH TO DEVELOP LIFE SKILLS, GROW CONFIDENCE, INDEPENDENCE, RESILIENCE, AND STEM SKILLS THROUGH FUN HANDS ON LEARNING IN SAFE, HEALTHY, AND ENRICHING ENVIRONMENTS. EXTENSION PROGRAMS ALSO ADDRESS CRITICAL CHALLENGES AFFECTING CONSUMER AND FAMILY WELLBEING. IN ADDITION TO YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, OTHER FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE PARENTING, CHILDCARE, FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, AGING, HEALTHY HOMES, AND DISASTER READINESS, RESPONSE, AND RECOVERY. AT THE COMMUNITY LEVEL, EXTENSION WORKS WITH INDIVIDUALS, COMMUNITY GROUPS AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS ON LEADERSHIP SKILLS, WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT, ENTREPRENEURSHIP, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, VOLUNTEERISM, COMMUNITY PLANNING, AND DISASTER PREPAREDNESS NC STATES RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS TO ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH AND TO KEEP AMERICANS HEALTHY AND FREE FROM FOODBORNE ILLNESS NECESSITATE A FOCUS ON PREVENTING FOOD SAFETY PROBLEMS RATHER THAN TAKING A REACTIONARY APPROACH. NC STATES INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS FOCUS ON PROTECTING THE SAFETY OF FOODS ALONG THE ENTIRE SUPPLY CHAIN, FROM PRODUCTION TO CONSUMPTION. TO MEET THE GROWING NEED FOR HEALTHY FOOD, RESEARCHERS ARE DEVELOPING AND PRODUCING NEW FOOD PRODUCTS THAT PROMOTE HEALTH AND PREVENT DISEASE. AT THE SAME TIME, EXTENSION PROVIDES NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMMING TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE THEY NEED TO MAKE INFORMED CHOICES ABOUT FOOD AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLES. IMPROVING PLANT AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS: WITHIN THIS AREA, WE WILL WORK TO ADDRESS CROSSCUTTING AND EMERGING ISSUES OF ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH AND PRODUCTION. IN ANIMAL SYSTEM, RESEARCHERS WILL STUDY THE EFFICIENCY OF DIFFERENT FEEDING SOURCES TO IMPROVE ANIMAL PRODUCTIVITY AND GUT HEALTH. IN PLANT SYSTEMS, THE FOCUS WILL BE IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE, ALTERNATIVE AND HIGH VALUE CROP PRODUCTION, SEASON EXTENSION, CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION, VALUE ADDED AGRICULTURE, DIGITAL AGRICULTURE, SOIL HEALTH, PEST CONTROL, AND AGRO ECONOMICS. EXTENSION WILL CONTINUE TO EXPAND ITS WORK WITH LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS, PLACING SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON LIMITED RESOURCES, SMALL SCALE MINORITY FARMERS. THE FARM PAVILION WILL FOCUS ON SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND LOCAL AND COMMUNITY FOOD SYSTEMS, HOUSING ITS APPLIED RESEARCH AND DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS STAFF AND PROVIDING SPACE FOR MEETINGS, FORUMS AND CONFERENCES. ENHANCING FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH: WITHIN THIS AREA BOTH RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WILL WORK TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF HUMAN HEALTH, FOOD SAFETY AND HEALTHY LIVING HABITS. THE RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON WHOLE GRAIN CEREALS, HUMAN HEALTH AND HUMAN NUTRITION, PROBIOTICS STRAINS, FOOD ALLERGY, FOOD PRODUCTION PROCESS, BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS OF FOOD, POSTHARVEST TECHNOLOGY AND FOOD SECURITY. COOPERATIVE EXTENSION AND RESEARCHERS AT NCA<(>&<)>T WILL WORK TOGETHER IN A CONCERTED EFFORT TO INCREASE INFORMATION AND RESOURCES FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN FAMILIES AND CHILDREN IN RURAL COMMUNITIES WHO ARE OFTEN POOR AND DISPROPORFINANCIALLY VULNERABLE ARE WELL EQUIPPED TO MAKE SOUND FINANCIAL DECISIONS FOR THEMSELVES AND THEIR FAMILIES. 4-H PROGRAMMING WILL FOCUS ON AREAS SUCH AS STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH), LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT, AND AGRISCIENCE. INNOVATION STATION, THE CUTTING-EDGE MOBILE LEARNING EXPERIENCE, WILL CONTINUE TRAVELING TO COUNTIES THROUGHOUT NORTH CAROLINA, PROVIDING INTRODUCTORY AND ADVANCED STEM CURRICULA FOR CHILDREN IN GRADES K-12. ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES: IN THIS AREA WE WILL WORK TO PROTECT THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT, PROVIDE THE SOLUTION FOR WASTE MANAGEMENT AND CONVENTIONAL ENERGY. CAES RESEARCHERS WILL INVESTIGATE AN ADVANCED BIOLOGICAL SYSTEM TO PRODUCE ALTERNATIVE ENERGY, TREAT THE AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL WASTE, AND PROTECT AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY. CAES RESEARCHERS WILL BE INVOLVED IN MULTISTATE CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECT TO STUDY THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND COMMUNITY OF COLOR. RESEARCHERS WILL BE DEVELOPING THE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION SOLUTION TO IMPROVE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES AND WILL BE PROPOSING POLICIES TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND CLIMATE CHANGE. EXTENSION WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT SMALL SCALE PRODUCERS AND LANDOWNERS IN THEIR EFFORT TO DEVELOP WOODLOT MANAGEMENT PLANS WHILE ALSO INTEGRATING TECHNIQUES AND PRACTICES SUCH AS SILVOPASTURE PRODUCTION AND RIPARIAN BUFFERS

ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE ABSTRACT  ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH AT NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY IN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL, CONSUMER, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES (ACES) IS EXPLORING IMMUNE SUPPORTIVE NUTRIENTS THAT CAN SUPPORT THE BEEF CATTLE INDUSTRY BY INCREASING FEEDLOT CALF HEALTH AND PERFORMANCE AFTER WEANING, MARKETING, AND TRANSPORTATION. IN THE BEEF CATTLE INDUSTRY, SICKNESS DUE TO DISEASES (SUCH AS BOVINE RESPIRATORY DISEASE) COSTS THE UNITED STATES BEEF INDUSTRY MORE THAN $900 MILLION PER YEAR IN LOST REVENUE. DISEASE OCCURRENCE IS MOSTLY DURING HANDLING AND TRANSPORTATION OF WEANED CALVES TO A FEEDLOT, BECAUSE DURING TRANSPORTATION THE ANIMALS ARE STRESSED AT A TIME WHEN EXPOSURE TO INFECTIOUS DISEASES IS VERY HIGH (DUE TO CO-MINGLING AND CONTACT WITH OTHER SICK ANIMALS). SICK CATTLE ARE COMMONLY TREATED WITH ANTIBIOTICS AND ANTI-INFLAMMATORY DRUGS TO REDUCE FEVER, BUT CONSUMER PRESSURE TO MINIMIZE THE USE OF ANTIBIOTIC AND OTHER DRUGS IN THE CATTLE FEEDING INDUSTRY DEMANDS THE EXPLORATION OF ALTERNATIVE STRATEGIES TO IMPROVE ANIMAL HEALTH. IT IS WELL D OCUMENTED THAT AN ACTIVATED IMMUNE SYSTEM HAS AN INCREASED NUTRIENT DEMAND, AND THAT SUPPLEMENTATION OF SPECIFIC IMMUNE SUPPORTIVE NUTRIENTS IMPROVES FEEDLOT RECEIVING CATTLE HEALTH AND PERFORMANCE. HOWEVER, THE INCREASED DEMAND FOR NUTRIENTS TO SUPPORT AN ACTIVE IMMUNE SYSTEM TYPICALLY OCCURS WHEN CATTLE ARE UNDER STRESS. IN ADDITION TO A SUPPRESSED IMMUNE SYSTEM, STRESSED ANIMALS TYPICALLY HAVE LOW DIETARY NUTRIENT INTAKES. ADDITIONALLY, ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE FUNDS AT NMSU SUPPORT RESEARCH THAT INVESTIGATES HOW BACTERIAL INFECTIONS ARE LINKED TO INFERTILITY IN FEMALES. SPECIFIC TYPES OF INFECTIONS, INCLUDING THOSE OF THE UTERUS, CAN DISRUPT NORMAL OVARIAN FOLLICULAR DEVELOPMENT, AND REDUCE INTRAFOLLICULAR ESTRADIOL CONCENTRATIONS AS WELL AS SYSTEMIC ESTRADIOL CONCENTRATIONS. THIS RESEARCH CAN POSITIVELY IMPACT THE OVERALL FERTILITY OF CATTLE AND POSSIBLY COULD BE APPLIED TO OTHER SPECIES.

ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED WILL INCLUDE RESEARCH EFFORTS WILL SEEK TO 1) ENHANCE THE HEALTH AND WELL BEING OF LIVESTOCK AND WILDLIFE; 2) PREVENT AND MITIGATE DISEASE DEVELOPMENT IN LIVESTOCK AND WILDLIFE. EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS THAT WILL ENHANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF ANIMAL WELL-BEING, STRESS AND DISEASES THAT ULTIMATELY LEAD TO SOLUTIONS AND PRODUCTS THAT ARE ABLE TO EFFECTIVELY AND ECONOMICALLY ENHANCE HEALTH AND MITIGATE ANIMAL DISEASES. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES WILL BE THE CITIZENS OF THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA PRIMARILY AS WELL AS THOSE CITIZENS IN OUR NEIGHBORING STATES WHERE OUR RESULTING CHANGES IN PRACTICES MIGHT BE RELEVANT.

TITLE OF PROJECT 1: MICRORNAS PRESENT IN BOVINE MILK AND THEIR ABILITY TO SHAPE THE NEONATAL IMMUNITY TO RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS ABSTRACT: NEWBORN CALVES LACK OF CIRCULATING ANTIBODIES. IN THE FIRST WEEKS OF LIFE, THE BOVINE NEONATE’S ABILITY TO FIGHT OFF PATHOGENS IS THEREFORE FULLY DEPENDENT UPON INGESTING COLOSTRUM (THE FIRST MILK PRODUCED BY FEMALE MAMMALS). THIS TRANSFER OF PASSIVE IMMUNITY IS CRUCIAL FOR THE NEWBORNS’ SURVIVAL DURING THE FIRST WEEKS OF LIFE, WHICH ARE THE MOST CHALLENGING PERIOD TO ENTERIC INFECTIONS. IN THIS SCENARIO, BOVINE RESPIRATORY DISEASE COMPLEX (A COMBINATION OF STRESS, VIRAL, AND BACTERIAL INFECTIONS) IS A MAJOR CAUSE OF MORTALITY IN NEONATAL CALVES. IN ADDITION TO ANTIBODIES AND NUTRITIONAL FACTORS (I.E., FAT, PROTEIN, MINERALS), COLOSTRUM CONTAINS A VARIETY OF BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS INCLUDING GROWTH FACTORS, CYTOKINES, MILK MICROBIOTA, AND RECENTLY MICRORNAS (MIRNAS) HAVE BEEN ADDED TO THE COLOSTRUM COMPOSITION LIST. MICRORNAS ARE SMALL NON‐CODING RNA MOLECULES, WHICH HAVE BEEN IMPLICATED IN REGULATING MRNA EXPRESSION AND PROTEIN TRANSCRIPTION. ADDITIONALLY, THEY HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO BE INVOLVED IN VARIOUS DISEASE STATES AND MAY HAVE A ROLE IN IMMUNE SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT AND FUNCTION. FOR INSTANCE, MICRORNAS HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO REGULATE BAND T‐CELL DIFFERENTIATION AND AFFECT CYTOKINES PRODUCTION BY MACROPHAGES. IN HUMANS, MICRORNAS IN BREASTMILK VARY DUE TO ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS, SUCH AS PRETERM BIRTH AND MATERNAL DIET, AND HAVE ALSO BEEN SHOWN TO ORIGINATE FROM THE MAMMARY GLAND AND NOT THE MOTHERS’ SYSTEMIC CIRCULATION. THUS, IT’S PLAUSIBLE TO EXPECT SIMILAR RESPONSES IN OTHER SPECIES WHERE MICRORNAS CAN SERVE AS SIGNALING MOLECULES PASSED FROM THE MOTHER TO THE NEWBORN TO ENHANCE THE RESPONSE TO NEONATAL INFECTIONS. THUS, THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IDENTIFY KEY MICRORNAS DERIVED FROM BOVINE COLOSTRUM THAT CAN REGULATE THE INFLAMMATORY RESPONSE TO NEONATAL INFECTIONS. RATIONALE: BOVINE MICRORNAS HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO BE ABSORBED AND TRANSPORTED INTO SYSTEMIC CIRCULATION IN MICE. HOWEVER, THE ROLE OF SUCH MICRORNAS DERIVED FROM COLOSTRUM AND THEIR ROLE IN PROTECTING NEWBORN CALVES FROM RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS REMAIN TO BE DETERMINED. METHODOLOGY: FOR MICRORNA ISOLATION, ISOLATE MICRORNAS FROM BOVINE MILK (COLOSTRUM, TRANSITION MILK, AND MATURE MILK) AND THROUGH REAL TIME QPCR IDENTIFY THE MOST EXPRESSED MICRORNAS IN BOVINE MILK. IN VITRO STUDY: BOVINE PRIMARY LUNG CELLS (PURCHASED FROM ACCEGEN™) WILL BE CHALLENGED WITH ESCHERICHIA COLI LIPOPOLYSACCHARIDE (LPS) AND INCUBATED WITH A POOL OF MICRORNAS EXTRACTED FROM THE DIFFERENT MILK SAMPLES FOR 24 HOURS. ENDPOINT ASSAYS INCLUDING CYTOKINES MEASUREMENT AND FLOW CYTOMETRY ANALYSIS WILL BE PERFORMED TO EVALUATE THE IMMUNE RESPONSE TO THE INDUCED‐INFECTION IN THE CONTROL VS MICRORNA‐TREATED CELLS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FOR COMPOSITION OF MICRORNAS IN BOVINE MILK, WE WILL DETERMINE THE COMPOSITION OF MICRORNAS FROM COLOSTRUM VS. MATURE MILK. WITH THE MICRORNAS COMPOSITION FROM DIFFERENT STAGES OF LACTATION, WE CAN IDENTIFY THE COMMON MICRORNA PROFILE IN BOVINE MILK AND THE POTENTIAL MICRORNAS MARKERS THAT MIGHT IMPACT THE IMMUNE RESPONSE. IMPACT OF MICRORNAS ON IMMUNE SYSTEM: IMMUNE CELL REPERTOIRE, INCLUDING T CELLS, B CELLS, AND NEUTROPHILS WILL BE ENUMERATED USING FLOW CYTOMETRY ANALYSIS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT DR. ROBERTS S. WEISS, ASSOCIATE DEAN OF RESEARCH <(>&<)> GRADUATE EDUCATION CORNELL UNIVERSITY, COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE TITLE: 2023 ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM THE CORNELL UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE WILL USE FUNDS RECEIVED FROM THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM FOR RESEARCH-RELATED EXPENSES FOR CONDUCTING ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH, PUBLISHING AND DISSEMINATING THE RESULTS OF SUCH RESEARCH, WITH THE GOAL OF INCREASING ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES

PROJECT ABSTRACT IN AN EFFORT TO BE RELEVANT AND ACCOUNTABLE, THE NEVADA AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (NAES) HAS CONTINUOUSLY AND SYSTEMATICALLY REVIEWED AND FOCUSED ON PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS NEVADAS HIGHESTPRIORITY NEEDS RELEVANT TO ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE. NAES FULLY SUBSCRIBES TO AND SUPPORTS THE UNIVERSITYS GOAL TO ACHIEVE RECOGNITION AS A FULLY ENGAGED INSTITUTION AND IS COMMITTED TO THE PRINCIPLES OF ACCESSIBILITY AND PROGRAM UTILITY THAT HAVE GUIDED THE LAND GRANT UNIVERSITY SYSTEM FOR MORE THAN 150 YEARS. OUR PLAN OF WORK RELEVANT TO ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE FOCUSES ON ADDRESSING SEVERAL CRITICAL ISSUES IN THE STATE. NEVADAS NUMBER ONE AGRICULTURAL COMMODITY IS ITS LIVESTOCK INDUSTRY AND IN PARTICULAR, BEEF CATTLE. IMPROVING THE GENERAL HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND OTHER INCOMEPRODUCING ANIMALS ESSENTIAL TO THE NATIONS FOOD SUPPLY AND THE WELFARE OF PRODUCERS AND CONSUMERS OF THESE ANIMAL PRODUCTS IS AN IMPORTANT ISSUE FOR NEVADA. COMPETING INTERESTS PRESENT CHALLENGES TO THE GENERAL HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND WILDLIFE ON NEVADAS RANGELANDS AND FORESTS/WOODLANDS. DROUGHT, EXCESSIVE TEMPERATURES AND WILDFIRES IN NEVADA AND THE GREAT BASIN HAVE GREATLY REDUCED AVAILABLE FORAGE AND WATER IN THESE AREAS. WILD HORSE POPULATIONS AT 2 TO 3 TIMES APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT LEVELS HAVE ALSO GREATLY IMPACTED AVAILABLE RESOURCES. THESE RESOURCE LIMITATIONS GREATLY IMPACT THE WELFARE OF DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS AND THEIR ABILITY TO RAISE LIVESTOCK. STUDIES WILL BE CONDUCTED TO LOOK AT THE VARIOUS ISSUES AND TO DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO SUPPORT A HEALTHY BALANCE BETWEEN DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK, WILDLIFE AND WILD HORSE POPULATIONS. STUDIES WILL ALSO BE CONDUCTED TO DEVELOP BREEDS BETTER SUITED TO THE HARSH ENVIRONMENTS OF THE WEST WHICH WILL IMPROVE THE GENERAL HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF THESE DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK. TRANSMISSION OF DISEASE BETWEEN DOMESTIC AND WILD SHEEP IS A CONCERN IN NEVADA AND THE GREAT BASIN. THE CONCERN OF TRANSMISSION OF VARIOUS DISEASES TO WILD SHEEP FROM DOMESTIC SHEEP HAVE GREATLY REDUCED LAND AVAILABLE FOR DOMESTIC SHEEP GRAZING. STUDIES WILL BE CONDUCTED TO DEVELOP NEWER BREEDS AND BETTER MANAGE BREEDS OF DOMESTIC SHEEP IN ORDER TO MINIMIZE THE TRANSMISSION OF DISEASES FROM DOMESTIC SHEEP TO WILD SHEEP. THIS WILL NOT ONLY HELP PROTECT THE WILD SHEEP POPULATION BUT WILL POTENTIALLY OPEN UP MORE LAND FOR DOMESTIC SHEEP GRAZING AND IMPROVE THE WELFARE OF THE DOMESTIC SHEEP PRODUCERS.

ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM ABSTRACT  FEDERAL AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THE AHDR PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AT ACCREDITED PUBLIC OR PRIVATE VETERINARY SCHOOLS OR COLLEGES, OR STATE AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATIONS CONDUCTING ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH. THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM IS ALIGNED WITH TWO SPECIFIC STRATEGIC GOALS FROM THE USDA STRATEGIC PLAN FOR FY 2022‐2026. THESE USDA STRATEGIC GOALS ARE AS FOLLOWS: ENSURE AMERICA’S AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM IS EQUITABLE, RESILIENT AND PROSPEROUS; PROVIDE ALL AMERICANS SAFE, NUTRITIOUS FOOD. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: IN THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA‐LINCOLN (UNL) INSTITUTE OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES (IANR), WE ARE ALL ABOUT PEOPLE AND THE FOOD, WATER AND NATURAL RESOURCES THAT SUSTAIN THEM. IANR INNOVATION IN RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND EXTENSION EDUCATION PLACES NEBRASKA ON THE LEADING EDGE OF FOOD PRODUCTION, ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, HUMAN NUTRITION, BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT, AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT. COMPOSED OF THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES AND NATURAL RESOURCES (CASNR), THE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH DIVISION (ARD), NEBRASKA EXTENSION, AND THE ARD AND EXTENSION COMPONENTS OF THREE DEPARTMENTS IN THE COLLEGE OF EDUCATION AND HUMAN SCIENCES; IANR IS COMMITTED TO GROWING THE FUTURE OF NEBRASKA'S PEOPLE, BUSINESSES, AND COMMUNITIES. STRATEGIC PLANNING IS INTEGRAL TO IANR'S FUNCTION AS A LAND‐GRANT INSTITUTION, AND IT PRIDES ITSELF ON WORKING AS AN INTEGRATED SYSTEM AND COLLABORATIVE ENVIRONMENT ACROSS THE THREE MISSION AREAS. IANR STRIVES TO COMBINE RESEARCH, TEACHING AND EXTENSION IN A MULTIDISCIPLINARY, COLLABORATIVE ENVIRONMENT THAT ENCOURAGES THE BEST THINKING AND EXPERTISE FROM ACROSS THE UNIVERSITY AND PRIVATE ENTERPRISE TO ENSURE NEBRASKA’S COMPETITIVENESS IN A WORLD OF CHANGE AND CHALLENGE. SPECIFIC TO ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE, IANR RESEARCH ADDRESSES HEALTH AND DISEASE PROBLEMS THAT EXIST PRESLAUGHTER OR PRE‐COLLECTION OF ANIMAL PRODUCTS (PRE‐HARVEST). ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH COMPRISES BASIC AND APPLIED STUDIES ON INFECTIOUS AND NONINFECTIOUS AGENTS WHICH IMPAIR THE NORMAL STATE OF THE LIVING ANIMAL BODY AND/OR THAT AFFECT THE PERFORMANCE OF VITAL FUNCTIONS. THIS INCLUDES RESEARCH TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK, POULTRY, AQUATIC ANIMALS AND OTHER INCOME PRODUCING ANIMALS AND TO FACILITATE THE EFFECTIVE PREVENTION OF DISEASES IN BOTH DOMESTICATED AND WILD ANIMALS WHICH, IF NOT CONTROLLED, WOULD ENDANGER THE LIVESTOCK AND POULTRY INDUSTRIES. ALSO INCLUDED IS RESEARCH TO MINIMIZE TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING LOSSES; MONITOR THE SUITABILITY OF ANIMALS AND ANIMAL PRODUCTS FOR HUMAN USE; PROTECT PUBLIC HEALTH THROUGH CONTROL OF ANIMAL DISEASES TRANSMISSIBLE TO HUMANS AND IMPROVE METHODS OF CONTROLLING THE REPRODUCTION OF PREDATORS. INVESTIGATIONS OF METABOLIC DISEASES AND REPRODUCTIVE DISEASES INCLUDING ENDOCRINE DYSFUNCTIONS SUCH AS ANESTRUS ARE INCLUDED. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES FROM ACTIVE ANIMAL HEALTH PROJECTS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: 1. GENERATE FERRITIN NANOCAGES DISPLAYING THE HETEROTRIMERIC COMPLEX GP2A‐GP3‐GP4 AND HETERODIMERIC COMPLEX GP5‐M SEPARATELY AND TEST THEIR EFFICACY INDUCING POTENT AND LONG LASTING PROTECTIVE IMMUNE RESPONSES IN PIGS. GENERATE NANOCAGES DISPLAYING BOTH THE HETEROTRIMERIC AND HETERODIMERIC COMPLEXES SIMULTANEOUSLY AND TESTING THEIR EFFICACY IN GENERATING LONG LASTING PROTECTION. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS INNOVATIVE STRATEGY WILL HAVE SIGNIFICANT ADVANTAGES OVER THE CONVENTIONAL SUBUNIT VACCINES IN INDUCING HIGHLY EFFICACIOUS, POTENT, AND LASTING NEUTRALIZING ANTIBODY RESPONSES FOR PROTECTION OF PIGS. 2. TO DEVELOP NOVEL AND EFFECTIVE INTERVENTION STRATEGIES TO CONTROL PRRSV INFECTION OF SWINE. IN STEPS TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL, WE WILL FIRST DESCRIBE 1) THE DYNAMICS OF PRRSV INFECTION OF PAMS, 2) THE COMPRESSIVE LIST OF DIFFERENTIALLY EXPRESSED IN THE DIFFERENT SUB‐POPULATIONS OF MACROPHAGES (INFECTED VS NON‐INFECTED) WITHIN INDIVIDUAL PRRSV INFECTED PIGS AND 3) THE POTENTIAL ROLES OF THE TOP DIFFERENTIALLY EXPRESSED GENES IN PRRSV INFECTION. 3. CONDUCTING GENOMIC RESEARCH THAT WILL LEAD TO 1) IDENTIFICATION OF NOVEL PATHOGENS AND DEVELOPMENT OF DIAGNOSTIC APPROACHES, 2) IN VIVO AND IN VITRO MODELS TO TEST GENES ASSOCIATED WITH VIRAL DISEASE SUSCEPTIBILITY, AND 3) ALTERNATIVE MOLECULAR SOLUTIONS FOR BREEDING AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS IN LIVESTOCK. 4. UNDERSTANDING OF GENOTYPIC AND PHENOTYPIC DIVERSITY OF CIRCULATING OPPORTUNISTIC BACTERIAL PATHOGENS. IDENTIFICATION OF GENOTYPES ASSOCIATED WITH CLINICAL DISEASE AND ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE. TRANSLATION OF GENOTYPES AND PHENOTYPES INTO ASSESSABLE BIOMARKERS TO ENHANCE PATHOGEN CHARACTERIZATION. DEVELOPMENT OF DIAGNOSTIC TESTS THAT FACILITATE RAPID AND HIGH THROUGHPUT TESTING OF PATHOGEN TYPES SUCH AS AMR AND IDENTIFICATION OF VIRULENCE AND POTENTIAL VACCINE TARGETS. FOR A COMPREHENSIVE LIST OF ALL OUTCOMES, WE WELCOME THE REVIEW OF IANR’S ANNUAL REPORT OF ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND RESULTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: AS NEBRASKA’S RESIDENTS ARE THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES AND STAKEHOLDERS, THERE IS AN ONGOING, TWO‐WAY DIALOGUE TO ENSURE THAT IANR’S PRIORITIES REFLECT THE NEEDS OF THE STATE. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/A

ABSTRACT FOR ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM  NORTH DAKOTA AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION  THE PURPOSE OF THE ANIMAL HEALTH CAPACITY FUNDS WILL BE TO DEVELOP NOVEL, RAPID-RESPONSE VACCINE PLATFORMS FOR NEWLY EMERGING PATHOGENS IN SWINE WITH BROAD, PROSPECTIVE APPLICATION. THE ACTIVITIES WILL TARGET THE RAPID ATTENUATION OF VIRAL AGENTS IN A MANNER THAT ENSURES SAFETY AND EFFICACY, BOTH CRITICAL PARAMETERS FOR VACCINE PERFORMANCE. SPECIFIC RESEARCH WILL (1) OBTAIN GENETICALLY WELL CHARACTERIZED, RAPID ATTENUATION OF PORCINE EPIDEMIC DIARRHEA VIRUS ISOLATES, AND OTHER RNA AND DNA VIRUSES BY HEAT AND ENZYMATIC TREATMENT; AND (2) DEVELOP AND TEST DIRECT SUICIDAL VACCINES AGAINST EMERGING VIRUSES. PORK PRODUCTION IS AN IMPORTANT LIVESTOCK SECTOR IN NORTH DAKOTA, AND DUE TO GEOGRAPHIC ISOLATION OF FACILITIES, SWINE PRODUCTION IN NORTH DAKOTA IS RELATIVELY FREE OF INFECTIOUS DISEASES THAT AFFECT THE REST OF THE COUNTRY. WHILE A NAÏVE POPULATION IS A MARKET ADVANTAGE FOR NORTH DAKOTA, IT IS PARTICULARLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO AN EMERGING VIRAL DISEASE. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL HELP TO PROTECT SWINE HEALTH AND IMPROVE PRODUCTION BY REDUCING ECONOMIC LOSSES. WE EXPECT THAT THE TECHNOLOGY WILL STRENGTHEN THE AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY SECTOR, WHICH HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A PRIORITY AREA FOR DEVELOPMENT AND INVESTMENT BY THE STATE OF NORTH DAKOTA. THE COMMERCIALIZATION OF UNIVERSITY RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING TO THE NEXT GENERATION OF NORTH DAKOTA SCIENTISTS WHO WILL BE ABLE TO COMPETE ON A GLOBAL AND INTER-DISCIPLINARY LEVEL IN THE BIOTECHNOLOGY AND VIROLOGY AREAS

A TISSUE ENGINEERING APPROACH TO INVESTIGATE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN PATHOGENS AND MAMMALIAN CELLS, EUKARYOTIC CELL DEVELOPMENT, OR OTHER DISEASE STATES OF MAMMALIAN CELLS CAN BEST BE ACCOMPLISHED USING INNOVATIVE THREE-DIMENSIONAL (3-D) TISSUE CULTURES, OR ORGANOIDS. 3-D TISSUE CULTURES PRESENT A MORE PHYSIOLOGICALLY RELEVANT SYSTEM THAN SIMPLE 2-D TISSUE CULTURES. SEVERAL PHYSIOLOGICAL PROCESSES ARE CORRELATED TO THE DIMENSIONALITY OF THE CELLULAR MICROENVIRONMENT AND ARE DEPENDENT ON CHARACTERISTICS OF THE SURROUNDING SUBSTRATE. THERE IS GROWING EVIDENCE THAT SEVERAL ASPECTS OF CELLULAR AND TISSUE LEVEL FUNCTIONS THAT HAVE BEEN PREVIOUSLY OBSERVED ON 2-D SUBSTRATES MAY INDEED CHANGE WHEN CELLS HAVE TO NAVIGATE THROUGH A COMPLEX 3-D NETWORK. FOR EXAMPLE, SOME OF THE FACTORS THAT HAVE DELAYED A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING FOR TREATING BOVINE RESPIRATORY DISEASES DUE TO BACTERIAL AND VIRAL INFECTION, BOVINE METRITIS, AND UNDERSTANDING ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITY IN VIVO IS THE LACK OF PHYSIOLOGICALLY-RELEVANT 3-D TISSUE CULTURES TO OBTAIN FUNDAMENTAL INSIGHTS INTO HOW PATHOGENS HARM CELLS. A 3-D TISSUE CULTURE SYSTEM WOULD BE PARTICULARLY USEFUL IN FOLLOWING THE ATTACHMENT AND BIOFILM DEVELOPMENT OF BACTERIAL PATHOGENS IN HOST TISSUES. OUR GOAL IS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND ANIMAL DISEASES THAT AFFECT ORGAN SYSTEMS DUE TO, OR INDEPENDENTLY FROM, INFECTIOUS AGENTS IN ORDER TO PREVENT OR TREAT DISEASES AFFECTING SUCH ORGANS. TO OBTAIN THIS GOAL, OUR OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) DEVELOP A 3-D TISSUE CULTURE SYSTEM LABORATORY TO SERVE LONG ISLAND UNIVERSITY (LIU) COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE FACULTY IN ADVANCING THEIR RESEARCH, 2) TRAIN AN LIU RESEARCH SCIENTIST IN THE ART OF ESTABLISHING A 3-D TISSUE CULTURE OF ANY CELL LINE THAT CAN BE MADE AVAILABLE; 3) CARRY OUT EXPERIMENTS AND PUBLISH THE RESULTS OF THE USE OF 3-D TISSUE CULTURES RELEVANT TO UNDERSTANDING AND CONTROLLING ANIMAL DISEASES IMPORTANT TO AGRICULTURE. THE EUKARYOTIC CELLS OF CHOICE (E.G. BOVINE RESPIRATORY EPITHELIAL OR ENDOTHELIAL CELLS) WILL BE CULTURED USING A PREVIOUSLY ESTABLISHED PROCEDURE. THE CELLS WILL BE CULTURED IN SERUM-FREE CULTURE MEDIUM FOR 3-4 DAYS, THEN ENZYMATICALLY DETACHED AND CULTURED ON POROUS TRANSWELL INSERTS. A POLYGLYCOLINE SCAFFOLD (SYNTHECON) WILL BE SEEDED ON PLATES, AND THEN INCUBATED WITH FIBRONECTIN SOLUTION FOR 1 H AT RT TO IMPROVE CELL ADHERENCE. THE CELLS (5 X 106 CELLS IN 50 ΜL) WILL BE ADDED ONTO THE CENTER OF EACH SCAFFOLD DISC AND INCUBATED FOR 1 H AT 38.5°C. MEDIUM IS ADDED TO EACH WELL AND THE PLATE MAINTAINED IN A HUMIDIFIED ENVIRONMENT OF 5% CO2 AT 38.5°C. EACH DAY TRANS-EPITHELIAL ELECTRICAL RESISTANCE (TEER) MEASUREMENTS ARE CONDUCTED TO MEASURE THEIR DIFFERENTIATION. WHEN THE TEER VALUES REACH 200 WCM2, THE CULTURE MEDIUM IS CHANGED TO A FORMULATION CONTAINING EPIDERMAL GROWTH FACTOR, RETINOIC ACID, AND BOVINE PITUITARY EXTRACT TO PROMOTE EPITHELIALIZATION. WHEN THE TEER VALUES EXCEED 500 WCM2, THE CULTURE MEDIUM FROM APICAL CHAMBER WILL BE REMOVED IN ORDER TO EXPOSE THE CELLS TO AIR AND FORM A 3-D CELL LAYER IN THE AIR-LIQUID INTERFACE. THE CULTURES WILL BE MAINTAINED UP TO 3 WEEKS PRIOR TO USE IN DESIGNED EXPERIMENTS, SUCH AS BIOFILM FORMATION BY ANIMAL PATHOGENS. THE THICKNESS OF THE CELL LAYER WILL BE IMAGED USING CONFOCAL LASER SCANNING MICROSCOPY (CLSM), AND QUANTIFIED AND VIABILITY MEASURED BY LIVE/DEAD STAINING USING IMAGEJ SOFTWARE (NIH). ONCE THE 3-D ORGANOID IS ESTABLISHED FOR THAT CELL LINE, THE 3-D TISSUE CULTURE CAN BE USED BY THE PRINCIPLE INVESTIGATOR AS NEEDED. FOR EXAMPLE, THE STUDY OF BIOFILMS ON THE ORGANOID CAN BE DONE USING CLSM, LIVE/DEAD STAIN, AND SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY IN A GROWTH SYSTEM IN WHICH DEVELOPMENT OF THE BIOFILM CAN BE EXAMINED IN THE CLSM OVER TIME, THUS PROVIDING MORE THOROUGH INFORMATION ON HOW BIOFILMS DEVELOP IN HOST TISSUES. WILD TYPE AND MUTANT STRAINS CAN BE TESTED FOR UNDERSTANDING COMPONENTS AND REGULATORY FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO BIOFILM DEVELOPMENT. POLY-MICROBIAL BIOFILMS CAN ALSO BE EXAMINED IN THIS SYSTEM TO STUDY COMMENSALISM, MUTUALISM, AND ANTAGONISM BETWEEN MICROORGANISMS. INVESTIGATION INTO THE EFFECTS OF ANTIBIOTICS AND COMPOUNDS THAT DISRUPT A BIOFILM CAN ALSO BE STUDIED IN A 3-D SYSTEM THAT MORE CLOSELY REPLICATES BIOFILM INFECTION IN THE HOST.

ANIMAL HEALTH CAPACITY FUNDS ABSTRACT  THE CAPACITY FUNDS FROM USDA‐NIFA ARE TO SUPPORT ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH FOR THE BENEFIT OF IMPROVED ANIMAL HEALTH OF AGRICULTURAL ANIMALS PERFORMED BY NCSU FACULTY AND STUDENTS. FUNDS WILL BE USED TO STRATEGICALLY INVEST IN PROMISING RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT WILL IMPACT PRODUCTION ANIMALS, PURCHASE EQUIPMENT OR MATERIALS NEEDED TO SUPPORT THE RESEARCH THAT WILL BE DONE FOR THE BENEFIT OF THESE SPECIES OR HELP SUPPORT TRAINEES (UNDERGRADUATE, VETERINARY, AND GRADUATE STUDENTS, POST DOCTORAL FELLOWS) OR STAFF INVOLVED WITH THE COMPLETION OF THE RESEARCH. OUR EXPECTATION IS THAT THE INVESTMENT WILL RESULT IN ADDITIONAL DISCOVERIES, SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE, RESEARCH PUBLICATION AND PATENTS THAT WILL BENEFIT THESE SPECIES

AHDR ABSTRACT – RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY. NEW JERSEY AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION THE USDA-NIFA ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROVIDES SUPPORT FOR RESEARCH ON DISEASES AFFECTING FOOD-PRODUCING ANIMALS. UNIVERSITY LABORATORIES ARE THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CENTERS FOR AMERICAN AGRICULTURE.  AT THE NEW JERSEY AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION AT RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY, ANIMAL HEALTH-RELATED PROJECTS FOCUS ON AREAS SUCH AS OUR ROBUST AQUACULTURE RESEARCH AND BREEDING PROGRAMS. WE ALSO HAVE RESEARCHERS CONDUCTING MANY VARIOUS PROJECTS STUDYING ANIMAL-HUMAN CONNECTIONS SUCH AS THE STUDY OF THE BIOLOGY OF ARTHROPOD VECTORS AND HOW THEY FIND AND TRANSMIT DISEASES TO ANIMALS AND THEN TO HUMANS, AND TRANSLATIONAL MOLECULAR BIOLOGY TO APPLY DISCOVERIES FOUND DURING LABORATORY RODENT RESEARCH AND COMPARE THEM TO ANIMAL AND HUMAN HEALTH AND DISEASE ISSUES. PREVIOUS ANIMAL HEALTH PROJECTS HAVE FOCUSED ON NEMATODE PARASITES ON PASTURES IN NEW JERSEYCAUSING PROBLEMS ON DOMESTIC ANIMAL FARMS, AND URBAN DEER CAUSING RISK TO HUMANS CONTRACTING LYME DISEASE. CURRENT AHDR PROJECTS HIGHLIGHT OYSTER AQUACULTURE, A MAJOR INDUSTRY IN THE US AND WORLDWIDE. THE GOALS OF THESE AQUACULTURE PROJECTS ARE TO IMPROVE ANIMAL HEALTH BY PRODUCING DISEASE-RESISTANT OYSTER STOCKS AS WELL AS TO IMPROVE GROWTH DESPITE WARMING OCEANS AND ACIDIFICATION CAUSING STRESS WHICH MAKES OYSTERS AND OTHER SHELLFISH MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO DISEASES.

UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE – PROJECT ABSTRACT RESEARCH AND INNOVATION IS THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THE NH AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION. IN THE 2023-2027 PERIOD, THE STATION EXPECTS TO SUPPORT BETWEEN 44 AND 50 RESEARCH PROJECTS ACROSS FIVE CRITICAL ISSUES—AGRICULTURE; CLIMATE CHANGE AND SUSTAINING NATURAL RESOURCES; FOOD SAFETY; NUTRITION, HEALTH, AND WELLNESS; AND RURAL COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT—AS WELL AS PROJECTS WITHIN THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS FORESTRY SCIENCE AREAS. WITHIN THE AGRICULTURE AREA, RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON INCREASING KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY TO SUPPORT HIGHLY DIVERSIFIED AGRICULTURAL AND FOOD SYSTEM THAT PRODUCES, PROCESSES AND DELIVERS FOOD, FIBER, AND MYRIAD ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES. EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON BIOTECHNOLOGICAL AND MANAGEMENT IMPROVEMENTS IN CROP AND DAIRY PRODUCTION TO MINIMIZE PRODUCTION AND MARKET RISKS AND CAPTURING NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES. RESEARCH HERE IS EXPECTED TO GROW WITH THE RECENT HIRING OF A CROP BREEDER FACULTY. FOCUS WILL ALSO BE PLACED ON HELPING THE STATE AND REGION CONTINUE TO EXPAND ITS SUSTAINABLE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY TO BENEFIT THE BLUE ECONOMY. WORK WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO TARGET ISSUES RELATED TO MITIGATING AND ADAPTING TO CLIMATE CHANGE, ESPECIALLY IN THE ROLE OF AGRICULTURE AS A SOLUTION TO CLIMATE CHANGE. THROUGH BASIC AND APPLIED SCIENCE, AN EMERGING AREA OF EXCELLENCE IS IN SOIL MICROBIOLOGY, AND THESE EFFORTS WILL BE ONE OF THE CORE OF THE NHAES RESEARCH MISSION IN CLIMATE SCIENCE. A SECOND CORE AREA IS IN WATER QUANTITY AND QUALITY MANAGEMENT, ESPECIALLY AS IT RELATES TO THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN WATER AND AGRICULTURAL LAND AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. FOOD SAFETY IS AN AREA IN WHICH LESS RESEARCH IS EXPECTED THAN IN THE PAST. HOWEVER, THE RESEARCH THAT WILL CONTINUE WILL FOCUS ON SUPPORTING THE GROWING AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY, ESPECIALLY AS IT RELATES TO MANAGING PATHOGENS IN SHELLFISH. DIFFERENTIATING STRAINS OF PATHOGENS AND PREDICTING NEW STRAINS IS CRITICAL TO ENSURING THAT THE NORTHEAST AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY MAINTAINS ITS HIGH QUALITY STANDARDS. RESEARCH IS EXPECTED TO GROW IN THE NUTRITION AND HEALTH AND WELLNESS AREAS, AS EARLY-CAREER FACULTY TRANSITION INTO BEING MORE EXPERIENCED SCIENTISTS AND NEW FACULTY ARE ONBOARDED. THE FOCUS OF THE RESEARCH WILL BE ON IDENTIFYING AND DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ENSURING NUTRITIONAL BALANCE AND HEALTH OF UNDERREPRESENTED POPULATIONS IN NORTHERN NEW ENGLAND. THIS INCLUDES REFUGEE, IMMIGRANT, AND LATINX POPULATIONS, WHICH HAVE CONTINUED TO GROW IN SIZE IN THE REGION. CONSIDERATIONS OF THE DIFFERENCES IN THESE POPULATIONS' EATING HABITS, MICROBIOME COMPOSITIONS, AND NUTRITIONAL BEHAVIORS WILL HELP INFORM SCIENCE-BASED RECOMMENDATIONS. LASTLY, AS NEW HAMPSHIRE'S COMMUNITIES CONTINUE TO EVOLVE DEMOGRAPHICALLY AND SOCIOECONOMICALLY, NHAES RESEARCH WILL CONTINUE TO FOCUS PART OF ITS RESEARCH PORTFOLIO ON CHARACTERIZING THOSE TRENDS, THE IMPACTS OF THOSE TRENDS, AND HOW LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS CAN BE BEST DEVELOPED TO BE SUCCESSFUL AND SUPPORT THE CHANGING DEMOGRAPHICS OF THE STATE AND REGION. USING SCIENCE-BASED, DATA-DRIVEN METHODS TO IDENTIFY KEY FACTORS STRESSING ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL WELFARE IN RURAL COMMUNITIES AND PROVIDING RESEARCH-INFORMED RECOMMENDATIONS AT THE INDIVIDUAL, FIRM, MUNICIPALITY, AND STATE LEVELS ARE CRUCIAL FOR SHORT- AND LONG-TERM COMMUNITY SUSTAINABILITY. THE NHAES WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO GROW ITS OUTREACH AND SCIENCE COMMUNICATION PROGRAM. AFTER LAUNCHING IN WINTER 2021, A NEW PUBLICATI ON, INSPIRED, FOCUSES ON PRESENTING RESEARCH BRIEFS TO A BROAD POPULATION OF STAKEHOLDERS IN THE STATE AND REGION. THIS EFFORT WILL CONTINUE WITH ISSUES PUBLISHED AND MAILED BIANNUALLY. ADDITIONALLY, THE STATION WILL MAINTAIN ITS HIGHLY ROBUST ACTIVITY OF DISSEMINATING ITS RESEARCH THROUGH WEEKLY NEWS BRIEFS (WHICH FOCUS ON NHAES RESEARCH), SOCIAL MEDIA PRESENCE, FIELD DAYS, AND INCREASINGLY MORE INTEGRATED COLLABORATION WITH EXTENSION.

TITLE: UNDERSTANDING THE ROLE OF CYCLOOXYGENASE ISOFORMS AND SOLUBLE EPOXIDE HYDROLASE IN CHONDROCYTE APOPTOSIS AND JOINT PAIN. AREAS OF INTEREST: DEGENERATIVE JOINT DISEASES, MUSCULOSKELETAL PAIN. PI: ALONSO GUEDES GUEDE003@UMN.EDU, CO IS: TROY TRUMBLE, CATHY CARLSON BACKGROUND/PROBLEM:  OSTEOARTHRITIS (OA) IS HIGHLY PREVALENT IN ANIMALS AND HUMANS;  THERE IS AN URGENT NEED FOR THERAPIES THAT CAN EFFECTIVELY MITIGATE OA ASSOCIATED PAIN, DISABILITY AND JOINT PATHOLOGY;  A THERAPY WITH THESE QUALITIES WOULD HAVE A HIGH SOCIOECONOMIC IMPACT IN BOTH ANIMAL AND HUMAN HEALTH/MEDICINE. OBJECTIVE: TO ELUCIDATE THE INTERACTION BETWEEN TWO COX ISOFORMS (COX 1 AND COX 2) AND SEH IN APOPTOSIS OF EQUINE PRIMARY ARTICULAR CHONDROCYTES AND (II) THEIR EFFECTS ON REACTIVITY OF PRIMARY SENSORY NEURONS. RESEARCH PLAN: WE WILL USE CULTURED PRIMARY EQUINE ARTICULAR CHONDROCYTES AND PERIPHERAL SENSORY NEURONS OBTAINED FROM MICE. HOW/WHY IS THE RESEARCH TEAM UNIQUELY QUALIFIED? A STRONG MULTIDISCIPLINARY TEAM (ANESTHESIOLOGIST, EQUINE SURGEON, PATHOLOGIST) WITH ROBUST PRELIMINARY IN VIVO AND IN VITRO DATA TO SUPPORT OUR HYPOTHESES.  BENEFITS OF PROPOSED RESEARCH/ EXPECTED OUTCOMES AND IMPACT:  WE BELIEVE, BASED ON STRONG PRELIMINARY DATA, THAT IT IS IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTAND THE INTERACTION BETWEEN SEH THE COX ISOFORMS IN MEDIATING CHONDROCYTE APOPTOSIS AND HYPERREACTIVITY OF SENSORY NEURONS IN ORDER TO GUIDE DEVELOPMENT OF A NOVEL ANALGESIC THERAPY FOR OA. SUCH DEVELOPMENT WILL VERTICALLY ADVANCE THE MOST COMMON OA THERAPY, WHICH IS BASED ON COX INHIBITION ALONE BUT IS OFTEN INADEQUATE FOR PAIN RELIEF, HAVE NO DISEASE MODIFYING EFFECT AND CAN CAUSE SIGNIFICANT ADVERSE EFFECTS. IF YOURE SUCCESSFUL, WHAT DIFFERENCE WILL YOUR RESULTS MAKE?  OUR RESULTS WILL SUPPORT FUTURE GRANT APPLICATIONS TO DEVELOP THIS TECHNOLOGY FOR THE CLINICAL MANAGEMENT OF NATURALLY OCCURRING OA IN HORSES AND POSSIBLY OTHER SPECIES. WHAT ARE THE RISKS?  THERE IS SOME RISK THAT DATA OBTAINED IN CELL CULTURES MAY NOT ENTIRELY RECAPITULATE THE NATURALLY OCCURRING DISEASE. HOWEVER, WE BELIEVE THIS RISK TO BE SMALL BASED ON OUR EXTENSIVE PRELIMINARY DATA SUPPORTING AN INTERACTION BETWEEN SEH AND COX IN BOTH MICE AND HORSES  PICTURE OR GRAPHIC THAT ILLUSTRATES THE RESEARCH OR CONCEPT: ARACHIDONIC ACID (AA) METABOLISM VIA THE CYCLOOXYGENASE (COX) AND SOLUBLE EPOXIDE HYDROLASE (SEH) PATHWAYS. SEH BREAKS DOWN BENEFICIAL EPOXYEICOSATRIENOIC ACIDS (EETS), GENERATED BY EPOXYGENASES (CYP450) FROM AA, TO THEIR CORRESPONDING HARMFUL DIHYDROXYEICOSATRIENOIC ACID (DIHETS). COX ACTIVITY RESULT IN PRODUCTION OF PROSTAGLANDINS (PG) AND THROMBOXANES (TX). THESE METABOLITES INTERACT IN COOPERATIVE AND OPPOSING WAYS TO REGULATE CELLULAR ACTIVITY, THAT CAN BE MODULATED BY COMBINED INHIBITION OF COX AND SEH.  TIMELINE, MILESTONES AND FUNDING: WHO ARE POTENTIAL FUNDERS?   FOUNDATIONS (GRAYSON JOCKEY CLUB, AMERICAN QUARTER HORSE) AND NIH HOW MUCH WILL IT COST?  $29,173 IN YEAR 1 AND $26,449 IN YEAR 2 (TOTAL $55 ,662) HOW LONG WILL IT TAKE?  IT WILL TAKE APPROXIMATELY 18 24 MONTHS TO COMPLETE THIS PROJECT. WHAT ARE THE MIDTERM AND FINAL MILESTONES FOR THIS PROJECT?  A GANTT CHART IN THE PROPOSAL DETAILS TIMELINES/MILESTONES. BRIEFLY:  BY ABOUT 3 6 MONTHS: PURCHASE SUPPLIES, EXPAND MOUSE COLONY AND BEGIN EXPERIMENTS. BY MIDTERM (ABOUT 9 12 MONTHS): APOPTOSIS EXPERIMENTS COMPLETED; 1/3 OF NEURON EXPERIMENTS COMPLETED (24/72 MICE STUDIED)  BY ABOUT 12 18 MONTHS: APOPTOSIS MANUSCRIPT SUBMITTED/GRANT SUBMITTED;   BY ABOUT 18 24 MONTHS: NEURONAL EXPERIMENTS COMPLETED, MANUSCRIPT SUBMITTED/GRANT SUBMITTED.

THE USDA DEDICATES FUNDING TO INCREASE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AT ACCREDITED PUBLIC OR PRIVATE VETERINARY SCHOOLS OR COLLEGES THROUGH THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH (AHDR) CAPACITY PROGRAM. THE SCOPE OF THE RESEARCH WHICH MAY BE CONDUCTED WITH AHDR FUNDS IS QUITE BROAD. IT INCLUDES RESEARCH TO PROMOTE THE GENERAL WELFARE THROUGH IMPROVED HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK, POULTRY, AQUATIC ANIMALS, AND OTHER INCOME-PRODUCING ANIMALS WHICH ARE ESSENTIAL TO THE NATION'S FOOD SUPPLY AND THE WELFARE OF PRODUCERS AND CONSUMERS OF ANIMAL PRODUCTS; TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF HORSES; TO FACILITATE THE EFFECTIVE TREATMENT OF, AND WHERE POSSIBLE, PREVENT, DISEASES IN BOTH DOMESTICATED AND WILD SPECIES WHICH, IF NOT CONTROLLED, WOULD BE DISASTROUS TO THE UNITED STATES ANIMAL INDUSTRIES AND ENDANGER THE NATION'S FOOD SUPPLY; TO MINIMIZE LIVESTOCK AND POULTRY LOSSES DUE TO TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING; TO PROTECT HUMAN HEALTH THROUGH CONTROL OF ANIMAL DISEASES TRANSMISSIBLE TO HUMANS; TO IMPROVE METHODS OF CONTROLLING REPRODUCTION OF PREDATORS AND OTHER ANIMALS; AND OTHERWISE TO PROMOTE THE GENERAL WELFARE THROUGH EXPANDED PROGRAMS OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION TO IMPROVE ANIMAL HEALTH.  ANIMAL HEALTH RESEARCH COMPRISES BASIC AND APPLIED STUDIES ON INFECTIOUS AND NONINFECTIOUS AGENTS WHICH IMPAIR THE NORMAL STATE OF THE ANIMAL BODY AND/OR THAT AFFECT THE PERFORMANCE OF VITAL FUNCTIONS. THIS INCLUDES RESEARCH TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK, POULTRY, AQUATIC ANIMALS AND OTHER INCOME-PRODUCING ANIMALS AND TO FACILITATE THE EFFECTIVE PREVENTION OF DISEASES IN BOTH DOMESTICATED AND WILD ANIMALS WHICH, IF NOT CONTROLLED, WOULD ENDANGER THE LIVESTOCK AND POULTRY INDUSTRIES. ALSO INCLUDED IS RESEARCH TO MINIMIZE TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING LOSSES; MONITOR THE SUITABILITY OF ANIMALS AND ANIMAL PRODUCTS FOR HUMAN USE; PROTECT PUBLIC HEALTH THROUGH CONTROL OF ANIMAL DISEASES TRANSMISSIBLE TO HUMANS AND IMPROVE METHODS OF CONTROLLING THE REPRODUCTION OF PREDATORS.  STUDIES ARE CLASSIFIED AS AHDR IF THE STUDIES RELATE DIRECTLY TO THE HEALTH OF A TARGET LIVESTOCK, POULTRY OR AQUATIC ANIMAL SPECIES AND INCLUDES LABORATORY STUDIES, RESEARCH ON ANIMAL CARE AS IT RELATES TO LIVESTOCK HEALTH AND WELL-BEING, INVESTIGATIONS OF METABOLIC DISEASES AND REPRODUCTIVE DISEASES INCLUDING ENDOCRINE DYSFUNCTIONS SUCH AS ANESTRUS AS WELL AS THE INFRASTRUCTURE AND EQUIPMENT NECESSARY TO COMPLETE THIS RESEARCH. APPLICATION OF MOLECULAR BIOLOGY TO ANIMAL HEALTH PROBLEMS IS INCLUDED.

PROJECT ABSTRACT – MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY: ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM THE MISSION OF MSU AGBIORESEARCH IS TO ENGAGE IN INNOVATIVE, LEADING‐EDGE RESEARCH THAT COMBINES SCIENTIFIC EXPERTISE WITH PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE TO GENERATE ECONOMIC PROSPERITY, SUSTAIN NATURAL RESOURCES, AND ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF LIFE IN MICHIGAN, THE NATION AND THE WORLD. AS WE OFTEN DESCRIBE AS “FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH WITH AN INTENDED OUTCOME.” ALL OF OUR RESEARCH IS AIMED AT SOLVING PROBLEM OR CREATING A NEW OPPORTUNITY. THE 340 PLUS RESEARCHERS ACROSS CAMPUS STRIVE TO MAINTAIN A BALANCE BETWEEN BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH AND RELY HEAVILY ON THE INPUT OF THEIR CONSTITUENTS IN IDENTIFYING RESEARCH PRIORITIES. WITH ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH FUNDING, WE WILL: CONDUCT RESEARCH ON NEW METHODS TO COMBAT DISEASES AND PARASITES; STUDY NUTRITION AND ANIMAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS.

UNIVERSITY OF MAINE – ANIMAL HEALTH ABSTRACT  THE MAINE AGRICULTURAL AND FOREST EXPERIMENT STATION HAS BEEN CONDUCTING ANIMAL HEALTH AND OTHER AGRICULTURE RESEARCH FOR MAINE AND ITS PEOPLE FOR OVER 125 YEARS. ANNUAL APPROPRIATIONS UNDER ANIMAL HEALTH, IN COMBINATION WITH UNIVERSITY OF MAINE FUNDS, PROVIDE FUNDING TO FACULTY IN THE ANIMAL AND VETERINARY SCIENCES PROGRAM FOR RESEARCH PROGRAMS OF THE STATION. THE RESEARCH CAPACITY PROVIDED BY ANIMAL HEALTH LEVERAGES ADDITIONAL FUNDING FROM COMPETITIVE GRANTS AND CONTRACTS AND INDUSTRY SUPPORT. ANIMAL HEALTH FUNDS ARE USED AT THE MAINE AGRICULTURAL AND FOREST EXPERIMENT STATION TO SUPPORT RESEARCH ON PROJECTS ADDRESSING HEALTH AND DISEASE OF AGRICULTURAL ANIMALS. THE STATION DIRECTOR WILL FACILITATE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW ANIMAL HEALTH PROJECTS OF WHICH THERE TENDS TO BE THREE ACTIVE PROJECTS AT ANY TIME, APPROVE NEW PROJECTS AND MONITOR ALL APPROVED PROJECTS INCLUDING LEVERAGED GRANTS AND CONTRACTS. THE CURRENT PROJECTS FOCUS ON EQUINE, POULTRY, AND SWINE HEALTH.

UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND COLLEGE AGNR ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH, FY 2023 PROJECT ABSTRACT  THE MARYLAND AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (MAES) OF THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES (AGNR) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND WILL UTILIZE THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH (AHDR) FUND FOR THE RESEARCH PROJECT ENTITLED “ROLE OF IL-27 SIGNALING IN FUNGAL INFECTION” CONDUCTED AT THE LABORATORY LOCATED IN AGNR’S DEPARTMENT OF VETERINARY MEDICINE. THE STUDY FOCUSES ON CRYPTOCOCCUS NEOFORMANS, A FUNGAL PATHOGEN THAT INFECTS HUMANS AND ANIMALS WORLDWIDE. EACH YEAR, ABOUT 600,000 PEOPLE DIE FROM CRYPTOCOCCOSIS. THE FUNGUS ALSO INFECTS ANIMALS, INCLUDING CATS, DOGS, CATTLE, HORSES, SHEEP, GOATS, PIGS, AND WILD ANIMALS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO CHARACTERIZE THE ROLE OF IL-27 IN REGULATING THE IMMUNE RESPONSES TO C. NEOFORMANS INFECTION. TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, A MOUSE MODEL WAS ESTABLISHED TO STUDY THE FUNCTION OF IL-27. MICE ARE INFECTED INTRANASALLY OR INTRAVENOUSLY WITH THE FUNGAL ORGANISMS AND THEN EUTHANIZED AT VARIOUS TIME POINTS AFTER INFECTION. DIFFERENT TISSUES OF THE INFECTED MICE ARE COLLECTED AND ANALYZED FOR IMMUNE RESPONSES USING DIFFERENT APPROACHES. THESE ASSAYS HELP DETERMINE THE EXACT FUNCTIONS OF IL-27 IN REGULATING HOST IMMUNE RESPONSES. THE TARGET AUDIENCE IS HEALTH WORKERS, VETERINARIANS, AND BIOMEDICAL RESEARCHERS. THE FINDINGS OF THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THESE AUDIENCES WITH FUNDAMENTAL KNOWLEDGE REGARDING HOST IMMUNE RESPONSES TO FUNGAL INFECTIONS, WHICH IS IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTAND THE PATHOGENESIS OF THE DISEASE. THE MECHANISMS ELUCIDATED BY THIS PROJECT CAN BE USED TO MAKE NOVEL THERAPEUTIC STRATEGIES FOR THE DISEASE, HAVING THE POTENTIAL TO IMPROVE THE TREATMENT OF THE DISEASE. OUTPUTS WILL INCLUDE PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLES AND PRESENTATIONS AT PROFESSIONAL AND SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES. AGNR RESEARCH PROJECTS ARE PEER-REVIEWED BEFORE THEY ARE APPROVED BY THE MAES DIRECTOR TO ENSURE THAT THEY ALIGN WITH THE PURPOSES OF THE AHDR PROGRAM. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT NOTED ABOVE ALIGNS WITH THE USDA STRATEGIC PLAN FY 2022-2026 (GOAL 4: PROVIDE ALL AMERICANS SAFE, NUTRITIOUS FOOD) AND OUR COLLEGE’S STRATEGIC INITIATIVE - ONE HEALTH: IMPROVE HUMAN, ANIMAL, AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH.  AGNR SUBMITS AN ANNUAL INVENTORY OF ANIMAL HEALTH RESEARCH PROJECTS TO USDA-NIFA CALLED THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH CAPACITY REPORT (RCR). THESE PROJECTS ARE FUNDED BY VARIOUS FEDERAL AND NON-FEDERAL SOURCES AND INVOLVE STUDIES OF ANIMAL DISEASES; UNDERSTANDING MECHANISMS OF IMMUNE RESPONSES AND HOW IT CONTROLS INFECTIOUS DISEASES; AND DEVELOPMENT OF NOVEL VACCINES AND ANTI-VIRAL THERAPEUTICS. OTHER RESEARCH ARE IN THE AREAS OF ANIMAL NUTRITION, GROWTH, REPRODUCTION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS AFFECTING LIVESTOCK AND POULTRY PRODUCTION.

PROJECT ABSTRACT: UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AMHERST 1 ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH  THE PURPOSE OF FEDERAL ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH FUNDING PROVIDED BY USDA/NIFA IS TO PROMOTE ANIMAL HEALTH RESEARCH AT ACCREDITED STATE VETERINARY SCHOOLS OR COLLEGES OR AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATIONS. RESEARCH SUPPORTED BY THIS PROGRAM IMPROVES THE FLOW OF KNOWLEDGE AND RESOURCES TO PRODUCERS REGARDING ANIMAL HUSBANDRY PRACTICES, DIAGNOSTIC AND TREATMENT METHODS; FOSTERS THE ACHIEVEMENT OF FOOD SAFETY GOALS; AND ADVANCES THE WELL-BEING AND TREATMENT OF FARM ANIMALS, WITH PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON DISEASE PREVENTION STRATEGIES. AT UMASS AMHERST, THE FUNDS ASSOCIATED WITH THE FEDERAL ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH ARE USED TO SUPPORT STUDENT EMPLOYMENT AND TO PROVIDE OPERATING FUNDS FOR RESEARCH RELATED EXPENDITURES (RESEARCH EQUIPMENT, MATERIALS, SUPPLIES, AND TRAVEL) BY FACULTY INVESTIGATORS WHO EMPLOY A VARIETY OF METHODS APPROPRIATE TO THEIR DISCIPLINE AND SPECIFIC PROGRAM OF RESEARCH. THE FUNDS ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE MASSACHUSETTS AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENTATION STATION, A UNIT OF THE CENTER FOR AGRICULTURE, FOOD AND THE ENVIRONMENT (CAFE), WITHIN THE UMASS COLLEGE OF NATURAL SCIENCES AND ARE TYPICALLY USED BY FACULTY IN THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERINARY AND ANIMAL SCIENCE WHO EMPLOY A WIDE VARIETY OF SCIENTIFIC METHODS FOR INVESTIGATIONS FOCUSED ON UNDERSTANDING AND TREATING LIVESTOCK INFECTION.

PROJECT ABSTRACT  THE PROPOSED WORK COVERED UNDER THIS AWARD FALLS INTO TWO BROAD CATEGORIES. THE FIRST IS SUPPORT FOR WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT THROUGH T RAINING OF PROFESSIONAL (DVM) STUDENTS IN RESEARCH RELEVANT TO THE STATED USDA OBJECTIVES. THE SECOND RELATES TO DIRECTLY SUPPORTING RESEARCH THAT IMPROVES THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF USDA TARGET SPECIES. THESE SEPARATE INITIATIVES ARE DETAILED BELOW: SHORT TERM TRAINING OF DVM STUDENTS: VETERINARIANS PLAY A CRITICAL ROLE IN SAFEGUARDING THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING FOOD ANIMALS, ENSURING THE SAFETY OF THESE ANIMALS, AND WORKING WITH FARMERS/PRODUCERS IN RURAL SETTINGS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT IN AREAS OF UNMET NEED. ONGOING CHALLENGES EXIST WITH RESPECT TO SUSTAINABILITY OF THIS WORKFORCE AS INCREASINGLY DVM STUDENTS AND NEW GRADUATE VETERINARIANS ARE MIGRATING INTO SMALL ANIMAL PRACTICES, THUS CONSTRAINING THE POOL OF QUALIFIED INDIVIDUALS. GIVEN THE COMPLEX INTERDEPENDENCE OF ANIMAL, HUMAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH, AND THE EVOLVING COMPLEXITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE, IT IS BECOMING EVEN MORE IMPORTANT TO EFFECTIVELY ENGAGE THE DVM STUDENT POPULATION TO CONSIDER ALTERNATE CAREERS. TO ADDRESS THIS SPECIFIC NEED, WE PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR 2-4 DVM STUDENTS TO UNDERTAKE RESEARCH OVER THE SUMMER, PERFORMING STUDIES RELEVANT FOR THE SUSTAINABILITY AND HEALTH OF FOOD/FIBER ANIMAL SPECIES. THESE STUDENTS SPEND 12 WEEKS IMMERSED IN THEIR SPECIFIC PROJECT, AND MOST WILL PRESENT THEIR FINDINGS AT THE NATIONAL VETERINARY SCHOLARS SYMPOSIUM. IMPORTANTLY, ALL STUDENTS UNDERTAKING USDA SUPPORTED RESEARCH PRESENT A POSTER AT THE TUFTS CUMMINGS ANNUAL RESEARCH DAY AT THE BEGINNING OF SEPTEMBER. ATTENDANCE AT RESEARCH DAY IS MANDATORY FOR ALL INCOMING FIRST YEAR AND CONTINUING SECOND YEAR DVM STUDENTS, WITH THE GOAL OF MAXIMIZING EXPOSURE TO RESEARCH AND ALTERNATIVE CAREER PATHS VERY EARLY IN THEIR TRAINING. RESEARCH RELEVANT TO FOOD/FIBER SPECIES: OVER THE PAST DECADE, IT HAS BECOME INCREASINGLY CLEAR THAT THE MICROBIOTA IN THE INTESTINE, LUNGS, SKIN, AND OTHER ORGANS PLAYS A CRITICAL ROLE IN REGULATING DISEASE SUSCEPTIBILITIES. HOWEVER, VERY LITTLE IS CURRENTLY KNOWN REGARDING HOW THIS IS AFFECTED BY EXTERNAL AND INTERNAL INFLUENCES. THIS IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT WITH RESPECT TO THE INTESTINAL MICROBIOTA, A COMMUNITY OF BILLIONS OF MICROORGANISMS, WITHIN THE DIGESTIVE SYSTEM. THIS MICROBIOTA MOSTLY CONSISTS OF BACTERIA AND PERFORMS METABOLIC FUNCTIONS WHICH ARE ESSENTIAL FOR DIGESTING NUTRIENTS AND REGULATING THE IMMUNE RESPONSE. WITH THE ADVENT OF HIGH-THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING TECHNOLOGY IS HAS BECOME FEASIBLE TO SEQUENCE THE DNA OF COMPLEX MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES. THIS APPROACH HAS BEEN USED TO INVESTIGATE A MULTITUDE OF INTERACTIONS BETWEEN THE GUT MICROBIOTA AND THE HOST. BASED ON RESEARCH PERFORMED IN HUMANS, IT IS NOW CLEAR THAT HEALTH INTESTINAL MICROBIOTA CAN PROVIDE “COLONIZATION RESISTANCE” AND PREVENT AGAINST OTHER ENTERIC PATHOGENS (I.E., BAD BACTERIA THAT CAUSE DIARRHEA AND WASTING, COLIC,AMONG OTHERS). ADDITIONALLY, SUCH HEALTHY MICROBIOTA CAN IMPROVE CRITICAL IMMUNE FUNCTIONS THAT PROTECT AGAINST OTHER PATHOGENS. INDEED, TRANSPLANTATION OF HEALTHY MICROBIOTA SPECIES HAS BECOME A RECOGNIZED THERAPEUTIC APPROACH IN HUMANS TO ADDRESS A MULTITUDE OF DISORDERS. WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF ANIMAL DISEASES, WE KNOW FAR LESS ABOUT  WHAT IS CONSIDERED A HEALTHY MICROBIOTA AND WHICH SPECIES OF BACTERIA ARE LIKELY TO BE CRITICAL FOR MAINTAINING THIS HEALTHY STATE. CONSEQUENTLY, THE OVERRIDING GOAL OF THIS WORK IS TO CHARACTERIZE THE FECAL MICROBIOTA IN TWO KEY SPECIES, ALPACAS AND RABBITS. WE WILL ASSESS THE IMPACT OF VARIOUS EXTERNAL AND INTERNAL FACTORS (ENVIRONMENT, PARASITE LOAD, ETC.) ON THE COMPOSITION OF THE MICROBIOTA USING ADVANCED GENOMICS AND MACHINE LEARNING APPROACHES. WE WILL DETERMINE IF SPECIFIC CHANGES ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SUSCEPTIBILITIES TO OTHER SECONDARY CONDITIONS (I.E., INFECTION, WEIGHT LOSS, ETC.). LASTLY, WE WILL WORK TO IDENTIFY METHODOLOGIES THAT CAN EFFECTIVELY ADDRESS CHANGES IN THE MICROBIOTA (I.E., PROBIOTICS, PREBIOTICS, FECAL TRANSPLANTATION) WITH THE GOAL OF RESTORING THE COMPOSITION OF GUT BACTERIA TO A HEALTHY STATE. ULTIMATELY, BY PERFORMING THESE STUDIES, WE ANTICIPATE GENERATING A SET OF TECHNOLOGIES AND RESOURCES THAT WILL HAVE BROAD APPLICABILITY TO IMPROVING THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF ALPACAS AND RABBITS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES. THROUGH THE INCLUSION OF BOTH DVM STUDENTS AND POST DVM HOUSE OFFICERS (RESIDENTS) IN THIS RESEARCH, WE ANTICIPATE OUR STUDIES WILL ALSO HAVE A POSITIVE IMPACT ON WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT.

2023 VETERINARY SUMMER RESEARCH SCHOLAR TRAINING ABSTRACT: THE OVER-ARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO TRAIN THE FUTURE WORKFORCE OF VETERINARIANS CONTRIBUTING TO THE MISSION OF THE USDA. THE SHORT-TERM GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENGAGE A VETERINARY STUDENT IN RESEARCH RELEVANT TO THE GOALS OF THE USDA AHDR-SEC1433 PROGRAM. THIS GOAL WILL BE ACHIEVED BY ENROLLING A FIRST- OR SECOND-YEAR VETERINARY STUDENT IN AN 11-WEEK LONG SUMMER SCHOLAR PROGRAM, UNDER THE MENTORSHIP OF A FACULTY WITH ACTIVE RESEARCH THAT FOCUSES ON AGRICULTURAL ANIMAL HEALTH, PUBLIC HEALTH, PREVENTION OF FOOD-BORNE ILLNESS, OR AGRICULTURAL HEALTH BY PREVENTING AND MITIGATING THE SPREAD OF AGRICULTURAL PESTS AND DISEASES. THIS HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE WILL BE COMPLEMENTED BY GROUP TRAINING SESSIONS AND WORKSHOPS FOCUSED ON RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT OF RESEARCH AND CAREER PATHS RELEVANT TO USDA. THE FY 2022 DISTRIBUTION OF FORMULA FUNDS INCLUDES $6,467 AND MATCHING FUNDS EQUAL TO $4,044, FOR A TOTAL OF $10,511. THESE MATCHING FUNDS WILL BE PROVIDED BY THE COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE, OFFICE FOR RESEARCH. THIS BUDGET WILL PROVIDE $6500 FOR THE SCHOLAR’S STIPEND (CONSISTENT WITH THE STIPEND OFFERED BY BI IN 2023), $2000 TO SUPPORT PRESENTATION OF A POSTER AT THE 2023 NA TIONAL VETERINARY SCHOLAR SYMPOSIUM (IN PUERTO RICO), AND $2,011 FOR SUPPLIES USED TO TRAIN THE SCHOLAR. THE IMMEDIATE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF THE SCHOLAR’S PRESENTATION OF HIS/HER RESEARCH RESULTS AT THE ANNUAL NATIONAL VETERINARY SCHOLARS SYMPOSIUM, WITH ALL ASSOCIATED COSTS COVERED BY THE COLLEGE.
