THIS TRAINING PROGRAM WILL HAVE FIVE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES. 1) TO UNDERSTAND AND FOLLOW RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT IN RESEARCH. 2) TO UNDERSTAND THE IMPORTANCE OF, AND BE FAMILIAR WITH STRATEGIES TO ENHANCE DATA REPRODUCIBILITY 3) TO INSTRUCT STUDENTS IN RESEARCH METHODOLOGY AND ACQUIRE TECHNICAL SKILLS REQUIRED TO CARRY OUT RESEARCH RELEVANT TO THE GOALS OF THE USDA AHDR-SEC1433 PROGRAM. 4) TO GAIN EXPERIENCE IN INTERPRETATION AND DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS. 5) TO EXPOSE STUDENTS TO RESEARCH CAREER AND TRAINING PATHWAYS RELEVANT TO USDA. PROGRAM FEASIBILITY, FTE ALLOCATION, AND RESOURCES. THIS TRAINING IS PRIMARILY DESIGNED TO PROVIDE HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE TO VETERINARY STUDENTS, IN RESEARCH RELEVANT TO USDA. THIS PROGRAM IS IN LINE WITH THE VETERINARY RESEARCH SUMMER PROGRAM (VRSP) RUN BY THE COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE AT WESTERN UNIVERSITY FOR OVER A DECADE. DURING THIS TIME, WE HAVE DEVELOPED AN INFRASTRUCTURE THAT WILL SUPPORT STUDENT RESEARCHERS CONDUCTING SHORT-TERM RESEARCH AT EVERY STAGE: FROM PAIRING STUDENTS WITH FACULTY MENTORS, TO PROVIDING IN-LAB TRAINING, TO SUPPORT WITH THE DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS. THE PROPOSED ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH TRAINING PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT A VETERINARY SCHOLAR INTERESTED IN RESEARCH IMPORTANT TO USDA AHDR-1433. AS SUCH, OUR INFRASTRUCTURE HAS THE HUMAN CAPITAL, EQUIPMENT, AND SUPPORT TO ENSURE THE SUCCESS OF THE STUDENT. THIS SUPPORT INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING FTE ALLOCATIONS: FACULTY MENTORSHIP (5%), TECHNICAL SUPPORT FROM A STAFF SCIENTIST (15% FTE), AND ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT (5%). EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING HAS A PROFOUND INFLUENCE OF STUDENTS’ CAREER PATHS. WE EXPECT THAT THIS DIRECT EXPOSURE TO ISSUES RELEVANT TO USDA WILL INSPIRE STUDENTS TO SEEK FURTHER TRAINING AND ENGAGEMENT IN THIS FIELD. FACULTY WITH ACTIVE RESEARCH RELEVANT TO USDA AHDR INCLUDE: DR. MAISIE DAWES: VIRAL INFECTIONS IN DISEASE RESISTANT AND DISEASE SUSCEPTIBLE HAPLOTYPE CHICKENS. DR. YVONNE DRECHSLER: GENOME-WIDE ANNOTATION OF CIS-REGULATORY ELEMENTS IN THE CHICKEN GENOME. DR BABAK FARAMARZI: EQUINE LAMENESS ASSOCIATED WITH PATHOLOGY OF THE HOOF DR SHEEMA MIR: MULTIPLEX DIAGNOSTIC ASSAYS FOR EMERGING PATHOGENS DR. BRIAN OAKLEY: BUILDING STRAIN LIBRARIES AS ALTERNATIVES TO ANTIBIOTIC GROWTH PROMOTERS IN BROILER CHICKENS. DR TXEMA PERALTA: INFLUENCE OF HOUSING ON THE MICROBIOME OF NURSING CALVES DR. JAMES REYNOLDS: FOOD ANIMAL WELFARE METHODS STUDENT ELIGIBILITY: STUDENTS MUST HAVECOMPLETED AT LEAST ONE YEAR OF A DVM CURRICULUM, BE CURRENTLY ENROLLED, AND IN GOOD ACADEMIC (GPA > 3.0) STANDING AT THEIR UNIVERSITY. STUDENTS MUST COMMIT TO ATTEND ALL TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES, INCLUDING THE NATIONAL VETERINARY SCHOLARS SYMPOSIUM (NVSS).  SELECTION OF FACULTY MENTORS: FACULTY MEMBERS WHO HOLD AN ADVANCED DEGREE IN RESEARCH (MS OR PHD), AND ARE ACTIVELY ENGAGED IN A RESEARCH PROJECT RELEVANT TO THE USDA AHDR, ARE ELIGIBLE TO MENTOR STUDENTS. MENTORS MUST HOLD AN APPOINTMENT IN CVM. CANDIDATE MENTORS SUBMIT A LETTER OF SUPPORT AS PART OF THE APPLICATION PROCESS, STATING THEIR ABILITY TO SUPPORT THE PROJECT FINANCIALLY, AND THEIR COMMITMENT TO PROVIDE DIRECT SUPERVISION OF STUDENTS. APPLICATION PROCESS AND CRITERIA FOR SELECTION: STUDENTS MUST SUBMIT ELECTRONICALLY TO THE CVM RESEARCH OFFICE, BY FEBRUARY 11, 2018: 1) A GRANT PROPOSAL FOR A PROJECT RELEVANT TO USDA. 2) AN APPLICATION FORM INCLUDING STATEMENT OF CAREER GOALS, LEARNING OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROGRAM, BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION, GPA, AND A COMMITMENT TO PARTICIPATE IN ALL GROUP TRAINING ACTIVITIES, AND PRESENT A POSTER AT NVSS; 3) A LETTER OF SUPPORT FROM THE MENTOR. SCHOLARS WILL BE SELECTED BASED ON A RUBRIC AVAILABLE TAKING INTO CONSIDERATION SCIENTIFIC MERIT OF THE PROJECT, RELEVANCE TO USDA AHDR, FEASIBILITY WITHIN THE TIMEFRAME OF THE PROGRAM, RELEVANCE TO THE CAREER GOALS OF THE STUDENT, STUDENT’S ACHIEVEMENT, MENTORSHIP, AND BREADTH OF LEARNING OBJECTIVES. EACH APPLICATION IS SCORED BY AT LEAST THREE INDEPENDENT REVIEWERS. REVIEWERS ARE SELECTED PREFERABLY AMONG THE RESEARCH ADVISORY COMMITTEE. OTHER RESEARCH FACULTY MAY VOLUNTEER, IF NEED, TO HAVE ENOUGH REVIEWERS WITHOUT CONFLICT OF INTEREST. SCORES ARE AVERAGED AND STANDARDIZED FOR REVIEWER’ SEVERITY OF SCORING, PRIOR TO RANKING. RESULTS ARE SHARED WITH THE SELECTED APPLICANT, SO THAT THE STUDENT CAN ADDRESS THE REVIEWER COMMENTS, AND UPDATE THEIR PROPOSAL TO INCORPORATE THE FEEDBACK RECEIVED. ADVERTISING: YEAR 1 AND YEAR 2 STUDENTSARE IMMEDIATELY INFORMED OF RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES DURING THEIR YEARLY ORIENTATION, WITH A P RESENTATION BY DR. GRIFFON. FACULTY ARE KEPT INFORMED DURING FACULTY MEETINGS, AND THROUGH AN ANNUAL FALL REPORT SUMMARIZING THE EVALUATIONS FROM STUDENTS AND MENTORS ENGAGED IN THE PROGRAM. SUMMER RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES ARE PRESENTED BY DR. GRIFFON DURING A LUNCH MEETING FOR STUDENTS AND MENTORS IN NOVEMBER, WITH A FOLLOW-UP IN JANUARY. A LIST OF POTENTIAL MENTORS CONDUCTING RESEARCH, INCLUDING THOSE RELEVANT TO USDA, IS DISTRIBUTED DURING THE PRESENTATIONS AND ELECTRONICALLY, AS WELL AS POSTED ONLINE. WHEN FUNDING IS CONFIRMED, STUDENTS AND FACULTY WILL ALSO BE INFORMED BY EMAIL, AND THE INFORMATION WILL BE UPDATED ON THE WESTERNU CVM RESEARCH WEBSITE: HTTP://WWW.WESTERN U.EDU/VETERINARY/VETERINARY-RESEARCH-OVERVIEW/VSRP-APPLICATION-AND-SPONSORS/. THE WESTERNU WEBSITE FEATURES A CURRENT LIST OF ELIGIBLE MENTORS, THE APPLICATION FORM, AND INSTRUCTIONS FOR ELECTRONIC (EMAIL) SUBMISSION OF APPLICATION MATERIALS, AND DESCRIPTION OF PAST PROGRAMS. REMINDERS ARE SENT PERIODICALLY TO STUDENTS AND FACULTY UNTIL THE DEADLINE FOR APPLICATIONS. STUDENTS AND FACULTY ARE INVITED TO CONTACT DR. GRIFFON DIRECTLY WITH INDIVIDUAL QUESTIONS. THE PROGRAM: THE LEARNING OBJECTIVES AND MEANS TO ACHIEVE THOSE ARE OUTLINED BELOW: 1. TO UNDERSTAND AND FOLLOW RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT IN RESEARCH: THIS OBJECTIVE WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH ONLINE COURSES, SEMINARS, GROUP DISCUSSIONS, TOURS OF LABORATORIES, LABORATORY DEMONSTRATIONS, HANDS-ON LABORATORY WORK, AND DIRECT INTERACTION WITH THE RESEARCH. 2. TO DESCRIBE AND PROVIDE A CRITICAL APPRAISAL OF THE METHODS USED IN THEIR PROJECT TO ENSURE SCIENTIFIC RIGOR AND REPRODUCIBILITY OF RESULTS: THIS OBJECTIVE WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH ONE-ON-ONE INTERACTIONS WITH THE MENTOR, SEMINARS, A SEMINAR ON SOURCES OF VARIATION IN IN-VIVO RESEARCH, WORKSHOPS FOCUSING ON SAMPLE SIZE, STATISTICAL METHODS AND DATA MANAGEMENT. 3. TO BE COMPETENT IN BASIC TECHNICAL SKILLS RELEVANT TO THEIR PROJECT: THIS OBJECTIVE WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN THE LABORATORIES, UNDER DIRECT SUPERVISION FROM MENTORS. 4. TO INTERPRET AND DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS OF THEIR RESEARCH PROJECT: STUDENTS WILL RECEIVE ASSISTANCE TO ANALYZE THEIR OWN DATA BY ATTENDING A STATISTICS WORKSHOP. STUDENTS WILL BE REQUIRED TO PASS AN ONLINE WRITING CLASS (BIOSCIENCES WRITERS INC., USA, PAID BY THE PROGRAM) AND PROVIDE A COPY OF THEIR CERTIFICATE. THIS CLASS WILL HELP THEM WRITE A CV, DRAFT A MANUSCRIPT, AND UNDERSTAND THE PATH TO PUBLISH SCIENTIFIC ARTICLES. ANOTHER SEMINAR WILL FOCUS ON BASIC PRINCIPLES OF POSTER PREPARATION. STUDENTS WILL THEN PREPARE THEIR POSTER UNDER GUIDANCE FROM THEIR FACULTY, FOR PRESENTATION AT THE NATIONAL VETERINARY SCHOLARS SYMPOSIUM (NVSS).  5. TO EXPOSE STUDENTS TO RESEARCH CAREER AND TRAINING PATHWAYS RELEVANT TO USDA: THIS OBJECTIVE WILL BE DELIVERED THROUGH A PRESENTATION BY AN EXTERNAL, KEYNOTE SPEAKER, AND A PANEL DISCUSSION LED BY ALUMNI ENGAGED IN NON-TRADITIONAL VETERINARY CAREERS. IN ADDITION TO THIS, 2 FIELD TRIPS, SOCIAL EVENTS BETWEEN SCHOLARS AND MENTORS AT WESTERN U AND NETWORKING AT THE NVSS WILL COMPLEMENT SEMINARS AND PANEL DISCUSSIONS. TARGET AUDIENCE THE SCHOLAR WILL BE RECRUITED AMONG OVER 220 STUDENTS ENGAGED IN YEAR 1 OR YEAR 2 OF THE DVM CURRICULUM AT WESTERN UNIVERSITY OF HEALTH SCIENCES, COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE DISSEMINATED AT SYMPOSIA, CONFERENCES, AND PUBLICATIONS, INCLUDING A POSTER PRESENTATION AT THE UPCOMING NATIONAL VETERINARY SCHOLARS SYMPOSIUM. THIS CONFERENCE GATHERS APPROXIMATELY 800 SCIENTISTS, INCLUDING 700 VETERINARY SCHOLARS PRESENTING POSTERS OF THEIR RESEARCH. THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE DATA THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE SUBMISSION OF GRANTS AND PUBLICATIONS BY THE MENTOR. THE STUDENT WILL ALSO SHARE FINDINGS WITH PEERS DURING THE “DATA BITES” ORGANIZED BY THE COLLEGE EACH FALL TO INSPIRE STUDENTS TO ENGAGE IN THE NEXT SUMMER RESEARCH PROGRAM. STUDENTS WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO PRESENT THE RESULTS OF THIS RESEARCH AT THE WESTERN UNIVERSITY STUDENT TECHNOLOGY AND RESEARCH SYMPOSIUM, ANNUAL COLLEGE RESEARCH DAY, AND/OR THE PACIFIC VETERINARY CONFERENCE. PRODUCTS THE MAIN ACTIVITIES OF THIS PROJECT THAT ARE RELEVANT TO USDA AHDR WILL BE: • THE DIRECT MENTORSHIP OF A VETERINARY STUDENT RESEARCH TRAINEE IN AN APPROVED USDA AHDR PROJECT. • CONDUCTING AND ANALYZING EXPERIMENTS INTENDED TO ADDRESS AHDR TOPICS. THE MAIN EVENTS FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE: • 11-WEEKS OF FULL-TIME RESEARCH ENGAGEMENT IN A PROJECT RELEVANT TO USDA AHDR. • WEEKLY SEMINARS ON RESEARCH DESIGN, GRANT WRITING, ETHICS IN RESEARCH, LABORATORY SAFETY, AND CAREER OPPORTUNITIES RELEVANT TO USDA. • WORKSHOPS ON STATISTICS AND SCIENTIFIC WRITING. • A POSTER PRESENTATION AT THE NATIONAL VETERINARY SCHOLARS SYMPOSIUM, WHERE STUDENTS WILL DISCUSS THEIR USDA AHDR PROJECT. EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES ARE EXPECTED: SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES: • EXPOSURE OF A VETERINARY STUDENT TO USDA MISSION AND CAREER OPPORTUNITIES • INCREASED PARTICIPATION OF VETERINARY STUDENTS IN OUR SUMMER RESEARCH PROGRAM WITH RESEARCH FOCUSED ON AHDR MISSION. • NEW KNOWLEDGE RELEVANT TO USDA WILL BE GENERATED. • RESULTS WILL BE PRESENTED AT THE NATIONAL VETERINARY SCHOLARS SYMPOSIUM. LONG-TERM OUTCOMES: • RESULTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO PROGRAM OF A FACULTY WITH ACTIVE RESEARCH RELEVANT TO USDA. • STRENGTHEN THE CONTRIBUTION OF VETERINARIANS IN THE FUTURE BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH WORKFORCE RELEVANT TO USDA. KEYWORDS VETERINARY RESEARCH TRAINING ~ ANIMAL DISEASE RESEARCH

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY OVERVIEW K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION (KSRE) IS A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF EDUCATORS SHARING UNBIASED, RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION AND EXPERTISE ON ISSUES IMPORTANT TO KANSANS. THE KSRE NETWORK INCLUDES OFFICES IN ALL 105 COUNTIES, ALONG WITH FOUR REGIONAL EXTENSION OFFICES, FIVE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH CENTERS DISTRIBUTED THROUGHOUT THE STATE TO ENCOMPASS VARIABILITY IN CLIMATE AND SOILS, FOUR SATELLITE UNITS, FOUR AGRONOMY EXPERIMENT FIELDS AND FOUR HORTICULTURE CENTERS AND EXPERIMENT FIELDS. IN ADDITION, KSRE FUNDS RESEARCH PROJECTS IN 20 DEPARTMENTS ACROSS FIVE COLLEGES. A UNIQUE FEATURE WITHIN THE K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ORGANIZATION IS THE CLOSE ALIGNMENT OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION. IN 1996, K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WAS FORMED BY ALIGNING THE KANSAS AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (KAES) AND THE KANSAS COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE. THE STRATEGIC INTENT OF THIS ALIGNMENT WAS TO ACHIEVE GREATER EFFICIENCY AND SYNERGY BETWEEN DISCOVERY AND OUTREACH EFFORTS. ONE ANCILLARY BENEFIT OF THIS ALIGNMENT IS THAT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH WILL LEAD TO RAPID EXTENSION PROGRAMMING AND APPLICATION IN THE FIELD. THIS ALIGNMENT ALSO ALLOWS MORE FLUID COMPLIANCE WITH MULTI-STATE AND INTEGRATED COMPONENTS OF AREERA. K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION IS FOCUSING ITS EFFORTS ON FIVE GRAND CHALLENGES (CRITICAL ISSUES) THAT DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY AFFECT ALL KANSANS: GLOBAL FOOD SYSTEMS, WATER AND NATURAL RESOURCES, HEALTH, DEVELOPING TOMORROW'S LEADERS, AND COMMUNITY VITALITY. THESE GRAND CHALLENGES WERE DETERMINED THROUGH A SERIES OF MEETINGS WITH STAKEHOLDERS AND DEFINE AREAS OF EMPHASIS FOR AGENTS, SPECIALISTS, AND RESEARCHERS. EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS AT THE LOCAL, REGIONAL AND STATE LEVEL WORK TO DEVELOP REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE SIGNATURE PROGRAMS ALONG WITH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR ITS MEMBERS THROUGH 11 PROGRAM FOCUS TEAMS – ADULT DEVELOPMENT AND AGING; COMMUNITY VITALITY; CROP PRODUCTION; FAMILY AND CHILD DEVELOPMENT; FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; FARM MANAGEMENT; HORTICULTURE; LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION; NATURAL RESOURCES; NUTRITION, FOOD SAFETY AND HEALTH; AND YOUTH DEVELOPMENT. IN ADDITION, TWO TRANSDISCIPLINARY TEAMS WERE CREATED TO ADDRESS COMPLEX ISSUES TO KANSANS - LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS AND STRESS AND RESILIENCY. THE WORK OF THESE TEAMS FALLS WITHIN THE OVERALL UMBRELLA OF THE FIVE GRAND CHALLENGES. K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CANNOT SOLVE THESE CHALLENGES ALONE. KSRE'S STATEWIDE PRESENCE LENDS ITSELF TO COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS WITH ORGANIZATIONS, PRIVATE BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY, LOCAL GROUPS, STATE AND FEDERAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND COLLEAGUES IN OTHER STATES. QUALITY FACULTY DRAW BUSINESSES AND FUNDING TO K-STATE AND TO KANSAS INCLUDING: - K-STATE IS THE ONLY UNIVERSITY IN THE WORLD WITH ACCESS TO A FULL CONTINUUM OF BIOSECURITY LABORATORIES LOCATED ON OR ADJACENT TO CAMPUS. THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE WILL PROVIDE PLANT DISEASE DIAGNOSTICS, RESEARCH, SURVEILLANCE, AND TRAINING IN DISEASE VECTOR BIOLOGY. THE LABORATORIES WILL OFFER EMERGENCY RAPID TESTING AND MANUFACTURING TO PROTECT THE NATION'S ANIMAL HEALTH AND FOOD SUPPLY DURING A CRISIS. - KANSAS PRIDE IS DEDICATED TO SERVING COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE TO ENCOURAGE AND ASSIST LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND VOLUNTEERS IN MAKING THEIR COMMUNITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE AND WORK. THE KANSAS PRIDE PROGRAM IS A PARTNERSHIP OF K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION, THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE, KANSAS MASONS AND KANSAS PRIDE, INC. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, LOCAL COMMUNITIES IDENTIFY WHAT THEY WOULD LIKE TO PRESERVE, CREATE, OR IMPROVE FOR THEIR FUTURE. THEN, WORKING WITH THE RESOURCES OF K-STATE RESEARCH <(>&<)> EXTENSION AND THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE, COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS PULL TOGETHER TO CREATE THEIR IDEAL COMMUNITY FUTURE.  - EXTENSION’S RESEARCH CENTERS, EXPERIMENT FIELDS AND HIGHLY SKILLED SCIENTISTS AND STAFF, COMBINED WITH THE CLIMATE AND SOIL VARIABILITY ACROSS THE STATE, PROVIDE UNIQUE OPPORTUNITIES FOR AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND CORPORATE AND PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS. - FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES IS A PARTNER OF THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT FOR AGING AND DISABILITY SERVICES TO PROVIDE HEALTH INSURANCE EDUCATION TO MEDICARE ELIGIBLE KANSANS. APPROXIMATELY 1/3 OF THE CONTACTS OF THOSE SERVED ARE VULNERABLE BENEFICIARIES WITH INCOMES BELOW 150% OF THE POVERTY LEVEL. - KANSAS 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT WAS AWARDED A CONTRACT BY THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION FOR $4.2 MILLION OVER THE NEXT THREE SUMMERS TO PROVIDE HANDS-ON, PROJECT-BASED 4-H SUMMER PROGRAMMING OPPORTUNITIES TO ADDRESS COVID-19-RELATED LEARNING LOSS IN COUNTIES ACROSS THE STATE. BUILDING UPON THE LONG RECORD OF SUCCESSFUL PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND LEVERAGING THE STATE'S LARGEST YOUTH DEVELOPMENT NETWORK REACHING ALL 105 COUNTIES, KANSAS 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT WILL USE SUMMER ENRICHMENT PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS THE ACADEMIC, SOCIAL, EMOTIONAL AND MENTAL HEALTH NEEDS OF YOUTH AS A PART OF THE AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN — ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOL EMERGENCY RELIEF PLAN. - K-STATE - IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FOUR OTHER UNIVERSITIES AND SEVERAL INDUSTRY PARTNERS HAVE JOINED EFFORTS TO CREATE THE IRRIGATION I NNOVATION CONSORTIUM, A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH EFFORT TO ACCELERATE THE DEVELOPMENT AND ADOPTION OF EFFICIENT IRRIGATION TECHNOLOGIES AND PRACTICES. - K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WILL ADDRESS THE HEALTH OF KANSANS THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATIONAL COOPERATIVE EXTENSION’S FRAMEWORK FOR HEALTH EQUITY AND WELL-BEING WHICH INCLUDES A FOCUS ON HEALTH EQUITY, SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND COALITIONS AND COMMUNITY HEALTH ASSETS. THE DEMOGRAPHICS OF KANSAS CONTINUE TO CHANGE. KSRE IS REACHING OUT TO BOTH UNDERSERVED AND TRADITIONAL AUDIENCES THROUGH NEW VENUES. ANIMAL HEALTH ABSTRACT RESEARCHERS AT IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY ARE APPLYING THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE REDUCTION CAPACITY FUNDING TO ADDRESS DISEASE MANAGEMENT IN THE TWO ANIMAL INDUSTRIES IN THE STATE – PIGS AND CHICKENS. IOWA ACCOUNTS FOR APPROXIMATELY ONE THIRD OF THE NATION’S PIG INVENTORY AND MARKETS APPROXIMATELY 50 MILLION PIGS PER YEAR, MAKING IT THE NUMBER ONE PIG PRODUCING STATE IN THE U.S. HOWEVER, THE PIGS RAISED IN IOWA ARE CONTINUOUSLY CHALLENGED BY INFECTIOUS DISEASES ASSOCIATED WITH VERY COMMON ENDEMIC VIRAL AND BACTERIAL PATHOGENS. TO ADDRESS THIS, BETTER MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES INCLUDING PREVENTION, TREATMENT OR CURE VIA NUTRITIONAL MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO MINIMIZE THE IMPACT OF DISEASE IN GROWING PIGS IS A MAJOR RESEARCH FOCUS. WORK IS UNDERWAY TO UNDERSTAND THE NUTRITIONAL NEEDS OF PIGS PRONE TO DISEASE PRESSURES WITHIN IOWA TO ENABLE GREATER GROWTH PERFORMANCE AND WELLBEING. FURTHER, THE WORK WILL UTILIZE PIGS FROM POOR HEALTH (DISEASE CHALLENGED), WHICH ARE OFTENOVERLOOKED IN RESEARCH, TO STUDY NUTRITIONAL MANAGEMENT AND THE LONGITUDINAL IMPACTS OF DISEASE IN WEAN-TO-FINISH PIGS. THE RATIONALE IS THAT PIGS RAISED IN IOWA ARE CONTINUOUSLY CHALLENGED BY INFECTIOUS DISEASES ASSOCIATED WITH VERY COMMON ENDEMIC PATHOGENS. TWO OBJECTIVES WILL BE COMPLETED. THE FIRST WILL BE TO EVALUATE NUTRITIONAL STRATEGIES TO ALLEVIATE ENTERIC AND RESPIRATORY HEALTH CHALLENGES IN COMMERCIAL NURSERY-GROWER PIGS. SECOND, THE IMPACT OF ENTERIC ROTAVIRUS RELATED DISEASE IN NEWLY WEANED PIGS ON NUTRIENT UTILIZATION WILL BE STUDIES. PIGS WILL BE SOURCED FROM ROTAVIRUS A AND C POSITIVE SOW FARMS AND NURSERY FLOWS, AND ALSO FROM FLOWS THAT ARE PRONE TO PATHOGENIC E. COLI, BUT ARE PRRS NEGATIVE. THESE HEALTH COMPROMISED PIGS REPRESENT THE "TYPICAL" NURSERY PIG RAISED IN IOWA TO SPECIFICALLY EXAMINE THE IMPACT OF ROTAVIRUS A AND C ON NURSERY PIGS. TOGETHER, THESE TWO CONTROLLED ROTAVIRUS STUDIES WILL IDENTIFY THE IMPACT ROTAVIRUS A AND C HAS ON NURSERY PIG DIGESTIBILITY, METABOLISM, AND GROWTH. THESE DATA CAN BE USED TO IDENTIFY WAYS TO BETTER FEED AND MANAGE NURSERY PIGS INFECTED WITH ROTAVIRUS.  THE US POULTRY INDUSTRY IS A MULTIBILLION-DOLLAR INDUSTRY THAT ANNUALLY LOSES UP TO 15% OF ITS POTENTIAL INCOME DUE TO DISEASE. THESE ECONOMIC LOSSES ARE FROM MANY SOURCES, INCLUDING ANIMAL MORTALITY, HEALTH CARE COSTS, PRODUCT CONDEMNATION AND LOWER EFFICIENCY OF PRODUCTION. ADDITIONALLY, SOME PATHOGENS THAT CAUSE DISEASE IN POULTRY CAN ALSO CAUSE HUMAN HEALTH RISKS FROM CONSUMPTION OF IMPROPERLY PREPARED, CONTAMINATED EGGS AND MEAT. IN 2015, DEVASTATING ECONOMIC AND ANIMAL HEALTH CONSEQUENCES OF AVIAN DISEASE WAS BROUGHT TO THE FOREFRONT WITH THE OUTBREAK OF HIGH PATH AVIAN INFLUENZA IN THE US MIDWEST. IN 2019, VELOGENIC NEWCASTLE DISEASE OUTBREAKS OCCURRED IN BACKYARD AND COMMERCIAL FLOCKS IN THE US. THEREFORE, CONTROL OF DISEASE IN POULTRY IS URGENTLY NEEDED TO ENHANCE ANIMAL HEALTH AND WELFARE, ENSURE ECONOMIC VIABILITY OF THE U.S. POULTRY INDUSTRY, AND PROTECT HUMAN HEALTH AND FOOD SAFETY. UNDERSTANDING THE IDENTITY, VARIATION AND FUNCTIONAL ASSOCIATIONS OF PROTEINS, GENES AND PATHWAYS THAT CONTROL RESPONSE TO POULTRY PATHOGENS WILL HELP PROVIDE THE NECESSARY INFORMATION FOR GENETIC IMPROVEMENT OF DISEASE RESISTANCE IN POULTRY VIA CLASSICAL GENETIC SELECTION TECHNIQUES, WHOLE-GENOME SELECTION, AND NATURAL REGULATORS OF THE IMMUNE SYSTEM. ISU RESEARCHERS ARE APPLYING SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE BY USING CONTEMPORARY TECHNOLOGIES TO STUDY THE HOST-PATHOGEN INTERACTION; THE WORK WILL MAINTAIN AND STUDY NOVEL LINES OF CHICKENS TO ENHANCE THE ABILITY TO IDENTIFY HOW CERTAIN BIRDS ARE BETTER AT RESISTING DISEASE. THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO ENHANCE HOST GENETIC RESISTANCE TO POULTRY PATHOGENS. ENHANCED HOST RESISTANCE WILL REDUCE THE NEED FOR ANTIBIOTIC USE AND WILL LOWER THE PATHOGEN BURDEN IN THE LIVE BIRD AND THEREBY IMPROVE ANIMAL HEALTH, PRODUCTION EFFICIENCY, PRE-HARVEST FOOD SAFETY AND HUMAN HEALTH. THE MAJOR GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO MAINTAIN AND SHARE UNIQUE BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES FOR ANIMAL HEALTH RESEARCH, AND TO ADVANCE SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE OF THE GENETIC CONTROL OF IMMUNITY AND RESISTANCE TO PATHOGENS IN CHICKENS BY CHARACTERIZING NOVEL CHICKEN LINES. THE LONG-TERM AIM IS TO REDUCE THE OCCURRENCE AND NEGATIVE IMPACT OF DISEASES ON THE POULTRY INDUSTRY THROUGH SCIENCE-INFORMED CONTROL STRATEGIES, ESPECIALLY THOSE RELATED TO GENETICS. ONE AIM WILL BE TO MAINTAIN AND CHARACTERIZE THE BREEDING COLONY OF IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY CHICKEN GENETIC LINES OF UNIQUE IMMUNOLOGICAL PHENOTYPES AND GENETIC ARCHITECTURE. THE WORK WILL ALSO DETERMINE THE TRANSCRIPTOME RESPONSE OF SINGLE CELLS AND HETEROGENEOUS IMMUNE TISSUES OF CHICKENS OF DIVERSE GENETIC LINES TO IMPORTANT POULTRY PATHOGENS. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK IS RELEVANT TO THE POULTRY INDUSTRY AND WILL HAVE POSITIVE AND LASTING IMPACTS ON THE PRODUCTION OF POULTRY, FOOD SECURITY AND FOOD SAFETY BY PROVIDING NOVEL, ENVIRONMENTALLY-FRIENDLY, NON-ANTIBIOTIC, NON-GMO BASED STRATEGIESTO KNOWLEDGEABLY USE THE EXISTING BIODIVERSITY IN CHICKENS TO REDUCE MICROBIAL BURDENS IN THE LIVE BIRDS AND IN POULTRY MEAT AND EGGS.  ISU RESEARCHERS DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS OF THEIR WORK THROUGH PROFESSIONAL PRESENTATIONS, PUBLICATIONS IN PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS, EX TENSION PROGRAMS, WORKSHOPS AND PUBLICATIONS, PRESENTATIONS TO COMMODITY GROUPS AND MEMBERS, MEETINGS WITH FARMERS AND PRODUCERS, AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR UNDERGRADUATE, GRADUATE AND PROFESSIONAL STUDENTS. THESE AUDIENCES ARE PROVIDED WITH CURRENT INFORMATION FROM THE RESEARCH PROJECTS IN CONTEXT SO THAT IT CAN BE READILY APPLIED AND USED. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE WORK IS TO ENSURE THE HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF ANIMALS THROUGHOUT THE ECOSYSTEM, AND TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF DISEASES. THIS WORK IS OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE AS IT UNDERLIES FOOD SAFETY AND ACCESS, ECONOMIC VIABILITY, AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY, AND HUMAN HEALTH AND WELLNESS.

ANIMAL HEALTH FUNDS WILL SUPPORT TWO RESEARCH PROJECTS.  THE FIRST PROJECT IS AIMED AT IMPROVING DIAGNOSIS AND EPIDEMIOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE OF BOVINE RESPIRATORY DISEASE IN INDIANA. BOVINE RESPIRATORY DISEASE (BRD) IS THE GROUP OF DISEASES HAVING THE HIGHEST ECONOMIC IMPACT ON BEEF CATTLE IN NORTH AMERICA. IT IS THE MOST COMMON CAUSE OF MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY IN U.S. CATTLE FEEDLOTS AND IS RESPONSIBLE FOR APPROXIMATELY 50% OF ALL FEEDLOT DEATHS, ADDING TO THE COST OF TREATING BRD. TOTAL FINANCIAL LOSSES CAUSED BY BRD MOUNT TO $2 - 3 BILLION PER YEAR. BRD IS CAUSED BY DIFFERENT PATHOGENS INCLUDING VIRUSES AND BACTERIA. ALTHOUGH PATHOLOGIC CHANGES ARE SOMEWHAT DISTINCT AMONG DIFFERENT INFECTIOUS AGENTS, THERE IS ENOUGH OVERLAP THAT ANCILLARY TESTS ARE REQUIRED FOR DEFINITIVE DIAGNOSIS. MOREOVER, DIAGNOSTIC TESTS BASED ON NUCLEIC ACID DETECTION ARE MORE SENSITIVE AND PROVIDE A FASTER TURNAROUND. THE CHOICE OF DIAGNOSTIC METHODS IS BASED ON DIFFERENT PARAMETERS INCLUDING COST, SENSITIVITY,SPECIFICITY AND TEST COMPLEXITY. WITH THE GOAL OF PROVIDING THE BEST APPROACH TO DIAGNOSE BRD, THE SELECTION OF TESTS CHANGES OVER TIME. IN THIS STUDY, TRENDS IN BRD IN INDIANA HERDS WILL BE DETERMINED USING STATISTICAL ANALYSIS AND BASED ON RESULTS OBTAINED WITH PATHOLOGICAL AND MOLECULAR DIAGNOSTIC TESTS AVAILABLE AT THE ANIMAL DISEASE DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORY. THE SPECIFIC AIMS OF THIS RESEARCH INCLUDE: (1) IDENTIFY PATHOGENS AFFECTING THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM OF DOMESTIC CATTLE; (2) DETERMINE THE TEMPORAL TREND IN DISTRIBUTION OF BOVINE RESPIRATORY PATHOGENS; AND (3) CORRELATE CLINICAL AND PATHOLOGIC FINDINGS WITH THE RESULTS OF MICROBIOLOGY, VIROLOGY, AND MOLECULAR TESTING. THIS WORK WILL INCREASE OUR KNOWLEDGE OF CURRENT BOVINE RESPIRATORY INFECTIOUS AGENTS IN INDIANA HERDS WHICH IS CRITICAL TO PREVENTION OF INFECTIONS WITH PROPHYLACTIC AND MANAGEMENT MEASURES; INCREASE DIAGNOSTIC SUCCESS RATE DUE TO TEST SELECTION OPTIMIZATION; AND ENABLE DETECTION OF EMERGING AND RE-EMERGING PATHOGENS THAT CAUSE BRD. THE AUDIENCE INCLUDES FOOD ANIMAL VETERINARIANS AND BEEF AND DAIRY CATTLE FARMERS. IN ADDITION, PROFESSIONAL VETERINARY AND GRADUATE STUDENTS WILL BENEFIT FROM SUCH INFORMATION TO GET THEM WELL-PREPARED IN THEIR CAREER. THE SECOND PROJECT FOCUSES ON EQUINE PROTOZOAL MYELOENCEPHALITIS (EPM), A NEUROLOGIC DISEASE CAUSED BY SARCOCYSTIS NEURONA THAT RESULTS IN HUGE ECONOMIC LOSSES TO THE EQUINE INDUSTRY. S. NEURONA INFECTS BETWEEN 15 AND 89% OF HORSES, BUT CLINICAL DISEASE DEVELOPS IN LESS THAN 1% OF THESE HORSES. THE PROGRESSION OF THIS NEUROLOGICAL DISEASE IS UNPREDICTABLE AND OFTEN TIMES REQUIRES PROLONGED TREATMENT WITH ANTIPROTOZOAL DRUGS THAT ARE EXPENSIVE. UNFORTUNATELY, ONLY 60-70% OF THE HORSES APPEAR TO RESPOND TO TREATMENT AND 10-20% OF THE HORSES EXPERIENCE RELAPSE OF CLINICAL SIGNS UPON CESSATION OF TREATMENT. SARCOCYSTIS NEURONA ESTABLISHES INFECTION WITHIN THE CELLS OF THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT UNDERSTANDING HOW S. NEURONA SURVIVES WITHIN, AND INTERACTS WITH THE HOST CELL WILL PROVIDE INSIGHTS INTO MOLECULAR MECHANISMS THAT COULD BE TARGETED TO PREVENT RELAPSE FROM OCCURRING. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IDENTIFY KEY PARASITE PROTEINS THAT SUPPORT ITS INTRACELLULAR LIFESTYLE, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF MOLECULAR GENETICS TOOLS THAT WILL ENABLE US TO DECIPHER THE BIOLOGICAL ROLE OF THESE PROTEINS. THESE EFFORTS WILL LEAD TO IDENTIFICATION OF PROTEINS (SECRETORY AND MEMBRANE) THAT ARE FUNCTIONAL DURING INTRACELLULAR DEVELOPMENT OF S. NEURONA, AND POTENTIAL TARGETS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF NOVEL DRUGS TO TREAT THESE INFECTIONS. THE IMMEDIATE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR THIS WORK WILL BE OTHER SCIENTISTS IN ACADEMIC AND ANIMAL HEALTH COMPA NIES. THE OUTCOME IS THE IDENTIFICATION OF PROTEINS THAT ARE CRITICAL FOR THE INTRACELLULAR SURVIVAL AND FUNCTION OF THE PARASITES. THE RESULTS OF THE RESEARCH WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS AT NATIONAL MEETINGS.

ABSTRACT A STRONG AND PROSPEROUS AGRICULTURAL SECTOR IS ESSENTIAL TO THE WELL-BEING OF THE U.S. ECONOMY. AMERICA’S FARMERS AND RANCHERS ENSURE A RELIABLE FOOD SUPPLY, SUPPORT JOB GROWTH, AND PROMOTE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT. TO MAINTAIN AN EQUITABLE AND COMPETITIVE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR, THE USDA INITIATED THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE (AHD) RESEARCH CAPACITY PROGRAM. ACCORDING TO THE USDA THE AHD OPPORTUNITY IS A NATIONAL PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING TO STATE AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENTAL STATIONS AND AVMA ACCREDITED US COLLEGES OR VETERINARY SCHOOLS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH PROJECTS ADDRESSING HEALTH AND DISEASE OF AGRICULTURAL ANIMALS. THE AHD RESEARCH PROGRAM ALIGNS WITH THE STRATEGIC GOALS OF 1. ENSURING AMERICA’S AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM IS EQUITABLE, RESILIENT, AND PROSPEROUS; 2. PROVIDING ALL AMERICANS SAFE, NUTRITIOUS FOOD; AND 3. PROTECTING PLANT AND ANIMAL HEALTH BY MINIMIZING MAJOR DISEASES, PESTS, AND WILDLIFE CONFLICTS. TO THESE ENDS, THE USDA EMBARKS ON COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH TO DEVELOP PEST-RESISTANT STRAINS OF CROPS AND NEW ANIMAL-DISEASE VACCINES, EXPEDITES THE APPROVAL OF NEW TREATMENTS, AND DEVELOPS STRATEGIES TO PREVENT AND MITIGATE DAMAGE RELATED TO CONFLICTS WITH WILDLIFE. COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE AND BIOMEDICAL SCIENCES PROPOSES TO ADVANCE THE OBJECTIVES OF THE AHD FUNDS BY ADDRESSING REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH AND DISEASE PREVENTION, DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT BY FUNDING A WIDE ARRAY OF RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT LEVERAGE THE CONSIDERABLE RESOURCES, EXPERTISE AND EXPERIENCE OF OUR RESEARCH TEAMS. WE EMPLOY CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH TECHNOLOGY AND METHODS, INCLUDING NOVEL IMMUNOMODULATORY AGENTS, RNA FLOW CYTOMETRY, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, QUANTITATIVE BIOSECURITY ASSESSMENT TOOLS, CLASSICAL TRANSMISSION AND CELL CULTURE STUDIES AND IMMUNOLOGICAL ASSAYS, AND STATE-OF-THE-ART IN VITRO ORGANOID CULTURES. ANIMAL DISEASE PROJECTS PLANNED, INITIATED AND ONGOING INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO 1. IMPACT OF INTRANASAL IMMUNOTHERAPY ON LOCAL IMMUNE AND MICROBIOME RESPONSES IN PRE-WEANING DAIRY CALVES 2. EMPLOYING RNA FLOW CYTOMETRY TO TRACK VIRUS REPLICATION AND HOST IMMUNE RESPONSES LONGITUDINALLY IN A SHEEP MODEL OF BLUETONGUE VIRUS INFECTION 3. VIRULENCE DETERMINANTS AND ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE AMONG SALMONELLA ENTERICA SEROVAR TYPHIMURIUM ISOLATED FROM LIVESTOCK AND POULTRY 4. SUPER SPREADING INSECT VIRUSES FOR THE CONTROL OF VECTOR-BORNE DISEASES 5. A QUANTITATIVE ASSESSMENT TOOL TO ENHANCE AGRICULTURAL BIOSECURITY IN CONVENTIONAL AND ORGANIC COL ORADO DAIRY FARMS: GAPS AND RECOMMENDATIONS 6. EVALUATION OF SARS-2 INFECTION AND TRANSMISSION IN DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK ANIMAL REPRODUCTION STUDIES PLANNED, INITIATED AND ONGOING INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO 1. DETERMINING THE BRAIN CONTRIBUTION TO THE DELAYED OVU LATION IN OBESE EWES 2. OVIDUCTAL ORGANOID EXTRACELLULAR VESICLES AS INDUCERS OF ENHANCED STRESS TOLERANCE IN BOVINE EMBRYOS 3. OBESITY-LINKED CELLULAR ALTERATIONS IN THE EQUINE OVARIAN FOLLICLE CAN BE IMPROVED BY DIET SUPPLEMENTS

UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS FY23 ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE PROJECT ABSTRACT  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  ACTIVITIES WILL EXPLORE THE COMPARATIVE EFFICACY IN STIMULATING EQUINE PERIOSTEAL ENDOCHONDRAL OSSIFICATION, AND WILL DETERMINE WHETHER THESE SIGNALING PATHWAYS INTERACT IN STIMULATING PERIOSTEAL BONE FORMATION. MAREK’S DISEASE IS A VIRAL CAUSE OF IMMUNOSUPPRESSION AND LYMPHOMA (CANCER) OF CHICKENS. TODAY, MD REMAINS A CONSTANT WORRY TO THE POULTRY INDUSTRY DESPITE VACCINATION AND OTHER CONTROL MEASURES. ALTHOUGH CURRENT MD VACCINES PREVENT OVERT DISEASE, THEY ARE NOT USEFUL FOR DISEASE ERADICATION; VACCINE AND FIELD VIRUS PROPAGATE AND PERSIST WITHIN VACCINATED CHICKENS AND ARE COMMONLY TRANSMITTED BY RESIDUAL DANDER TO INFECT NEW GROUPS OF CHICKENS. RESEARCH ALTERNATE ENGINEERING TECHNIQUES TO ADDRESS THE MD VIRUS. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  OUR RESEARCH SEEKS TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF CARTILAGE HOMEOSTASIS AND ADAPTATION AND THE ADMINISTRATION OF ANTI-INFLAMMATORY DRUGS SPECIFICALLY TO EQUINE ATHLETES DURING TRAINING. OUTCOMES WILL DEVELOP VALUABLE INFORMATION ON THE CELLULAR MECHANISMS THAT STIMULATE BONE FORMATION AND SUPPORT CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT OF CLINICAL APPLICATIONS FOR FRACTURE REPAIR. GENERATE VACCINES TO DEVELOP REGULATED CONTROL OF VIRUS REPLICATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  INTENDED TARGET AUDIENCES WILL INCLUDE THE POULTRY INDUSTRY, MUSCULOSKELETAL BIOLOGY RESEARCHERS, PRACTITIONERS AND SURGEONS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS DOES NOT EXPECT ANY SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

PROGRAM ABSTRACT AGRICULTURE IS THE GREATEST CONTRIBUTION TO IDAHO’S ECONOMY WITH 25,000 FARMS AND RANCHES, AND PRODUCTION OF 185 COMMODITIES. AGRICULTURAL CASH RECEIPTS ARE CLOSE TO $7.1 BILLION AND AGRIBUSINESS CONTRIBUTES $20.6 BILLION IN SALES, 128,200 IDAHO JOBS, AND $3.7 BILLION IN WAGES. LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION DRIVEN BY DAIRY AND BEEF REPRESENT NEARLY 60% OF THE AGRICULTURAL ECONOMY IN IDAHO. THE FFY 2023 ANIMAL HEATH AND DISEASE (AHD) CAPACITY FUNDING SUPPORTS CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SAFETY NEEDS AT ANIMAL RESEARCH FACILITIES BOTH ON- AND OFF-CAMPUS AS WELL AS PERSONNEL, MATERIALS, AND SUPPLIES FOR SCIENTISTS PERFORMING ACTIVITIES TIED TO THOSE FACILITIES. THESE ACTIVITIES ARE AIDED BY HATCH, MULTISTATE HATCH, AND COMPETITIVE GRANTS FOR RESEARCH ON SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION, LACTATION, GROWTH, REPRODUCTION, GENOMICS, MASTITIS, EFFECTS OF SMOKE AND HEAT STRESS, AND NUTRITION. THE IDAHO AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION, UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO CONTINUES TO EXPAND CAPACITY IN THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH ARENA WITH A FOCUS ON DAIRY CATTLE, BEEF CATTLE, AND SHEEP.

THE COLLEGE OF TROPICAL AGRICULTURE AND HUMAN RESOURCES (CTAHR) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAIʻI AT MANOA (UHM) OVERSEES A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF 22 RESEARCH AND EXTENSION STATIONS ON FIVE HAWAIIAN ISLANDS. CTAHR, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS THE STATE, IS ACTIVELY SEARCHING FOR OPPORTUNITIES TO INCREASE LOCAL FOOD PRODUCTION IN A SUSTAINABLE WAY WHILE ALSO MAKING IT MORE PROFITABLE. WHILE THERE ARE OPPORTUNITIES, THERE ARE ALSO SUBSTANTIAL CONSTRAINTS. THE COSTS OF LAND, LABOR, AND ENERGY EXCEED THOSE FOUND IN MOST OTHER STATES. AGROCHEMICALS AND ANIMAL FEED ARE MOSTLY IMPORTED AND EXPORTING PRODUCTS TO DISTANT MARKETS REDUCES THE FARMERS’ COMPETITIVE ABILITY. THE HIGH COSTS OF ENERGY, LACK OF SKILLED LABOR, AND REDUCED INTEREST IN FARMING ARE MAJOR CHALLENGES. CTAHR UNDERSTANDS THESE CHALLENGES AND ENGAGES IN A BROAD SPECTRUM OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING: MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES THAT CONSTANTLY THREATEN THE "GATEWAY" STATE OF HAWAI’I; IMPROVED CULTIVATION AND PROCESSING OF SPECIALTY CROPS; AGRICULTURAL ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY; DEVELOPMENT OF VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS; INCREASING FOREST PRODUCTIVITY; PROTECTION OF FORESTS, WATERSHEDS AND COASTAL R ESOURCES; PLANT AND ANIMAL BREEDING AND GENETIC IMPROVEMENT; BIOFUEL DEVELOPMENT TO ADDRESS SOARING ENERGY COSTS AND FOSSIL FUEL DEPLETION; PLANT STRESSES RELATED TO DROUGHT AND CLIMATE CHANGE; FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY; THE HEALTH (MENTAL, PHYSICAL, AND FINANCIAL) OF HAWAI'I'S CITIZENS AND COMMUNITIES; AND HUMAN NUTRITION PROGRAMS. CTAHR WORKS WITHIN THE FRAMEWORK OF FIVE CRITICAL ISSUES: BIOENGINEERING FOR AGRICULTURE/NATURAL RESOURCES/HEALTH; BIOSECURITY OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES; DIVERSIFIED TROPICAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS; PROTECT AND MANAGE NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE ENVIRONMENT; AND YOUTH/FAMILY/COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND HEALTH.

ABSTRACT  COCCIDIOSIS IS AN ECONOMICALLY SIGNIFICANT ENTERIC DISEASE OF ALL TYPES OF COMMERCIAL POULTRY. COCCIDIOSIS IS CAUSED BY COCCIDIA, A PROTOZOAL PARASITE IN THE EIMERIA GENUS. COCCIDIA ARE UBIQUITOUS IN THE ENVIRONMENT, AND CAN BE FOUND IN ALL POULTRY PRODUCING REGIONS OF THE WORLD. PRODUCTION SYSTEMS FOR BROILERS AND BROILER BREEDERS PUT THEM MOST AT RISK FOR THE DISEASE SINCE THEY ARE IN DIRECT CONTACT WITH LITTER AND FECAL DROPPINGS AND COCCIDIA HAVE A FECAL/ORAL LIFE CYCLE. LAYER CHICKENS HOWEVER, DO NOT BREAK WITH COCCIDIOSIS WITH THE SAME FREQUENCY AS THEY HAVE BEEN TRADITIONALLY REARED IN CAGES AWAY FROM THE LITTER. COCCIDIOSIS HAS BEEN CONTROLLED USING CHEMICAL ANTI-COCCIDIALS, IONOPHORES (ANTIBIOTICS), OR LIVE COCCIDIA VACCINES, BUT RECENT GOVERNMENT REGULATIONS HAVE LIMITED THE ABILITY TO USE IONOPHORES SINCE THEY ARE CLASSIFIED AS ANTIBIOTICS. CHANGING CONSUMER SENTIMENT HAS ALSO FORCED THE LAYER INDUSTRY TO BEGIN REARING CHICKENS ON THE FLOOR OR IN AN AVIARY SYSTEMAND OUT OF CAGES, WHERE THEY ARE NOW EXPOSED TO LITTER AND FECAL MATERIAL. THE IMPACT OF THESE REGULATIONS AND CHANGING PRODUCTION PRACTICES IS NOT KNOWN, THOUGH MANY VETERINARY PROFESSIONALS ESTIMATE THAT THE INCIDENCE OF CLINICAL COCCIDIOSIS, AND THE RELATED DISEASE NECROTIC ENTERITIS, WILL DRAMATICALLY INCREASE. THERE IS CURR ENTLY A NEED FOR SURVEILLANCE AND CHARACTERIZATION OF COCCIDIA SPECIES FOUND IN CLINICAL CASES SUBMITTED TO DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORIES TO EVALUATE HOW THESE CHANGES ARE AFFECTING THE PREVALENCE OF ENTERIC DISEASE. THIS WILL BE DONE BY IDENTIFICATION, BOTH BY MORPHOLOGY AND MOLECULAR DIAGNOSTICS, OF COCCIDIA FROM THESE CASES AND CHARACTERIZATION OF PATHOGENICITY IN TRADITIONAL BIRD STUDIES AS WELL AS CHARACTERIZATION OF GENETIC MARKERS FOUND IN GENOMIC ANALYSIS. TO ACCOMPLISH THE GOALS IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL SOLICIT THE AID OF CLINICAL DIAGNOSTICIANS IN LABORATORIES ACROSS THE U.S. WE WILL ASK THAT FECAL SAMPLES (OR GUT SCRAPINGS IF NO FECES CAN BE OBTAINED) BE COLLECTED AND SHIPPED TO OUR LABORATORY AT UGA. ONCE RECEIVED, THESE SAMPLES WILL BE PROPAGATED IN CHICKENS AND IDENTIFIED BY MORPHOLOGY FROM FECAL COLLECTIONS OF THOSE BIRDS. THESE SAMPLES WILL THEN BE MOLECULARLY CHARACTERIZED USING PCR TARGETING MULTIPLE GENOMIC TARGETS, INCLUDING THE 18S, ITS-1 AND 2, AND COI GENOME REGIONS. THE LAST COMPONENT IN THE ANALYSIS WILL BE TO INOCULATE CHICKENS WITH DIFFERENT DOSES OF EACH SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN THE SAMPLING AND SCORES INTESTINAL LESIONS PRODUCED BY THE PARASITE. THIS WILL PROVIDE A PATHOGENICITY SCORE THAT CAN BE FURTHER USED TO AID IN DIAGNOSES OF THE CAUSE OF THE ORIGINATING CLINICAL PRESENTATION.

PROJECT ABSTRACT  UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE THE USDA CAPACITY GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE WILL BE USED FOR RESEARCH THAT WILL BE OF BENEFIT TO THE HEALTH OF AGRICULTURE ANIMALS WITHIN THE STATE OF GEORGIA, UNITED STATES, AND WORLDWIDE. THIS IN TURN WILL BENEFIT CONSUMERS, PRODUCERS AND THE AGRICULTURE INDUSTRY AND OTHERS IN PROTECTING FOOD SOURCES FOR HUMANS AND IN PROTECTING HUMAN HEALTH BY PREVENTING AND MITIGATING THE SPREAD OF DISEASE. POULTRY DISEASE RESEARCH A LARGE PORTION OF THE FUNDS THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE RECEIVES FROM THIS GRANT WILL BE USED FOR ADVANCED CLINICAL INVESTIGATION AND APPLIED RESEARCH ON CURRENT FIELD PROBLEMS ENCOUNTERED BY THE POULTRY DIAGNOSTIC RESEARCH CENTER (PDRC) CLINICIANS AND MASTERS OF AVIAN MEDICINE (MAM) GRADUATE STUDENTS. THE STUDIES WILL INVOLVE RESEARCH ATTEMPTING TO REPRODUCE A NATURALLY OCCURRING DISEASE OR DISEASE SYNDROME OR FIELDSTUDIES EVALUATING THE EFFECT OF MANAGEMENT/VACCINATIONS. THESE STUDIES CONDUCTED BY THE PDRC CLINICIANS AND MAM STUDENTS WILL RESULT IN PUBLICATIONS OF CASE REPORTS, RESEARCH NOTES, AND ARE EXPECTED TO PROVIDE PRELIMINARY DATA FOR GRANT APPLICATIONS FOR OTHER PDRC RESEARCHERS. THESE STUDIES WILL TEACH MAM STUDENTS ABOUT APPLIED RESEARCH DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION. THE RESEARCH WILL ALSO ASSIST THE POULTRY INDUSTRY IN DETERMINING CAUSES OF VARIOUS DISEASES OR SOLUTIONS/THERAPIES FOR THESE DISEASES. THE PRIME OBJECTIVE IS TO ESTABLISH A STRUCTURE FOR THE ADVANCED INVESTIGATION OF SELECTED CASES FOR THE PURPOSES OF ENHANCING THE UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL DISEASE PROCESSES, INVOLVING THE MAM STUDENTS IN ADVANCED INVESTIGATIONS, PROV IDING PILOT STUDY INFORMATION TO SERVE AS A FOUNDATION DATA FOR GRANTS, AND GENERATING CASE REPORTS AND RESEARCH NOTES FOR PUBLICATION. IMPROVING THE HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF LIVESTOCK AN ADDITIONAL PORTION OF FUNDS WILL BE DIRECTED TO THE FOOD ANIMAL HEALTH AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (FAHMP) WITHIN THE COLLEGE. PROTECTION OF THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF AGRICULTURAL ANIMALS (CATTLE, SMALL RUMINANTS, SWINE, AND HORSES) IS IMPORTANT FOR MULTIPLE REASONS. IN RURAL AREAS, THESE ANIMALS SERVE AS THE BASIS FOR LARGE PORTIONS OF THE ECONOMY AND WHEN DISEASE AFFECTS THEM, PORTIONS OF THE ECONOMY CAN SUFFER. MOREOVER, THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS SHOWN HOW FRAGILE THE FOOD SUPPLY CHAIN CAN BE AND THE HEALTH OF FOOD PRODUCING ANIMALS, NAMELY CATTLE, SHEEP, GOATS, AND SWINE, IS IMPORTANT TO MAINTAIN A CONTINUOUS SUPPLY OF SAFE AND WHOLESOME FOODS. RESPIRATORY AND OTHER INFECTIOUS DISEASES HAVE BEEN AND CONTINUES TO BE A MAJOR HEALTH CHALLENGE AFFECTING CATTLE AND HORSES, PARTICULARLY. ADDITIONALLY, NEW BREEDING AND PRODUCTION STRATEGIES HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO REVOLUTIONIZE THE WAY BEEF IS PRODUCED AND HOW ANIMALS ARE PROTECTED FROM COMMON PESTS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES. THE STUDIES DESCRIBED HEREIN ARE DESIGNED TO PROVIDE PRACTICAL AND APPLIED DATAFOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF AGRICULTURAL ANIMAL HEALTH AND PRODUCTION BY PROVIDING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THERAPEUTICS AND HOW DIFFERENT BREEDING STRATEGIES MAY ENHANCE ANIMAL PRODUCTIVITY. CLASSICAL PHARMACOLOGIC METHODS (PHARMACOKINETIC AND PHARMACODYNAMIC ANALYSES, INFECTIOUS DISEASE CHALLENGES) WILL BE USED TO INVESTIGATE BOTH ANTIMICROBIAL AND NON-ANTIMICROBIAL THERAPEUTICS IN HORSES AND FOOD-PRODUCING ANIMALS. IN ADDITION, NOVEL GENETIC SELECTION AND GRANT13737066 8/12 CLASSICAL BREEDING TECHNIQUES WILL BE USED TO ASSIST WITH SELECTION OF DISEASE-RESISTANT AND MORE PRODUCTIVE ANIMALS. MOLECULAR DIAGNOSTICS (16S SEQUENCING, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, ETC) WILL BE USED TO INVESTIGATE THE IMPACT OF MANAGEMENT ON RESPIRATORY AND GUT MICROBIOMES AND HOW MODULATION OF THE MICROBIOME THROUGH FEEDING IMPACTS HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF CATTLE. THE RESULTS OF ALL OF THESE AGRICULTURE ANIMAL HEALTH PROJECTS WILL BE IMPORTANT TO POULTRY, BEEF, SWINE, SHEEP AND GOAT PRODUCERS AND DISTRIBUTORS. IT WILL ALSO BE IMPORTANT TO EQUINE OWNERS AND OTHER AGRICULTURE ANIMAL OWNERS AND HANDLERS. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES – NOT APPLICABLE WE DO NOT ANTICIPATE ANY SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS AWARD. INTERNAL CALL FOR PROPOSALS WE DO PLAN TO SEND OUT AN INTERNAL CALL FOR PROPOSALS AND THEN FUND ONE OR TWO AGRICULTURE ANIMAL HEALTH RESEARCH PROJECTS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT  THE GOAL OF UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA’S ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH (AHDR) PROGRAM RESEARCH CAPACITY IS TO EXPAND OUR CURRENT STUDY OF LIVESTOCK DISEASES AND THE ROLE OF ANTIMICROBIALS IN MAINTAINING HEALTHY HERDS AND FLOCKS. THE FIRST PROJECT FOCUSES ON METRITIS, A UTERINE DISEASE OF CRITICAL RELEVANCE TO THE DAIRY INDUSTRY WORLDWIDE. METRITIS IS ONE MAJOR REASON FOR ANTIMICROBIAL USE IN LIVESTOCK, AND IS ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED PRODUCTION COSTS, DECREASED YIELDS OF MILK, AND INCREASED MORTALITY AND CULLING OF LACTATING COWS. INFERTILITY IS AMONG THE MAIN DETRIMENTS CAUSED BY METRITIS AND REDUCING PREGNANCY IN SICK ANIMALS. THE LONG-TERM GOAL IS TO DETERMINE KEY CHANGES IN UTERINE BIOLOGY ASSOCIATED WITH INFERTILITY SUBSEQUENT TO UTERINE DISEASES, SO THAT BETTER PREVENTIVE AND THERAPEUTIC STRATEGIES CAN BE DEVISED TO IMPROVE ANIMAL HEALTH AND SUSTAINABILITY OF THE DAIRY INDUSTRY. THE DESCRIBED STUDIES WILL DEFINE CHANGES IN UTERINE MICROBIOME THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH LOSS OF FERTILITY IN COWS DIAGNOSED WITH METRITIS POSTPARTUM. THE SECOND PROJECT FOCUSES ON THE LACK OF KNOWLEDGE REGARDING THE EFFECTS OF HEAT STRESS ABATEMENT STRATEGIES, AND BIOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS OF YOUNG STOCK. THE THERMOREGULATION ABILITY OF CALVES IS MINIMAL DURING THE FIRST TEN DAYS OF LIFE AND INCREASES UNTIL 60 DAYS EXACERBATING THE NEED FOR STRATEGIES TO CONTROL THE ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH THEY ARE RAISED. THE DESCRIBED STUDIES WILL DETERMINE HOW HEAT ABATEMENT STRATEGIES IMPACTS ON THE WELL-BEING OF ANIMALS AND THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THE STAKEHOLDERS IT SERVES. SUCH STUDIES ARE OF IMPORTANCE TO INVESTIGATE AND MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF HEAT STRESS AND CLIMATE CHANGE ON ANIMAL WELL-BEING AND HEALTH. THE THIRD PROJECT FOCUSES ON SPOTTY LIVER DISEASE (SLD) CAUSED BY CAMPYLOBACTER HEPATICUS. SLD IS AN EMERGING CAUSE OF MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY AND LOSS OF PRODUCTION IN COMMERCIAL LAYING HENS. CURRENTLY, THE DISEASE IS CONTROLLED BY TREATING THE AFFECTED FLOCKS WITH ANTIBIOTICS, BUT THE EMERGENCE OF ANTIBIOTIC RESISTANCE IS NEGATIVELY IMPACTING THE ANTIBIOTIC-FREE LAYER INDUSTRY. THE DESCRIBED STUDY WILL TEST VACCINATION WITH VARIOUS C. HEPATICUS PROTEINS TO DETERMINE EXTENT OF PROTECTIVE IMMUNITY CONFERRED TO CONTROL SLD. SUCH APPROACH SHOULD ALLOW FOR ADEQUATE IMMUNITY BE INDUCED DURING PEAK EGG PRODUCTION, AT WHICH TIME, BIRDS ARE MOST SUSCEPTIBLE TO SLD. RESULTS FROM THESE STUDIES WILL IMPROVE ANIMAL HEALTH MANAGEMENT AND REDUCE THE RELIANCE ON ANTIMICROBIALS BY LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT POULTRY PRODUCTION ACCOUNTS FOR A SUBSTANTIAL PORTION OF THE TOTAL FARM INCOME IN MANY AREAS OF THE WORLD AND DIRECT LOSSES FROM INFECTIOUS DISEASES CONSTITUTES AN IMPORTANT ECONOMIC FACTOR FOR MOST POULTRY PRODUCERS, AND ULTIMATELY FOR THE CONSUMER OF POULTRY PRODUCTS. INFECTIOUS LARYNGOTRACHEITIS (ILT) IS A HERPESVIRUS-INDUCED ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISEASE OF WORLD-WIDE IMPORTANCE TO THE POULTRY INDUSTRY. INFECTIOUS LARYNGOTRACHEITIS (ILT) IS CAUSED BY AN AVIAN ALPHA HERPESVIRUS OF THE ILTOVIRUS GENUS, INFECTIOUS LARYNGOTRACHEITIS VIRUS (ILTV). THIS PROJECT IS CURRENTLY FOCUSED ON TWO OBJECTIVES. FIRST, WE ARE PERFORMING THE FIRST DETAILED AND COMPREHENSIVE EXAMINATION OF THE CHICKEN’S TRANSCRIPTIONAL RESPONSE TO INFECTION WITH A VIRULENT STRAIN OF ILTV. BY CORRELATING THE CLINICAL RESPONSE OF INFECTED BIRDS TO THEIR TRANSCRIPTIONAL RESPONSE, IT IS HOPED THAT BETTER METHODS FOR CONTROLLING AND LIMITING ILTV INFECTION MAY BE DEVELOPED. THIS OBJECTIVE WILL HELP TO ANSWERTHE QUESTION OF WHAT TRANSCRIPTIONAL CHANGES ARE OCCURRING IN THE CHICKEN IN RESPONSE TO ILTV. TRACHEA, LUNG, AND SPLEEN SAMPLES WERE COLLECTED ON THE DAYS 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 10, AND 14 FROM BIRDS INFECTED WITH ILTV. RNA EXTRACTION, LIBRARY CONSTRUCTION AND HIGH THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING HAS BEEN PERFORMED. TRANSCRIPTOME ANALYSIS IS UNDERWAY. SECONDLY, UNDER COMMERCIAL CONDITIONS, A CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS OF INFECTIOUS LARYNGOTRACHEITIS (ILT) CAN BE COMPLICATED BY CO-INFECTIONS WITH OTHER VIRAL AGENTS (EITHER PATHOGENS OR VACCINES) AND/OR THE DEVELOPMENT OF SECONDARY BACTERIAL INFECTIONS. COMBINED WITH SUBOPTIMAL ENVIRONMENTAL OR MANAGEMENT CONDITIONS, A COMPLEX MULTI-FACTORED RESPIRATORY DISEASE COMPLEX (RDC) OFTEN DEVELOPS. IT IS DIFFICULT TO REPRODUCE THE COMPLEX ETIOLOGY OF RDC UNDER DEFINED LABORATORY CONDITIONS DUE TO THE INABILITY TO REPRODUCE THE COMPLEX MICROBIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL ENVIRONMENT FOUND IN A COMMERCIAL BROILER FACILITY. WE HAVE RECENTLY DETERMINED THE BASELINE MICROBIAL COMPOSITION (ANIMAL VIRUS, BACTERIOPHAGE, BACTERIA, PROTOZOA, FUNGI) OF THE TRACHEA IN A NORMAL COMMERCIAL BROILER FLOCK FROM PLACEMENT THROUGH PROCESSING, 7 WEEKS. WE ARE CURRENTLY EXAMINING THE POTENTIAL OF DETERMINING THE COMPOSITION OF THE AVIAN RESPIRATORY MICROBIOME ON AN INDIVIDUAL BIRDS.

ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH CAPACITY PROGRAM ABSTRACT 1. FEDERAL AWARD PURPOSE - THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH (AHDR) PROGRAM IS A NATIONAL-SCOPE CAPACITY PROGRAM THAT DISTRIBUTES FEDERAL FUNDS ON A FORMULA BASIS TO ALL ELIGIBLE ENTITIES, INCLUDING ALL STATE AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATIONS (SAES) AND AMERICAN VETERINARY MEDICAL ASSOCIATION (AVMA) ACCREDITED U.S. COLLEGES OR SCHOOLS OF VETERINARY MEDICINE, FOR THE SUPPORT OF RESEARCH PROJECTS ADDRESSING HEALTH AND DISEASE OF AGRICULTURAL ANIMALS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDING IS TO PROMOTE ANIMAL HEALTH RESEARCH AT ACCREDITED STATE VETERINARY SCHOOLS OR COLLEGES OR AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATIONS. 2. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - SAES FUNDED AHDR ACTIVITIES CONSIST OF PEER REVIEWED RESEARCH PROJECTS, AS WELL AS ADMINISTRATIVE PROGRAM PLANNING AND DIRECTION. 3. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOME - PROGRAM OUTPUTS INCLUDE PUBLICATIONS AND DISSEMINATION OF STUDY RESULTS IN JOURNAL ARTICLE PU BLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS AT NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCES AND HUMAN CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT IN ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE NEW KNOWLEDGE IN THE FIELDS OF ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASES. STUDY RESULTS SERVE AS A BASIS FOR FUTURE RESEARCH AND CONTRIBUTIONS TO NEW DISCOVERIES TO IMPROVE AGRICULTURAL ANIMAL HEALTH. 4. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES FOR OUR AHDR PROJECTS INCLUDE RESEARCH SCIENTISTS AND INDUSTRY PARTNERS INTERESTED IN ANIMAL HEALTH AND DI SEASE, AND MASTERS, DOCTORAL, AND POSTDOCTORAL SCIENTISTS RECEIVING TRAINING IN AGRICULTURAL HEALTH SCIENCES.

UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS SYSTEM DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE (DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE) FACULTY, STAFF AND FACILITIES ARE LOCATED ON SEVEN UNIVERSITY CAMPUSES, FOUR RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CENTERS, SIX RESEARCH STATIONS, TWO EXTENSION CENTERS, AND IN ALL 75 COUNTIES. A FIFTH REGIONAL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CENTER IS CURRENTLY UNDER CONSTRUCTION. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE REMAINS COMMITTED TO THIS STATEWIDE INFRASTRUCTURE WITH A PRESENCE IN ALL 75 ARKANSAS COUNTIES, ENSURING THAT RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION EDUCATORS ARE READILY AVAILABLE TO ADDRESS THE SCIENCE AND BUSINESS OF AGRICULTURE AND THE BROADER NEEDS OF FAMILIES AND THE COMMUNITIES WE SERVE. CONSISTENT WITH THE LAND GRANT MISSION, DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION FACULTY HAVE A LONG HISTORY OF PROVIDING LEADERSHIP IN THE DEVELOPMENT, DISSEMINATION AND DELIVERY OF INNOVATIVE PRACTICES AND EMERGING TECHNOLOGY. DIVISION RESEARCHERS CONDUCT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH FOR ARKANSAS PRODUCERS, BUSINESSES, COMMUNITIES, AND FAMILIES. COUNTY AGENTS AND SPECIALISTS STRIVE TO PROVIDE THE BEST SCIENCE‐BASED RECOMMENDATIONS AVAILABLE. ALTHOUGH STAKEHOLDERS ARE EXPOSED TO MULTIPLE SOURCES AND COPIOUS AMOUNTS OF INFORMATION AND DATA, THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE REMAINS A RELIABLE SOURCE OF IMPARTIAL AND SCIENCE‐BASED RECOMMENDATIONS, INDEPENDENT OF FINANCIAL OR PHILOSOPHICAL INTERESTS. ALTHOUGH MOST IN‐PERSON EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES HAVE RESUMED, THE DIVISION WILL CONTINUE TO DELIVER TIMELY AND RESPONSIVE DISTANCE EDUCATION WEBINARS AND RESOURCES IN 2023 TO ENSURE WIDE‐SPREAD ACCESS TO EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS BY ARKANSANS. THIS INCLUDES MONTHLY WEBINARS THROUGH THE NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL LAW CENTER ON CURRENT AND EMERGING IMPORTANT AGRICULTURAL, ENVIRONMENTAL AND FOOD LAW TOPICS. ONLINE COURSES ARE AVAILABLE 24/7/365 THROUGH THE DIVISION’S WEBSITE (HTTP://COURSES.UADA.EDU). DIVISION FACULTY ALSO ADDRESS TIMELY TOPICS OF INTEREST TO ARKANSANS THROUGH VIRTUAL EVENTS AND OTHER WEB‐BASED PROGRAMMING. THE FOCUS OF WORK CONDUCTED BY THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE CONTINUES TO BE GUIDED ANNUALLY BY GRASSROOTS, COMMUNITY‐BASED INPUT FROM A DIVERSE RANGE OF ARKANSAS CITIZENS; MAINLY THROUGH THE USE OF COUNTY EXTENSION COUNCILS AND OTHER LOCAL AND PROGRAM ADVISORY GROUPS. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE FORMALLY ENGAGED A LARGE POOL OF STAKEHOLDERS (INCLUDING INDIVIDUAL CLIENTELE, PRODUCERS, SCHOOLS, PARTNER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS, STATE GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, UNDERSERVED GROUPS, AND LEGISLATORS) IN THE DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE 2017‐2023 STRATEGIC PLAN. BASED ON BROAD STAKEHOLDER FEEDBACK, THE DIVISION IDENTIFIED FIVE AREAS TO FOCUS OUR EFFORTS: AGRICULTURAL AND FORESTRY PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING, ACCESS TO SAFE AND NUTRITIOUS FOOD, STRENGTHENING ARKANSAS FAMILIES, BUILDING COMMUNITIES AND STRENGTHENING ECONOMIES, AND NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT. THESE FIVE EMPHASIS AREAS HELP TO PROVIDE STRATEGIC LOCAL GUIDANCE FOR DIVISION RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AND HELP TO SUPPORT INTEGRATED RESEARCH/EXTENSION EFFORTS THAT ALIGN WITH THE NIFA SCIENCE EMPHASIS AREAS.  AGRICULTURAL AND FORESTRY PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING A CRITICAL NEED IN ARKANSAS, AND NATIONWIDE, IS TO ENSURE FARM AND FOREST ENTERPRISES ARE PROFITABLE AND SUSTAINABLE TO MEET THE DEMANDS FOR SAFE FOOD, FIBER, AND FUEL. THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY MUST CONTEND WITH MORE REGULATIONS, HIGHER INPUT COSTS, FLUCTUATING COMMODITY PRICES, CLIMATE EXTREMES, AND GLOBAL TRADE POLICIES. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WILL FOCUS ON INCREASING PRODUCTIVITY IN A HUMANE AND SUSTAINABLE MANNER WHILE DECREASING COSTS THROUGH EFFICIENT USE OF RESOURCES. PLANT SYSTEMS EMPHASIZE ECONOMICS, ENVIRONMENT, GENETICS AND BREEDING, WEEDS, DISEASE, PEST MANAGEMENT, SAFE HANDLING AND STORAGE, FOOD PROCESSING, CULTURAL PRACTICES, AND SOIL FERTILITY.  ANIMAL SYSTEMS EMPHASIZE GENETICS, REPRODUCTION, ECONOMICS, NUTRITION, WASTE MANAGEMENT, PHYSIOLOGY, ENVIRONMENTAL STRESS, HEALTH, AND ANIMAL WELLBEING. COMMON TO BOTH PLANT AND ANIMAL SYSTEMS IS THE APPROPRIATE USE OF NEW PRODUCTS AND TECHNOLOGY.  ACCESS TO SAFE AND NUTRITIOUS FOODS THE AVAILABILITY OF SAFE AND NUTRITIOUS FOOD IS VITAL TO FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS IN ALL COMMUNITIES. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE WORKS TO PROMOTE HEALTHY DIETS THROUGH RESEARCH AND PUBLIC EDUCATION EFFORTS THAT TARGET OBESITY AND ENCOURAGE BETTER CONSUMER HABITS THROUGH PROGRAMS SUCH AS THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) AND SNAP‐ED. EFNEP EMPOWERS INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN, WITH LIMITED INCOME, TO ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDE, AND BEHAVIOR CHANGES NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND ENHANCE PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT. SNAP‐ED PROVIDES NUTRITION EDUCATION TO FOOD STAMP RECIPIENTS AND THOSE INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WHO ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE NUTRITION ASSISTANCE TO HELP CONSUMERS MAKE BETTER CHOICES ABOUT WHAT TO EAT TO STAY ACTIVE AND LIVE BETTER. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE SEEKS TO STRENGTHEN FOOD SYSTEMS THROUGH RESEARCH AND INNOVATION. THE LONGTERM GROWTH OF THE FOOD INDUSTRY IN ARKANSAS IS DEPENDENT UPON THE INDUSTRY’S ABILITY TO INNOVATE, TO RESPOND TO CONSUMERS’ TASTE AND EXPECTATIONS, TO EMPLOY A QUALITY WORKFORCE AND TO MINIMIZE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS AND THE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES WHILE MAINTAINING ECONOMIC VIABILITY. PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMUNITY LEADERS AND AGENCIES ARE PURSUED TO INCREASE ACCESS TO NUTRITIOUS FOODS. EXTENSION PROGRAMS HELP PEOPLE FROM MANY BACKGROUNDS UNDERSTAND HOW TO MAKE WISE NUTRITIONAL CHOICES AND STRETCH FOOD DOLLARS BY COOKING FOR THEMSELVES AND UTILIZE A WIDER VARIETY OF FOODS. THE DIVISION ALSO STRIVES TO ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY THROUGH RESEARCH AND TEACHING BEST PRACTICES TO ALL WHO HANDLE FOOD, FROM FIELD TO TABLE. THIS INCLUDES EDUCATION RELATED TO FEDERAL AND STATE LAWS, SUCH AS HOW TO ADHERE TO THE FDA’S PRODUCE SAFETY RULE AND MEETING CERTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS OF THE ARKANSAS DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH THROUGH SERVSAFE, A FOOD SAFETY CERTIFICATION PROGRAM FOR INDIVIDUALS WHO WORK IN FOOD HANDLING OR FOOD SERVICE AND RELATED INDUSTRIES. EXTENSION EDUCATORS PROVIDE EVIDENCE‐BASED INFORMATION TO ENSURE THAT ARKANSANS ARE EQUIPPED WITH THE BEST FOOD SAFETY INFORMATION TO KEEP THEIR FAMILIES SAFE FROM FOODBORNE ILLNESSES AND OTHER FOOD‐RELATED SAFETY ISSUES. STRENGTHENING ARKANSAS FAMILIES  IT IS CRITICAL TO ADDRESS CHALLENGES THAT AFFECT FAMILIES, CONSUMERS, AND THE COMMUNITIES IN WHICH THEY LIVE. THE MENTAL, PHYSICAL, AND FINANCIAL WELL‐BEING OF FAMILIES AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF YOUTH ARE ESSENTIAL TO BUILDING PROSPERITY FOR ARKANSANS. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE IS RESPONDING TO THESE NEEDS BY DELIVERING RESEARCH‐BASED PROGRAMS TO REDUCE STRESS, IMPROVE MENTAL HEALTH, STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS, INCREASE FINANCIAL STABILITY, AND IMPROVE WELL‐BEING FOR ARKANSANS. 4‐H CLUBS, ACTIVITIES AND EVENTS ACROSS ARKANSAS INVOLVE YOUNG PEOPLE IN HANDS‐ON EDUCATION AND SERVICE‐LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES THAT ENHANCED THEIR LIFE SKILLS, INCLUDING DECISION MAKING, PROBLEM SOLVING, CRITICAL THINKING, COMMUNICATIONS, AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLE CHOICES. 4‐H CONVEYS TO THE PUBLIC THAT ALL YOUTH HAVE VALUE. STRIVING TO REACH A DIVERSE POPULATION IS KEY TO DEVELOPING CURRICULUM, OFFERING RECOGNITION, AND TEACHING STRONG LEADERSHIP SKILLS TO REPRESENT OUR STATE’S CURRENT DEMOGRAPHICS. BUILDING COMMUNITIES AND STRENGTHENING ECONOMIES  CHANGES IN THE ECONOMY, TECHNOLOGY AND POPULATION ARE TRANSFORMING HOW ARKANSANS LIVE AND WORK. THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED FOR BUSINESSES TO UNDERSTAND THEIR CHANGING ECONOMIC ENVIRONMENT AND EFFECTIVELY EMPLOY TOOLS AND RESOURCES. AT THE SAME TIME, THE LABOR FORCE REQUIRES ENHANCED SKILLS AND TRAINING TO SUCCEED IN TODAY’S GLOBAL ECONOMY. AT A TIME WHEN MANY RURAL AREAS ARE LOSING POPULATION, COMMUNITIES MUST TAKE A PROACTIVE APPROACH TO CREATE A HIGH QUALITY OF LIFE AND PLACE IF THEY WANT TO SURVIVE. EFFECTIVE AND INCLUSIVE LEADERS WORKING WITH ENGAGED CITIZENS ARE KEY TO THIS EFFORT. TO ADDRESS THESE CRITICAL NEEDS, PROGRAMS FOCUS ON FOUR AREAS: ECONOMIC VIABILITY AND SUSTAINABILITY; ENTREPRENEURSHIP IN EVOLVING ECONOMIES; LEADERSHIP AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT; AND QUALITY OF LIFE AND PLACE.  NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ARKANSAS FACES CRITICAL NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUES INCLUDING GROUNDWATER DECLINE IN EASTERN ARKANSAS FROM IRRIGATION, WATER QUALITY CONCERNS FROM ANIMAL MANURES, SEDIMENT LOSS FROM CROPLAND AND URBAN STORMWATER. WE ALL SHARE CONCERNS FOR SOIL HEALTH, AIR QUALITY, PROTECTION OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES OF FORESTS AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, BUT AGRICULTURE IS UNDER SCRUTINY TO REDUCE IMPACT ON NATURAL RESOURCES. WE FOCUS ON UNBIASED RESEARCH AND SCIENCE‐BASED EXTENSION EFFORTS TO BALANCE CONSERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES. PROGRAMS, SUCH AS ARKANSAS DISCOVERY FARMS AND THE CENTER FOR AGRICULTURAL AND RURAL SUSTAINABILITY, WILL COLLABORATE WITH FARMERS, LANDOWNERS, AND INDUSTRY TO DELIVER INNOVATIVE, SUSTAINABLE PROGRAMS TO ENSURE PROPER CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES. IN ADDITION TO ANNUAL STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT ACTIVITIES TO INFORM RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS, THE DIVISION WILL LAUNCH A FORMAL AND COMPREHENSIVE EFFORT IN 2023 TO IDENTIFY PRIORITIES FOR THE ORGANIZATION’S NEW STRATEGIC PLAN WITH INPUT FROM STAKEHOLDERS THAT REPRESENT THE DIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS.

THERE IS A NEED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND EVALUATE THE BOVINE IMMUNE RESPONSE TO VIRAL INFECTION, AS WELL AS THE IMPACT OF VIRAL INFECTIONS ON THE IMMUNE SYSTEM. THE OBJECTIVE WILL EXAMINE HOW SPECIFIC VIRAL PATHOGENS INTERACT WITH THE HOST TO MODULATE IMMUNE RESPONSES BY UTILIZING METHODS AIMED AT MEASURING PROTECTIVE IMMUNE RESPONSES IN ADDITION TO IMMUNOMODULATORY MEASURES. RECENTLY STUDIES HAVE DEMONSTRATED THE IMPORTANCE OF EARLY EXPOSURE TO VIRAL ANTIGENS IN SHAPING LONG-TERM SPECIFIC IMMUNOLOGICAL MEMORY AND IS TERMED IMMUNOLOGICAL IMPRINTING. ANOTHER CONSIDERATION IS THE NOTORIOUS COSTLY PROCESS OF AN IMMUNE RESPONSE THAT OFTEN RESULTS IN CAUSES TRADE-OFFS WITH OTHER COSTLY ACTIVITIES SUCH AS REPRODUCTION AND GROWTH, HIGHLIGHTING THAT A ROBUST AND GREATER IMMUNE RESPONSE MAY NOT NECESSARILY BENEFIT PRODUCTION ANIMALS AND MAY NOT BE NECESSARY TO CONFER PROTECTION. A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF LEVERAGING DIFFERENT VACCINATION STRATEGIES TO MAXIMIZE PRODUCTION AND PRIME IMMUNE RESPONSES ARE NEEDED. RESULTS GENERATED UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL LEAD TO AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF HOW SPECIFIC RESPIRATORY VIRUSES INDUCE A MORE ROBUST PROTECTIVE RESPONSE OR IMMUNOMODULATORY AND HOW IMMUNE RESPONSES TO VIRUSES MAY BE REGULATED TRANSCRIPTIONALLY. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED FOR DESIGNING NEW VACCINES, THAT ELICIT BROADER PROTECTIVE IMMUNITY, PROVIDING GREATER KNOWLEDGE FOR THE SELECTION OF VIRUS STRAINS USED IN VACCINES, AND PROVIDING A BETTER KNOWLEDGE OF VACCINATION STRATEGIES THAT ELICIT BROADER PROTECTIVE RESPONSES, AND A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HOW VIRAL PATHOGENS INTERACT WITH THE HOST TO MODULATE IMMUNE RESPONSES IS NECESSARY TO IMPLEMENT INTERVENTION STRATEGIES AS THEY RELATE TO CONTROL OF BOVINE VIRAL PATHOGENS.

ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM FY 2023 THE SCHOOL OF VETERINARY MEDICINE PROJECT ABSTRACT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA (UC) HAS A LONG HISTORY OF SERVING SOCIETY THROUGH RESEARCH, OUTREACH, AND EDUCATION AIMED AT SOLVING IMPORTANT PROBLEMS INVOLVING CALIFORNIA AND ITS DIVERSE AGRICULTURAL ENTERPRISES. UNIQUE AMONGST THE ENTIRE TEN UC CAMPUS SYSTEM, THE SCHOOL OF VETERINARY MEDICINE, SERVES SOCIETY THROUGH NUMEROUS RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS RELATED TO ANIMAL HEALTH AND SUSTAINABLE FOOD SYSTEMS. THE ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH CAPACITY FUNDS GIVEN TO THE SCHOOL OF VETERINARY MEDICINE (SVM) ARE USED TO SUPPORT SVM FACULTY RESEARCH RELATED TO PRODUCTION ANIMAL HEALTH. THIS RESEARCH WILL PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE FOOD SYSTEMS IN THE ENTIRE UNITED STATES AND ALSO SERVE STAKEHOLDERS FROM CALIFORNIA’S DIVERSE AGRICULTURE COMMUNITY. THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED WILL BE BROAD, REFLECTING THE DIVERSITY OF FACULTY RESEARCH FOCUS AREAS INVOLVING THE FOLLOWING AGRICULTURAL COMMODITY AREAS: DAIRY CATTLE, BEEF CATTLE, POULTRY, SMALL RUMINANTS (SHEEP AND GOATS), SWINE, AND AQUACULTURE. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE DATA GENERATED THROUGH BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH AIMED AT PROMOTING SUSTAINABLE FOOD SYSTEMS, AS WELL AS EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH THROUGH THE NETWORK OF UC AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SPECIALISTS AND ADVISORS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL BE INCREASES IN KNOWLEDGE TO HELP SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION ANIMAL AGRICULTURE IN CALIFORNIA AND THE UNITED STATES. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES FROM THESE ACTIVITIES WILL BE CALIFORNIA’S AGRICULTURE ANIMAL PRODUCERS AS WELL AS DOMESTIC AND FOREIGN CONSUMERS OF ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

PROGRAM SUMMARY – UC ANR ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH  DESCRIPTION UC AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES OVERSEES UC’S AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION’S ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE RESEARCH PROGRAM. THE RESEARCH PROJECTS APPROVED FOR THIS CAPACITY PROGRAM ALIGN WITH NIFA’S GUIDANCE TO “IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF FOOD ANIMALS AND HORSES THROUGH EFFECTIVE PREVENTION, CONTROL OR TREATMENT OF DISEASE, REDUCTION OF LOSSES FROM TRANSPORTATION AND OTHER HAZARDS, AND PROTECTION OF HUMAN HEALTH THROUGH CONTROL OF ANIMAL DISEASES TRANSMISSIBLE TO PEOPLE.” THE PROJECTS FOCUS ON ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASES AND CAN INCLUDE HOW TO IMPROVE ANIMAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS AND ANIMAL WELFARE. THE RESEARCHERS BRING EXPERTISE IN THE FOLLOWING DISCIPLINES: ANIMAL SCIENCE, POPULATION HEALTH AND REPRODUCTION, ECOSYSTEM SCIENCES, ENTOMOLOGY, AND MEDICINE AND EPIDEMIOLOGY.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THE TARGET AUDIENCES ARE CALIFORNIA FARMERS, RANCHERS, AND OTHER ALLIED INDUSTRY PROFESSIONALS INVOLVED IN ANIMAL PRODUCTION SYSTEMS, STEWARDING THE HEALTH AND WELFARE OF DAIRY AND BEEF CATTLE, POULTRY, GOATS, SHEEP, AND FISH. THESE PROJECTS ALSO AIM TO SHARE NEW KNOWLEDGE AND TOOLS WITH EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS AND OTHER ACADEMIC EXPERTS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS, SUCH AS GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND NON-PROFITS, THAT SERVE THIS AGRICULTURAL SECTOR.  ACTIVITIES, DELIVERABLES, <(>&<)> EXPECTED OUTCOMES CURRENT RESEARCH IS BRIEFLY DESCRIBED BELOW BY ANIMAL COMMODITY. DAIRIES ONE STUDY IS RESPONDING TO RECENT GUIDELINES OF THE NATIONAL DAIRY FARM (FARMERS ASSURING RESPONSIBLE MANAGEMENT) PROGRAM THAT REQUIRED ALL PARTICIPATING DAIRIES TO DISBUD CALVES BEFORE 8-WEEKS OF AGE AND PROVIDE A PAIN MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR DISBUDDING. A SURVEY IS BEING CONDUCTED TO 1) DESCRIBE THE CURRENT DISBUDDING AND DEHORNING PRACTICES, INCLUDING PAIN CONTROL USE ON CALIFORNIA DAIRIES; AND 2) IDENTIFY FACTORS THAT HINDER THE ADOPTION OF PAIN MANAGEMENT PLANS ON CALIFORNIA DAIRIES. ANOTHER STUDY IS WORKING TO DEVELOP MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF LAMENESS AT THE GENETIC SELECTION LEVEL. LAMENESS AND HOOF HEALTH HAS NOT BEEN STUDIED MUCH BUT IMPACTS DAIRY PRODUCERS BOTH AS AN ANIMAL WELFARE ISSUE AS WELL AS LOWERED MILK PRODUCTION. IT IS ONE OF THE TOP THREE REASONS DAIRY CATTLE ARE CULLED PREMATURELY, FOLLOWING INFERTILITY AND MASTITIS. PREMATURE CULLING REPRESENTS A SIGNIFICANT COST TO THE PRODUCER AND CONTRIBUTES TO THE OVERALL CARBON FOOTPRINT OF THE DAIRY DUE TO THE ENVIRONMENTAL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH RAISING REPLACEMENT DAIRY HEIFERS. OTHER RESEARCH IS EXAMINING THE EFFECT OF DAIRY CALVE HOUSING (GROUP VS INDIVIDUAL) ON THE DYNAMICS OF ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE OF COMMENSAL FECAL E.COLI AND ENTEROCOCCUS SPECIES BACTERIA IN CALVES HOUSED IN THE CALIFORNIA-STYLE INDIVIDUAL HUTCH WITH A SIMPLE MODIFICATION TO ACCOMMODATE GROUP HOUSING. DAIRY CALVES IN CALIFORNIA ARE TYPICALLY RAISED IN INDIVIDUAL HUTCHES; YET THERE IS INCREASING INTEREST IN GROUP HOUSING OF PRE-WEANED CALVES, AND CONSUMER INTEREST IN HOUSING SYSTEMS WHICH PERMIT EXPRESSION OF NATURAL BEHAVIORS, SUCH AS SOCIAL GROOMING AND PLAY. HOWEVER, GROUP HOUSED CALVES HAVE INCREASED CALF-TO-CALF CONTACT, AND SHARE A MICROBIOME WITH THEIR PEN-MATES, INCREASING THE POTENTIAL FOR SPREAD OF INFECTIOUS DISEASE. THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION TO DAIRY PRODUCERS, CALF CAREGIVERS, VETERINARIANS, AND OTHERS INTERESTED IN DAIRY CALF HEALTH AND WELFARE ABOUT THE BENEFITS AND RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH GROUP HOUSING COMPARED TO INDIVIDUAL HOUSING OF CALVES IN CALIFORNIA.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS FEDERAL AWARD IS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES ALIGNED WITH THE BROAD GOALS OF THE USDA AND STAKEHOLDER GROUPS IN ARIZONA. ACTIVITIES ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING CRITICAL ISSUES: ENSURING A SUSTAINABLE, PROFITABLE, AND COMPETITIVE FOOD AND FIBER SYSTEM IN ARIZONA; ENHANCING NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT; IMPROVING THE HEALTH, SAFETY, AND ECONOMIC SECURITY OF ARIZONA FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES; PREPARING ARIZONA YOUTH TO BE PRODUCTIVE CITIZENS; AND PREPARING ARIZONA’S AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY FOR SOLUTIONS OF THE FUTURE. PROJECTS ARE IDENTIFIED THROUGH A COMPETITIVE PROCESS, ARE ADMINISTERED IN ALIGNMENT WITH THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE HATCH, HATCH MULTISTATE, ANIMAL HEALTH AND SMITH-LEVER PROGRAMS, AND CONTINUE THE LONG-STANDING INTEGRATION BETWEEN RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WITH STRONG STAKEHOLDER INPUT. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE NEW KNOWLEDGE LEADING TO PEER REVIEWED AND GENERAL PUBLICATIONS, IMPROVEMENTS IN THE FUNCTIONING, PRODUCTIVITY AND LONG-TERM HEALTH OF ARIZONA’S AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM, IMPROVED HEALTH, AND WELLBEING OF THE CITIZENS OF ARIZONA, INCLUDING RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, AND ENHANCED ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ACROSS THE STATE. BENEFICIARIES EXTEND ACROSS THE STATE WITH EMPHASIS ON RURAL AND TRIBAL AREAS.
